The research, conducted by Cass Business School, Warwick University, and the University of Wisconsin, analyzed data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey. The study controlled for factors such as part-time work, parental status, and qualifications. The results showed that when comparing like-for-like male and female workers, men were 25% more likely to receive a pay rise when they asked. The study also found no evidence to support the theory that women are less likely to ask for a pay rise due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from a perceived female stereotype. The researchers suggested that there may be an element of pure discrimination against women, as unsuccessful men who asked for a pay rise may not have shared their experiences. The study also found that women and men under 40 were equally likely to ask for and receive pay rises, indicating a potential change in negotiating behavior.

The Oxford City Council has been searching for a new burial site for many years, but has not found a suitable location. The two remaining cemeteries, Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021, respectively. The council has conducted ground investigations on several potential sites, but all have been discounted due to size, ground conditions, high water table, or covenants restricting use. After the cemeteries are full, only the reopening of family plots, use of reserved plots, and interment of ashes will be possible. The last increase in burial space in Oxford was in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis from 19-22 July, will offer an augmented reality experience through an app. This feature will allow visitors to access online information from signs and posters, watch videos, and interviews with bands like The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Dougie MacLean. Non-attendees can also interact with the festival and experience its atmosphere remotely. The app will provide real-time updates, ticket purchasing options, and a taste of the festival's unique offerings.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. He suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, which is rare and can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, but had never collapsed before. He had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime".

The passage describes a case where a 15-year-old girl was raped by a woman named Davina Ayrton, who was previously known as David Ayrton, in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Ayrton, now 34, has been found guilty and is awaiting sentencing on March 4. She will be held in a male prison in Winchester due to prison service protocols. Ayrton has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer. The victim, who had only consumed a can and a half of beer, clearly remembered the incident and shouted at Ayrton to stop. Ayrton revealed the attack to a care home worker in 2014.

The passage discusses Novak Djokovic's recent tennis matches. He lost his doubles match in Rio with his partner, scoring 4-6 and 4-6 against Brazilian pair Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares. This loss followed his defeat in the singles match the previous day against Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic, the world number one and 12-time Grand Slam winner, also experienced a surprise third-round defeat at Wimbledon in July against American Sam Querrey. Despite these setbacks, Djokovic managed to win the Toronto Masters title before the Olympics.

The passage describes an upcoming chainsaw carving competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, Scotland. Over 20 competitors from various countries, including Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US, will participate. The carvers can only use chainsaws to create sculptures of animals and people. The defending champion, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will attempt to defend his title and win the Claymore Trophy.

Webb, a 27-year-old Welsh rugby player, has been recovering from a serious foot injury sustained in a World Cup warm-up match with Italy in September. He is currently undergoing a pre-season-like training program and aims to return to play before the Six Nations tournament in February. Webb has renewed his contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay with his home region despite offers from other teams.

The incident involved two men, Jeffrey Laviolette and Nathan Hall, who were attempting to smuggle a load of MDMA (ecstasy) from Canada to San Francisco. They were intercepted by US border agents near the border in Washington state. One of the men, Hall, fired at the agents and fled, while Laviolette was taken into custody. Hall was later arrested in Canada. The backpacks they were carrying contained 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy. A woman, Kali Henifin, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were also arrested for their involvement in the plan. The three in US custody face charges of conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution. The area where the incident occurred is known for drug and firearm smuggling.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported a significant increase in counseling children affected by online abuse, with 4,500 children in the past year compared to 2,400 in 2011-12. The charity highlighted that online trolls cause misery and humiliation for many children, with some as young as seven experiencing torment and fear. Dame Esther Rantzen, Childline's president, emphasized the need for adults, parents, and teachers to intervene and protect children from cyber-bullying, as it can follow them home and become a persecution they cannot escape. The report was released during Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which aims to combat the problem with the help of parents, schools, and other organizations.

The passage discusses a series of events related to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The US abstained from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction, which infuriated Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. The resolution, which was passed on Friday, states that the establishment of settlements has no legal validity and constitutes a flagrant violation under international law. Israel rejected the resolution and responded by recalling ambassadors, cutting aid, and cancelling a visit. The Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee had planned to vote on authorizing 492 new homes in settlements, but postponed the vote at the request of Netanyahu's office to avoid further straining relations with Washington. US Secretary of State John Kerry is expected to lay out his vision for ending the conflict later on Wednesday.

The passage discusses the Queen's 90th birthday celebrations, including a visit to a Royal Mail delivery office, a ceremony to open a new bandstand, and a lunch with US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama at Windsor Castle. Prince William speaks about his commitment to royal duty and his grandmother, the Queen, as a role model. The passage also mentions criticism of Prince William's work ethic and the differing approaches to public life between Prince William and his father, Prince Charles.

West Ham United scored two goals in the first half, both from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew, to secure a 2-0 win over Cheltenham Town in the EFL Cup. Sakho scored the first goal from Sam Byram's pass, and Ayew added the second moments later. Cheltenham had chances to score, with Harry Pell's volley and Jordon Forster's header, but West Ham's goalkeeper Adrian did not have to make any significant saves. West Ham made seven changes following top-flight losses, while Cheltenham started with the same lineup from their previous match. The match ended with West Ham winning 2-0, and Cheltenham's exit ended League Two's representation in the EFL Cup.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a motorcycle accident caused by Andreas Werner, a 46-year-old man from Leipzig. Werner failed to notice McNicholl as he turned his VW Transporter, resulting in the fatal collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion on Sunday. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates' Court and was fined Â£1,000 and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family expressed no desire for Werner to be imprisoned, acknowledging the incident as a momentary lapse.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old British jihadist from Southall, London, is facing a possible life imprisonment for his role in Syria's battlefields. He left the UK in January 2015 and joined the group Rayat al Tawheed, which included many British men. Khawaja was involved in appeals for donations, video diaries, and propaganda videos. He was also involved in a gruesome incident where he was seen holding a bag containing a head of a supposed Syrian army soldier. Khawaja returned to the UK in June 2015 and was arrested at Dover. He has admitted to four offenses and is considered a dangerous man by the police.

Kayden Jackson, a 22-year-old player, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, contributing to their 8th place finish in the table. He has now joined Barnsley as their third signing for the upcoming season, ahead of their League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday. Jackson is known for his pace and ability to get past defenders, which aligns with Barnsley's playing style. He declined a contract offer from Wrexham for the next season.

A large number of bottles, believed to be from a container that fell overboard from a ship during stormy weather near Land's End in May, have been washing up on beaches in Cornwall, including Poldhu Cove and other nearby coves. The bottles are sealed but some have leaked, posing a risk to wildlife. The National Trust and Cornwall Wildlife Trust are concerned about the impact on marine life. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency has not confirmed if the bottles are from the lost container. The public is advised to keep children and dogs away from the bottles and not attempt to recover them.

The incident took place on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness around 14:00. Multiple individuals sustained minor injuries in the crash. The road was subsequently closed, and diversions were established via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is currently investigating the incident.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French center-back, played a significant role in Bolton's promotion to the Championship by making 14 appearances last season. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has since made 83 appearances in all competitions. Dervite's contributions towards the end of the season were recognized by manager Phil Parkinson, who also mentioned that he had signed new contracts along with other teammates, including David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

The passage discusses a strained relationship between the Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) and Labour in the UK Parliament, particularly regarding Brexit. The Lib Dems accused Labour of conceding too much, while Labour criticized the Lib Dems for giving false hope to EU citizens and those worried about their future in Britain. The two parties had previously collaborated to defeat the government on EU citizens' rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal, but this cooperation ended when MPs rejected their amendments. The Lib Dems were determined to insist on their amendments, while Labour was prepared to defer to the Commons. The Labour source described the Lib Dems' actions as grandstanding for their campaign leaflets, while the Lib Dems accused Labour of supporting a hard Brexit. The two parties have a history of forming alliances on various issues, but the Labour source predicted residual tensions and a lack of demand for future collaborations.

The passage discusses the low priority of defence in the current election, with Philip Hammond stating that there are no votes in defence. The public and politicians have a sense of combat fatigue due to UK military interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Libya. The UK's defence forces are being reduced, with the Army's size being cut from 102,000 to 82,000, and the Royal Navy and RAF having fewer warships and fast jet squadrons. The UK has fallen to sixth place in defence spending, below the US, China, Russia, Saudi Arabia, and France. The UK is not meeting the NATO goal of spending 2% of GDP on defence, and it is expected to fall below the threshold. The military top brass know that further cuts are likely, and the MoD has a large non-protected budget. The Conservatives plan to replace Trident and increase the defence equipment budget, but this may make it difficult to find significant savings in defence

Barcelona, the Spanish champions, have made a complimentary tax declaration of 13.55 million euros to cover potential interpretations of tax obligations related to Neymar's transfer. They deny any wrongdoing in the transfer process, which cost them a total of 106.8 million euros, including fees, wages, and taxes. The club's former president, Sandro Rosell, is also under investigation for alleged misappropriation of funds.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old delivery driver from Nottingham, was killed in a car crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, an 82-year-old man driving the wrong way on the motorway. Luciw's family advocates for regular driving tests for older drivers, while Age UK emphasizes the importance of older people maintaining their driving abilities. The crash occurred at 02:00 GMT on 12 October near Kegworth, Leicestershire, with Luciw and his colleague Andy Harrington in the van. Harrington sustained serious injuries and also supports mandatory medical examinations for older drivers. The DVLA maintains that evidence does not show older drivers are more likely to cause accidents, and they have no plans to restrict licensing based on age.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding transvaginal mesh implants used to treat incontinence, with many women experiencing debilitating side effects. The original review group faced criticism for a watered-down report, leading to two members resigning in protest. An independent expert, Alison Britton, will examine the review process and its conclusions. The report recommends against routine procedures for pelvic organ prolapse, advocates for informed patient choices, and mandates adverse event reporting. Despite calls for a ban, the health secretary states that the government lacks the power to do so. The review's chairwoman apologized for failing to unite panel members and acknowledged the difficulty of the task. Two women who suffered complications resigned from the review group, citing dismay and disgust at the final report. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had mesh or tape implants, with more than 400 currently taking legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old Scottish athlete, broke Jennifer McColgan's 25-year-old 5K record by 14 seconds with a time of 14 minutes, 49.12 seconds at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow. McColgan initially expressed concerns about the race's criteria for record-breaking attempts, but British Athletics confirmed Muir's time would be ratified. Muir, a 3.55 minute 1,500m runner, is expected to run faster than her current 5K record and has the potential to reach 14.30 seconds. McColgan, who also broke her record in a similar solo race, praised Muir's achievement and expressed confidence in her ability to win world medals.

Jung won the gold medal in the equestrian event, riding Sam, who replaced Fischertakinou due to an infection. France's Astier Nicolas won silver, and American Phillip Dutton won bronze. British rider William Fox-Pitt finished 12th, despite competing just 10 months after being in an induced coma following a fall. Fox-Pitt, a three-time Olympic medallist, had a faultless performance in the final show-jumping phase but his medal bid was ruined by a disappointing performance in the cross-country phase, where he incurred several time penalties. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished 9th on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

Andy Murray, a 30-year-old British player, won his third-round match at Wimbledon against Fabio Fognini of Italy. The match lasted for two hours and 39 minutes, with Murray winning 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5. Murray had five set points to force a fifth set but won five games in a row to secure his place in the fourth round. He will face Frenchman Benoit Paire on Monday. Johanna Konta, another British player, also advanced to the second week of the tournament. The match between Murray and Fognini was tense and had a dramatic ending as the light faded, with Murray winning despite Fognini's challenge.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 due to a sudden death. Police found alcohol being served until 04:49 BST. The bar was closed for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing consumption of liquor outside licensing hours. O'Neill had an "appalling record" and was fined Â£3,000, while Thomas was fined Â£1,000. The court noted that the licensing laws were not strictly adhered to and the premises were not run properly.

Mike Nesbitt, leader of the Ulster Unionists, launched his party's manifesto, emphasizing the importance of partnership over domination. He criticized the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle and the DUP and Sinn FÃ©in's rule in Stormont. Nesbitt's comments about potentially forming a coalition with the SDLP after the election sparked controversy. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership', focuses on addressing waiting lists, increasing PSNI numbers, prioritizing the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community, and ensuring no group is negatively impacted by Brexit. Nesbitt hopes his message about incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption in Stormont will resonate more than the ongoing controversy over his SDLP comments.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden has announced a motion to be presented to the assembly for approval, which will align Northern Ireland with England and Wales in granting automatic pardons for men convicted of now-abolished sexual offences. This move, dubbed 'Turing's Law', will also allow living men convicted of such offences to apply for a pardon. The motion is expected to contain the same provisions as the English and Welsh proposals, enabling both posthumous and living pardons for gay and bisexual men. The minister has secured executive agreement to ask the assembly to pass a legislative consent motion, aiming to implement these arrangements as soon as possible to ensure equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland.

Laura Muir, a 23-year-old from Kinross, set a new Scottish record in the 1500m race, finishing second with a time of 4:19.12. This time also moved her to second on the British all-time list. Muir, who finished fifth in last year's World Championships, is pleased with her performance and hopes to secure an Olympics place for Great Britain in Rio. She started her season with an 800m victory in France and will next compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm. Muir, who is studying veterinary medicine, fits her training around her studies.
The passage highlights 26 beaches in Scotland that have been recognized for their excellent water quality.

The passage discusses the murder of Alexander Litvinenko, a former Russian spy who was poisoned with polonium-210 in London in 2006. The main suspects are Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, who are believed to have been involved in the plot. The Met Police barrister, Richard Horwell QC, suggests that the Russian state was likely the sponsor of the plot, as they had reasons to wish Litvinenko harm. However, Horwell also notes that this does not necessarily mean that Russian President Vladimir Putin was involved or gave the order. The inquiry into Litvinenko's murder has been adjourned, and attempts to extradite the suspects have failed.

Steve Smith, a 26-year-old batsman, has been appointed as the permanent captain of the Australian cricket team, replacing Michael Clarke who retired after the Ashes defeat. Smith had previously captained the team in three Tests against India. He has played 32 Tests, scoring 2,952 runs at an average of 54.66. David Warner, 28, has been named as Smith's vice-captain despite his history of disciplinary issues. Warner has matured and developed into an important senior figure in the team.

Tim Farron, the new leader of the Liberal Democrats, has expressed his support for LGBT-plus rights and equal marriage, stating that these will be at the top of his agenda. He has also indicated his intention to extend marital rights to transgender people. However, when asked if he believes homosexual sex is a sin, he refused to give a direct answer, instead stating that everyone is a sinner. Farron voted against the Equality Bill in 2007 due to concerns about individual liberties, but he is in favor of equal access under law for all people regardless of their sexuality.

Sanofi's drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, Newcastle, was closed in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. The site is now being used by Accord Healthcare for pharmaceutical production, with the potential to rehire some ex-Sanofi staff. Accord Healthcare is a global player in the pharmaceutical industry, developing, manufacturing, and distributing over 130 products to around 60 countries. The investment is expected to have a positive impact on the local economy.

The passage discusses the departure of three senior staff members from a local authority. Richard Ellis, the former interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, is leaving at the end of his contract. Ciaran Monaghan, head of the chief executive's office, and Ewan Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are leaving under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. The opposition SNP group leader, Stephen Flynn, attributes these departures to the council's inability to retain senior staff and expects more departures in the future. The council chief executive, Angela Scott, expressed gratitude for their dedication and professionalism.

The English rider, who crashed at this year's TT and experienced mechanical issues with his Fireblade bike, has announced his decision to quit road racing on Hondas for the rest of the year. He will not participate in the North West 200 or the Ulster Grand Prix. The rider expressed dissatisfaction with his performance at the TT and stated that the bike would not be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix. He plans to focus on racing classics and oddball events instead.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The APC leader, Muhammadu Buhari, will be inaugurated on 29 May after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP lost in key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as Adamawa, a state affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The APC made historic gains, relegating the PDP to a regional party, with the PDP doing well only in the south-east and the oil-rich Niger Delta. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, which could pose a challenge for President-elect Buhari. The elections were marred by violence in some areas due to stiff rivalry and

The passage discusses the allegations against Olam, a Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader, and its main stakeholder, Temasek, for turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that contribute to the haze caused by agriculture fires in Indonesia. Olam buys 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and has recently released the names of its 14 suppliers. The company claims to have a strict sourcing policy with zero tolerance for burning, deforestation, and peatland use. However, Mighty, a US-based environmental lobby group, accuses Olam of creating a "secretive market for rogue palm oil companies" and unwittingly encouraging unsustainable practices. Temasek, the majority stakeholder in Olam, has been linked to the devastating annual haze affecting Singapore, Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia if the claims of sourcing from rogue palm oil producers are proven. The palm oil industry globally has a troubled track record, with accus
The restaurant started offering puppy platters as a result of a new law permitting dogs to dine at outdoor restaurants.

Fernando Forestieri, a forward, is likely to miss the upcoming game due to a knee injury, having only been able to play as a substitute in the last two matches. Derby County's striker, David Nugent, is expected to return to the team after missing the previous game due to a groin injury. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield is optimistic about getting a starting spot again, having scored a late equalizer in the last game against Huddersfield.

Pakistan has lifted its ban on YouTube, which was imposed in 2012 due to the upload of the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims". The ban was lifted after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of YouTube. However, activists demand greater transparency regarding the terms of the deal between Google and the government. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority has directed internet service providers to open access to YouTube, and Google has agreed to restrict access to offending material upon request. The ban was initially imposed due to the film's mocking portrayal of the Prophet Muhammad, which sparked widespread protests and violence in Pakistan.

Domenico Scala, a member of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is facing pressure to step down from Liberian Football Association (LFA) boss Musa Bility. Bility threatens to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday. Scala's participation in the committee is being questioned due to his Swiss-Italian nationality, which is also shared by one of the presidential candidates, Gianni Infantino. However, Scala's spokesman, Andreas Bantel, argues that there is no conflict of interest as per FIFA's regulations. The election to replace long-standing president Sepp Blatter is scheduled in 18 days, with five candidates including Infantino, Prince Ali, Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale.

Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were tragically killed at Harford Attachments in Spar Road, shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday. They were working in a paint-spraying area when the incident occurred. Their bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. The cause of the incident is believed to be a flashover explosion, which occurred due to a build-up of toxic fumes combined with an ignition source. The Health and Safety Executive is gathering evidence for their investigation.

Tunisia was at risk of being disqualified from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to a controversial letter they sent to CAF (Confederation of African Football) regarding a penalty decision in their quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea. The letter was misconstrued as accusing the referee of corruption, leading to a demand for an apology or disqualification. However, Tunisia maintained they never accused anyone of corruption and only expressed dissatisfaction with the referee's appointment. After a meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou, Tunisia's participation was secured, and they will now face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A. Morocco, who were initially banned from participating in the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw, were reinstated by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) and will compete in Group F against Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome.

The passage describes a football match between Chelsea and Manchester City at Etihad Stadium, which Chelsea won 3-1. The incident occurred in the 95th minute, leading to the dismissal of Manchester City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho. Aguero received a four-match ban for his second dismissal for violent conduct this season, while Fernandinho was given a three-match ban. Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will not face further action. Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for his team's involvement in the incident. Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses a pilot project in Wales and Denmark aimed at improving cancer diagnosis rates. The project involves a clinic in Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd, where doctors are using diagnostic systems from Denmark. The goal is to reduce the time it takes to diagnose cancer, as current methods can take a long time due to the lack of clear symptoms. The project aims to create a more efficient process, with doctors referring patients to a specialized clinic within a few days. The project is expected to make a significant difference in the lives of cancer patients and their families.

England won the cricket match against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, setting up their second-biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his impressive performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also took four catches and a wicket. Pakistan's spirit was broken, and they struggled to score runs, batting for only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second. The third Test is scheduled for Edgbaston on 3 August.

Rob McBryde, the forwards coach, has been appointed as the interim head coach for the British and Irish Lions' tour of New Zealand. This is his third time leading the team, having previously done so in 2009 and 2013. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is in the process of appointing assistant coaches for the tour and aims to confirm the full management team next week. The involvement of Welsh coaches is expected to benefit the national team and provide opportunities for their development.

Hull City secured their first league win in six games, ending a six-game losing streak, with a 2-1 victory over Southampton. The match was marked by a controversial penalty awarded to Southampton in the sixth minute, which Charlie Austin converted. Hull's strikers, Abel Hernandez and Will Keane, were forced to leave the game due to injuries in the first half. However, the introduction of Robert Snodgrass, who replaced Keane, brought new energy to Hull's team, leading to a quick-fire double goal just after the hour mark. Snodgrass scored the first goal and provided the assist for the second, which was scored by Michael Dawson. Southampton's goalkeeper, Fraser Forster, made several saves in the second half, but Hull's defense held strong, with David Marshall making crucial saves. In the final minute of added time, Claude Puel's men had a chance to equalize, but Jay Rodriguez's shot was blocked by Michael Dawson, and Sofiane Bou

A motorcyclist was killed in a collision with a tractor on the B1191 near Woodhall Spa, Lincolnshire, at around 14:15 BST. The motorcyclist was a local resident, but no further details have been released. The tractor driver was unharmed. The road was closed in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction and the A158 Jubilee Way junction. Witnesses are being urged to come forward.

President Ivanov of Macedonia cancelled an investigation into allegations of abuse of power, citing the need to end political turmoil ahead of June elections. This decision was criticized by the opposition and EU officials. The crisis began with covert recordings revealing alleged vote-rigging and cover-ups of a murder. Opposition leader Zoran Zaev has been releasing recordings since 2015, accusing the government of corruption and mismanagement. The government denies these claims.

Swansea City's assistant manager, Alan Curtis, and Paul Williams will manage the team against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's sacking. The club aims to appoint a new manager soon, with Paul Clement being the top choice. Curtis believes the team needs someone who can help them avoid relegation, as the Championship has become stronger and it's not guaranteed they'll return to the Premier League immediately. Swansea, promoted in 2011, have struggled since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, with Curtis noting a loss of the "Swansea Way" and dilution of their playing style. Despite this, Curtis is confident the current squad is capable of staying up and reminds new signings of the club's remarkable rise from near bankruptcy.

The Daggers, a football club that reached League One in 2010, were relegated to the National League after losing to Leyton Orient. The Daggers needed a win to keep their slim survival hopes alive, but they conceded 20 more goals this season than last, contributing to their worst goal difference in League Two. Their struggles in attack were evident, with 40-year-old striker Jamie Cureton scoring only nine goals this season, compared to 20 in the previous campaign. The Daggers' manager, John Still, is committed to helping the club gain promotion from the National League next season. Meanwhile, Leyton Orient secured a victory that keeps their play-off hopes alive, two points adrift of the play-off spots.

Steven Gerrard, a former Liverpool captain and player, will join the club as a youth coach in February. He plans to become a manager in the future and is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching licence. Gerrard made his Liverpool debut in 1998 and won several titles with the club before retiring in November 2015. He had been linked with the manager's job at MK Dons but found the opportunity too soon.

In the match, McManus scored two goals, one in the 15th minute and another in the late stages, while Forbes' deflected strike added to Morton's lead. Alloa's Kyle McAusland scored a goal before half-time, but Morton secured a comfortable victory.

Ofsted has found squalid conditions in three closed unregulated schools in Birmingham, leading to potential jail terms for operators. The investigation, involving 18 unregulated schools, mainly in Muslim communities in the Midlands, has resulted in the closure of three places. Sir Michael Wilshaw, Ofsted's Chief Inspector, expressed concern about children's safety and potential radicalization. The government is planning to fund a team of inspectors to investigate illegal schools and is considering further regulation.

Lilliard Gin, produced at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is set to become the first new distillery in the Scottish Borders in nearly 200 years. The gin is named after Lilliard, a legendary Borders figure who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545. The distillery aims to capture the local flavour palette and terroir of the Teviot valley, using wild food and Borders botanicals. The production team is led by Kate Macinnes, and the distillery is a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery on the site.

Harry Whitlam, a young man, was tragically killed when Gary Green, who was more than twice the legal drink-drive limit, reversed a vehicle into him at a farm in Leeds in August 2013. Green was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in prison for failing to ensure the safety of others. The incident occurred on private land, leading to Green's prosecution under health and safety legislation rather than road traffic law. The victim's mother, Pam Whitlam, expressed her family's grief and called for awareness about the dangers of drunk driving.

Luis Suarez, the Uruguayan striker, has been allowed to train and play in friendly matches by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas), but he must still serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in international competitive games. He will make his competitive Barcelona debut against Real Madrid on 26 October. Suarez's lawyers argued that the initial four-month ban was too harsh, and Cas agreed that preventing him from training was excessive. He can now attend matches, take part in promotional activities, and play in friendlies.

Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won the World Wife Carrying Championships in Lithuania, beating Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene. The couple trained for a week by running around an athletics track and faced challenges such as hurdling over haystacks, climbing a steep slope, and avoiding water pistols. The race allowed all combinations of competitors, including men carrying women, men carrying men, and women carrying women. Richard and Anna will now compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The passage discusses the replacement of the paper car tax disc system with an electronic one in October 2014. This change may lead to a reduction in job roles at the Driving and Vehicle Licensing Agency (DVLA) due to a decrease in refunds and the elimination of the tax disc. However, the government plans to manage any reductions in staff through redeployment to other areas of growth within the business, rather than redundancies. This news has been welcomed by Swansea East AM Mike Hedges, who is pleased that the minister is committed to redeployment and hopes this will give comfort to concerned DVLA employees.

Hungary's right-wing Fidesz government, led by Prime Minister Viktor Orban, is facing pressure from European institutions to withdraw three controversial laws. These laws include tight controls on asylum seekers and non-governmental organizations (NGOs), as well as a higher education law that could lead to the closure of the Central European University, founded by philanthropist George Soros. Thousands of Hungarians have protested against these laws in recent months. The EU objects to these laws, but Hungary's Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Peter Szijjarto, has stated that the EU should not interfere with domestic issues and that Poland would veto any EU sanctions against Hungary. The Higher Education Law, signed in April, could force the closure of the CEU, which ranks among the top 200 universities in the world in eight disciplines. Draft legislation on NGOs is expected to go before parliament soon, which human rights groups say would stigmatize them as "foreign-backed" organizations. The

The live-action adaptation of Disney's Beauty and the Beast will be released in US cinemas on 17 March 2017. Emma Watson will play Belle, while Harry Potter star Dan Stevens will portray the Beast. Luke Evans will play the villainous Gaston, and Josh Gad will co-star as LeFou. Dame Angela Lansbury's character Mrs Potts will be played by Emma Thompson, and Kevin Kline will play Maurice. Bill Condon will direct the film, which will begin filming at Shepperton Studios in May.

Adrian Gill, a renowned columnist for the Sunday Times, passed away suddenly this morning. He was known for his wit, dazzling writing, and compassion. Gill had been diagnosed with a "full English" of cancers and had been undergoing chemotherapy. Despite his illness, he remained stoic and did not feel cheated. He was a giant among journalists and a beloved colleague at the Sunday Times. His writing often caused controversy, but he was also known for his kindness. Gill was born in Edinburgh in 1954 and overcame dyslexia to become a successful writer. He began his career in the 1980s and was married to author Cressida Connolly from 1983 to 1991. He later married Amber Rudd, with whom he had two children, and they divorced. Gill engaged to his partner of 23 years, Nicola Formby, just before his death.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa, was allegedly attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator. He was hit with a bottle and kicked in the face, resulting in a 10-day coma. The attacker, a Russian diplomatic officer, has not been identified or arrested. The rapper often wears a swastika symbol on stage, which is a traditional Mongolian symbol of eternity, not associated with Nazism. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident, denying distorted reports about the attack.

Plane Stupid activists staged a protest on the northern runway of the airport at 03:30 BST on Monday, opposing the airport's expansion plans. They have been charged with aggravated trespass and entering a security restricted area of an aerodrome. The protesters will appear in court on 19 August, and the Metropolitan Police will review the airport's security.

Glamorgan's total was primarily driven by Nick Selman's century, his second in first-class cricket, after a series of low scores. However, regular wickets fell due to seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles. Gloucestershire struggled in their innings, with the day ending evenly balanced. Glamorgan is led by Michael Hogan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph.

Craig Hughes, a 33-year-old man from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after he threatened to shoot police officers on the Dee Estuary. He made these threats twice while drunk late at night, after chatting online with the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee. Hughes admitted to two charges at Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. He had a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009 and was on bail for firearms offences at the time of the threats, which he was later cleared of.

Surrey won the match by 19 runs after Yorkshire's run-chase was disrupted by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst. Surrey's total of 255-7 was built on a 130-run partnership between Davies and Ben Foakes. Yorkshire, aiming to reach Lord's for the first time since 2002, started well but lost momentum after dropping catches and conceding too many runs in the end overs.

The 56-foot converted trawler was experiencing water ingress due to a malfunctioning pump, approximately 6 miles west of South Stack. The crew contacted Holyhead coastguards at 07:00 BST. The RNLI lifeboat crew intervened by placing a pump and towing the vessel to Holyhead for safety.

Hellen Obiri won the 5,000m gold at the World Athletics Championships, with Jessie Muir finishing fourth. Muir set a new outdoor personal best of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds. Muir, a veterinary medicine student, will not be able to participate in the Commonwealth Games due to her exams and will focus on the World Indoor Championships in March.

Liverpool's title challenge is over, according to Robbie Savage, who believes they are miles away from the level required for a title challenge. Savage points out that Liverpool overachieved last season, raising expectations unrealistically, and that their transfer market decisions have not paid off. The loss of Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge's injury has left Liverpool without a lot of goals from their line-up. Savage criticizes Rodgers' transfer decisions, stating that the available front men (Balotelli, Lambert, and Borini) are not good enough and do not have the same work-rate as Suarez and Sturridge. Liverpool's defense is also a concern, with Rodgers still trying to find an answer to their weakness. Savage predicts that Liverpool will struggle to win against Chelsea on Saturday, as they lack a leader in defense and their goalkeeper does not give them much help.

The passage describes a Â£45 million educational facility being built in Kilmarnock, the birthplace of renowned writer William McIlvanney. The facility will house primary, secondary schools, a Gaelic school, and a childcare centre. The council plans to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name the campus after the writer, who was passionate about education. McIlvanney was an English teacher turned full-time writer, known for his "Tartan Noir" works and contributions to political and sporting life in Scotland. He passed away in Glasgow on 5 December.

An area near the swimming pool in Gourock was evacuated due to a sea mine discovered on Monday, believed to be a British mine from the 1940s or 1950s. The mine was moved to a safer location after it was deemed too risky to handle due to its deterioration. The evacuation affected three streets, and residents within 500m were advised to stay indoors and avoid going outside. An exclusion zone was also established at sea, causing disruption to ferry services. The operation was carried out as a precautionary measure, with no immediate danger to the community.

The passage discusses the funding decisions for Olympic and Paralympic sports leading up to the Tokyo 2020 Games. UK Sport has allocated Â£345m, Â£2m less than the previous cycle, with a focus on prioritizing sports with high medal potential. Archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby have missed out, while cycling's funding has been cut by Â£4m. Badminton's funding has been removed despite meeting its Rio target, causing outrage. Judo's funding has been slightly increased, and basketball, handball, and volleyball have had their funding withdrawn in previous years. UK Sport aims to have Team GB win 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals. The government has confirmed its commitment to the funding.

Three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff conservation area will be demolished to make way for a six-storey, four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks. The development, which includes 90 hotel rooms and 122 assisted-living apartments, was approved by councillors despite objections from English Heritage and residents. The buildings to be demolished are Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View hotels.

Pte Matthew Boyd, a 20-year-old soldier from Carrickfergus, County Antrim, was killed in Brecon during a night out. He was punched and beaten by Jake Vallely outside a bar called The Cellar. Vallely, 24, has been found guilty and will be sentenced on 8 December. Aaeron Evans, Vallely's friend, was cleared of any involvement as he was not present during the attack. The attack was described as a "despicable act" by the senior investigating officer.

Andrew Travers, the chief executive of Barnet Council, left his position by mutual agreement following an error in the electoral registration process. On election day, voters were initially turned away from all polling stations in the borough because their names were missing from the poll list. Travers blamed the electoral registration lists for the problems. The council has launched an independent investigation, and Deputy chief executive John Hooton will take over temporarily. The review will conclude by the end of May, and the findings will be presented publicly.

Gateshead won the match against Wrexham with a score of 2-1. Josh Gillies scored the first goal for Gateshead with a free-kick, while Sean Newton equalized for Wrexham. Ryan Bowman scored the winning goal for Gateshead with a header. The match was disappointing for Gateshead in the first half, but they improved in the second half, leading to their victory.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 ranks 96 countries based on the welfare of people aged 60 and above, with Norway topping the list and Afghanistan and Mozambique at the bottom.

The passage describes a project called OneWeb, which aims to provide global broadband internet access by launching a constellation of at least 600 satellites, potentially up to 2,000. The project is a collaboration between OneWeb and Airbus, with the first 10 satellites set to launch in April 2019. The manufacturing process involves a significant shift towards high-volume, low-cost production, with new assembly lines and automated methods similar to those used in car and plane factories. The satellites will be launched in clusters of 32-36 by Soyuz rockets, with the first satellites expected to be in orbit by November 2019. The project requires substantial financing, with $1.7 billion already raised and discussions ongoing for additional loans. The UK Space Agency is the licensing authority for OneWeb, which is registered in the UK's Channel Islands and expects to generate significant revenue for the UK. The project also aims to set new standards in debris mitigation, committing to de-orbit old satellites within two years and developing a system to capture and remove defunct

The Scottish government, led by Mr. Swinney, is facing significant budget cuts due to the UK government's spending review. These cuts will result in a 12.5% reduction in the Scottish government's discretionary budget by 2019-20, compared to 2010-11 levels. Mr. Swinney has criticized the UK government's austerity measures, stating that the cuts are not necessary and that the Scottish government will prioritize key services such as schools, hospitals, and the police. The UK government, however, argues that the Scottish government will have more spending available next year and that the block grant will be almost Â£30bn. The Scottish government is expected to present its 2016-17 spending plans on Wednesday.

The passage discusses the need for more accessible toilets, specifically Changing Places toilets, for people with severe disabilities and their families. These toilets have extra features and more space to meet the needs of those who use them. Currently, there are 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but campaigners are calling for them to be made compulsory in larger buildings. The lack of suitable toilet facilities can cause stress and isolation for families, and the psychological impact on the whole family can be significant. The passage also mentions the challenges in installing these toilets due to logistical and financial barriers, and the positive reaction from businesses and the public when they are installed.

The passage discusses a formal complaint made to the European Commission by Italian consumers' organizations against McDonald's. The complaint alleges that McDonald's forces franchisees to pay excessive rents and fees, which is disputed by McDonald's. The company claims to share risks and rewards with its licensees. The Service Employees International Union and European unions support the complaint, accusing McDonald's of abusing its dominant market position. The European Commission will now study the submission and may launch an investigation if the allegations are found to be valid. The complaint also suggests that franchisees are prevented from switching to competitors due to long contracts and leasing premises at above-market rates, leading to poorer consumer choice and higher prices in franchise stores.

The passage describes a social media campaign supporting 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve. The campaign, initiated by Bangor Elim Church, began as a hashtag on Facebook and Instagram and has since gone viral. A mystery donor paid for a billboard in Holywood, displaying the hashtag #prayforjosh, to show support for Joshua. The campaign has received global attention, with people from all over the world praying for Joshua's recovery.

The passage discusses the closure of Brecon Barracks in Wales, a historic military site that has served since the early 19th century. The decision has been criticized by local MP Chris Davies, who plans to launch a petition against it. The closure is part of a larger reorganization of UK military buildings, which also includes the closure of Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire in 2024 and a storage depot at Sennybridge in 2025. The reorganization aims to create a specialist light infantry centre at St Athan, Vale of Glamorgan. The closure is expected to impact the local economy, particularly in Brecon, which has high unemployment levels and a thriving military tourism industry.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights the industry's low priority for the government but emphasizes that it "must not be marginalized in the wider Brexit negotiations." The report warns that Britain may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of an overall deal. The Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) has been criticized for its quotas and equal access principle, but it also provides market access for UK fish exports. The report suggests that many elements of the CFP should be retained post-Brexit and that the UK should ensure total allowable catches and quotas are based on scientific advice. The report also raises concerns about potential different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland post-Brexit. Despite these challenges, many in the fishing industry believe Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats, citing recent increases in allowable catches for certain species as evidence.

The passage discusses the revelation by Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, that the US National Security Agency (NSA) has access to a massive scale of individual chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. This access is reportedly obtained through a program called Prism, which also enables "backdoor" access to the servers of nine major technology companies. The NSA has confirmed requesting millions of phone records from US company Verizon. The extent of US surveillance, as revealed by Snowden, was described as "horrifying" by him, while US Director of National Intelligence James Clapper described the leaks as "extremely damaging" to national security. The passage also touches on data-protection laws, the involvement of other governments, and the implications for internet use.

OpenAI, a new artificial intelligence (AI) research company, has received funding from notable investors such as Elon Musk, Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services. The company aims to focus its research on creating AI that benefits humanity, addressing concerns about potential existential threats posed by AI. Despite warnings from scientists and experts like Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking, the risk of AI harming humans remains a topic of debate. OpenAI plans to distribute AI widely and safely, with only a small portion of its $1 billion budget being spent in the near future.

L/Bdr Parkinson, a soldier from Doncaster, was severely injured in a bomb attack in Afghanistan in 2006. Despite losing his speech, he has regained it and is now a public figure due to his nomination to carry the Olympic torch. He has received thousands of friend requests on Facebook, but the site limits associations to 5,000 per personal page. He walks with crutches and spends 12 hours a day in the gym and rehab. He is a patron of the Pilgrim Bandits and raises money for military charities. His mother, Diane, has expressed her amazement at the overwhelming support and friendship he has received.

In 2011, the poverty rate remained at 15%, with 46.2 million Americans living in poverty. This was a stagnation after three consecutive years of increase. Real median income for households decreased by 1.5%. The average poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality, as measured by the Gini index, rose by 1.6%, marking the first annual increase since 1993. However, the percentage of uninsured Americans decreased slightly to 15.7% from 16.3%. Despite this, poverty in the US reached a record high in 2010, at 15.1%.

Jos Buttler, a 25-year-old cricketer, has signed a new deal with Lancashire until 2019. He joined the club in 2013 and is known for his short-format skills, having scored England's three fastest ODI centuries. Buttler's presence in the T20 Blast final last year contributed to Lancashire's victory. He is also praised for his positive influence in the dressing room and his international experience. Buttler is currently playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians and will return to Lancashire for their next T20 Blast home game against Durham.

The passage discusses the decommissioned Type 22 frigates HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham, and HMS Cornwall, which are currently moored in Portsmouth Harbour. The government's Disposal Services Authority is handling their sale, with bidders having until 23 January to register an interest. No proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. The government aims to award at least one of the frigates to a UK ship recycler to assess the UK's industry capacity in recycling. The frigates, originally designed as anti-submarine ships, evolved into powerful surface combatants with various weapons systems and excellent command and control facilities. The sale is expected to generate income for the country through tourism, with a preference for converting one of the frigates into a reef and diving attraction. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options to ensure the best financial return for the taxpayer.

The passage describes Fiji's political instability since 1987, marked by coups and racial tensions between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians. These events have led to international isolation, economic harm, particularly to the tourism industry, and a decline in the Indo-Fijian population due to emigration. The country's economy, while diverse, is heavily reliant on sugar and tourism, and it faces persistent trade and budget deficits, making it a significant aid recipient.

Syria's Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, has stated that Syria is doing its best to comply with the chemical weapons destruction timeline, despite missing the recent deadline. He claimed that two shipments of weapons were attacked, one of which was intercepted by terrorist groups. Al-Mekdad also criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of Syria's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, asserting that Syria is defending its people against terrorist attacks. The Syrian government denies reports of rebels seizing most of Aleppo's central prison, claiming that soldiers and security forces thwarted the attack. The UN-backed plan to destroy Syria's chemical weapons is falling behind schedule, with only 4% of the stockpile (30 tonnes) having left the country so far. The deadline for all weapons to be destroyed was set for the end of June, but has been extended to 1 March by Russia.

The passage discusses the shortlist for the 2014 Booker Prize, which is open to all authors writing in English regardless of nationality. The favorites are Joshua Ferris's "To Rise Again at a Decent Hour" and Australian author Richard Flanagan's "The Narrow Road to the Deep North". The winner will be announced at London's Guildhall on Tuesday night. The prize, now in its 46th year, is chaired by AC Grayling and consists of a panel of judges. Last year's winner was New Zealand's Eleanor Catton for "The Luminaries".

The passage discusses a celebrity, referred to as PJS, who is appealing against a Court of Appeal ruling that lifted a ban on his identification in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will now hear arguments about whether to grant an appeal and decide if it should be allowed or dismissed. The interim injunction preventing his identification will remain in place until the end of the hearing. The celebrity is accused of having extra-marital activities with another person, AB, starting in 2009, and they had a three-way sexual encounter in January 2012. The Sun on Sunday wants to publish an account of these alleged activities, but PJS argues he has a right to privacy and has taken legal action. The Court of Appeal judges ruled in his favor initially, but News Group Newspapers, publishers of the Sun on Sunday, argued that the story had already been published in the US, Scotland, and elsewhere, and on the internet and Twitter. The judges ruled that PJS was unlikely to get a permanent injunction

Fosse Park, located near junction 21 of the M1 and opened in 1989, was recently purchased for Â£345.5m. The new owners aim to enhance the park's appearance, parking, and traffic congestion. They plan to address the current issue of overcrowded parking and congestion, as well as improve the quality of common areas and facilities. The new owners have met with the Blaby District Council to discuss potential planning questions and their vision for the park as a gateway into the city.

The film "Beauty and the Beast" sparked controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" involving a character named LeFou. The Malaysian Censorship Board approved the film with a minor edit, but it has not been released yet. The film was initially scheduled for release on Thursday, but Disney held it for review. The film's director, Bill Condon, described the scene as LeFou trying to come to terms with his feelings for Gaston. The decision to review the film was criticized by netizens, who found it "stupid and laughable".

Landlords in Southampton who rent properties to more than three unrelated people must obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which costs Â£1,000. However, many landlords avoid this due to the risk of fines up to Â£20,000. The city council estimates around 1,500 unlicensed HMOs exist. Tenants in these properties often worry about eviction and poor maintenance. Mandatory licensing for HMOs nationally applies to three-story buildings or more, housing five or more unrelated individuals. In Southampton, the licensing affects properties in specific areas, with the council reporting cooperation from most landlords but prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny of Fine Gael and MicheÃ¡l Martin of Fianna FÃ¡il aim to prevent a second election. Fianna FÃ¡il has agreed to facilitate a minority government but will not support a programme for government. Water charges are a major obstacle in reaching an agreement. A commission to consider the future of Irish Water is being proposed. Fianna FÃ¡il wants immediate removal of water charges, while Fine Gael sees a role for them. After the election, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna FÃ¡il 44, Sinn FÃ©in 23, and the Labour Party got seven. No party could form a majority government, and TDs have not yet elected a taoiseach.

The Sorrento, an Italian ferry owned by Atlantica di Navigazione, was traveling to Valencia when a fire broke out on one of its car decks, approximately 27km from Mallorca. The fire caused the ship to sink, and passengers were evacuated to lifeboats. They were then rescued by another ship, the Puglia, and are expected to arrive at Palma de Mallorca port in a few hours. At least three people were injured, with one reported to be seriously hurt. The cause of the fire is unknown.

The passage discusses the 2017 UK general election, highlighting key statistics such as the record number of registered voters (46.8 million) and the high turnout (68.7%). It also mentions concerns about duplicate registrations, with an estimated 30-70% of online applications being duplicates. The Electoral Commission suggests improving the link between electoral registers and the online registration service to reduce this issue. The passage also notes that voting twice in a general election is an offence, but some people may lawfully register in multiple constituencies for local elections.

Lawrence Phillips, a former star NFL player in the 1990s, was found dead in his prison cell on Wednesday, believed to be a suicide. He played for the St. Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins, and San Francisco 49ers but had a troubled career due to legal issues both on and off the field. After his NFL career, he was convicted of assault for driving into a group of teenagers and assaulting a former girlfriend. He was serving a term of over 30 years and was placed in solitary confinement after being accused of killing his cellmate. A judge recently found enough evidence to try him in the death of Damion Soward. Despite his positive qualities, Phillips struggled with anger issues and personal demons.

Lance Corporal Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram mascot, was promoted to his rank at an event in Chester. He received his honor from Brigadier Andrew Williams, the colonel of the Mercian Regiment. Derby XXX, the 30th in a line of mascot rams, was promoted for "good behavior" and joined the regiment in 2014. He has his own army number, receives pay for rations, and takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate. He has also participated in events like switching on Christmas lights and meeting Prince William.

Liverpool, managed by Jurgen Klopp, defeated Borussia Dortmund 4-3 in a thrilling Champions League match, with Dejan Lovren scoring the winning goal in injury time. The game was filled with emotion, excitement, and brilliant football, with Liverpool overcoming a 2-0 deficit to secure a place in the last four. Klopp's approach of turning doubters into believers was evident as Liverpool completed a remarkable turnaround. The match was marked by a special atmosphere, with Anfield filled with color and emotion. Liverpool's performance showcased their growing stature, with Divock Origi and Philippe Coutinho standing out. However, the team still has a vulnerability at the back, with Alberto Moreno and Mamadou Sakho being weak links. Despite this, Klopp has successfully imprinted his identity on the team and fans, with Liverpool now in a strong position to reach the Champions League via the Europa League.

The UK government, led by David Davis, held a meeting with the devolved administrations of Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland to discuss Brexit negotiations. Davis proposed monthly meetings to share information and allow the devolved administrations to express their views. However, Scottish First Minister Nicola Russell criticized the lack of clarity from the UK government regarding their strategic intentions, particularly on single market access. The UK government plans to appeal the High Court judgment on triggering Article 50, while the Scottish government intends to oppose this in the Supreme Court.

The passage discusses a study on cloned sheep, specifically five identical twin sisters of Dolly the sheep, the first cloned mammal. The study aims to understand if these cloned animals age normally and how healthy they are, as there are concerns about the cloning process potentially transferring "age-memory" and causing premature aging. The sheep undergo various tests, including joint X-rays and full-body fMRI scans, to assess their health and compare it to the wider sheep population. The results of the study, which could impact the future of cloning, will be published next week.

The unbeaten favorite, Shutter Speed, won the Musidora Stakes by a length and three quarters, beating runner-up Vintage Folly. She will next race in the French Oaks at Chantilly instead of the Epsom Oaks. Tasleet won the Duke of York Stakes, while Shutter Speed's last run at Newbury saw her beat Enable into third. Trainer John Gosden is concerned about the ground for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes and may not run him in the race.

The passage discusses the recent fluctuations in the value of the British pound against various currencies, including the US dollar, euro, and Japanese yen. The pound has been volatile, with initial drops followed by partial recoveries, and overall losses. This volatility is attributed to investor uncertainty, as indicated by the high "volatility index" levels, and concerns about the potential economic impact of the UK leaving the EU, as reflected in the polls showing a tight race between the Leave and Remain campaigns. The passage also mentions that hedge funds have been betting on a further decline in the pound's value. The UK's trade deficit narrowed in April due to increased exports, but the overall impact of Brexit on the UK's economy remains uncertain.

The Iron, currently in sixth place in the National League, lost to Barrow, extending their losing streak to three games. Barrow, with an unbeaten league run of nine games, won the match. Despite the loss, the Iron's manager, Cowley, remained positive, acknowledging their remarkable journey and embracing their toughest challenge yet as a part-time team.

The passage discusses a significant change in Northern Ireland's planning system, where local councils will take over the responsibility of making planning decisions, previously handled by the Planning Service under Stormont's environment department. This shift is seen as an opportunity for democratization and community development by some, like Michael Corr, but others, such as Friends of the Earth, express concerns about potential discrimination, lack of transparency, and the influence of developers on political parties. The move also raises questions about the relevance of the Â£7,500 limit for declaring political donations and the potential impact on donors' personal security.

The passage describes an incident where a one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot multiple times with an air weapon, resulting in the amputation of her left back leg. The cat's owner, Sarah Nisbett, is understandably upset and urges anyone with information to contact the Scottish SPCA. The incident has raised concerns about the potential danger of air weapons, particularly in residential areas with children. The Scottish government had previously held a consultation on licensing air weapons, but a majority of respondents opposed the plan.

Benteke, a Belgian international striker, has joined Liverpool from Aston Villa for a reported Â£27m, triggering a release clause in his contract. This makes him the Reds' second most expensive signing and their seventh summer signing. Benteke, who scored 49 goals in 101 games for Villa, is expected to revive Liverpool's attack, which struggled last season following the sale of Luis Suarez and injuries to Daniel Sturridge. He missed the 2014 World Cup due to an Achilles tendon injury but returned to action last October and scored 15 times to help Villa stay in the Premier League and reach the FA Cup final. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert and former Liverpool striker John Aldridge are optimistic about Benteke's potential at Liverpool.

The study found that tablet computers are increasingly used in schools, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools using them. However, there is no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using tablet devices. The highest use of tablet computers is in academy schools. The number of tablet computers in schools is expected to rise from about 430,000 to almost 900,000 between 2014 and 2016. While head teachers reported a positive impact, it is not possible to make a definitive connection between tablet computers and improved results. The study also found that many pupils take internet-connected devices to bed for social media conversations.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs that depict the lives of children in Liverpool over more than 100 years. The images, spanning from the 1880s to the 1990s, showcase the evolution of childhood and how special occasions were celebrated on the city's streets. The oldest photograph dates back to 1887, featuring the Rollo family, who lived in a large home with servants. The exhibition, curated by Kay Jones, aims to showcase both the positive and negative aspects of childhood, including the children who had to work during their childhood.

Centre-back Anderson, aged 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent and joined their National League rivals. He has previously played for Aldershot and Exeter, and also in Italy. Anderson could potentially play against his former club, Barrow, on 18 February. Striker Keating, aged 21, has been recommended to the Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson by Micky Adams. Keating has had spells with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. His move is subject to international clearance. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

The passage discusses a new law in Bolivia that allows 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, aiming to help eradicate extreme poverty. The law also sets harsher penalties for violence against children and is a balance between the country's reality and international treaties. The International Labour Organisation's minimum working age for developing countries is 14, but Bolivia's law allows children as young as 12 to work. The law was signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in the absence of President Evo Morales, who was traveling to Brazil.

The 50-year-old actress, Rosie O'Donnell, experienced a heart attack, specifically a "widow maker" type, after helping a woman in her Nyack village home. She initially dismissed her symptoms of chest pain, nausea, and fever, but later sought medical attention. She wrote about her experience on her blog, warning women to be aware of heart attack symptoms and not ignore them. Despite not calling emergency services, she advised others to do so.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed at a party in Belvedere Way, Kenton, Kent, on Saturday evening. He was stabbed in a later altercation in an alleyway at around 00:30 GMT and pronounced dead about an hour later. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in a stable condition. A 21-year-old man and two boys aged 15 and 16 have been arrested on suspicion of murder, while a 14-year-old is being held on suspicion of possession of an offensive weapon. The party was reportedly well-run with appropriate adults present, and Che was not involved in an early altercation.

The passage discusses a reorganization of cancer diagnosis in Denmark, which was initially struggling with poor cancer survival rates compared to other European countries. The new approach focuses on three routes:

1. Fast-track diagnosis and treatment for patients with "alarm" symptoms of specific cancers.
2. Investigation of patients with unexplained symptoms within 30 days of a GP referral.
3. Simple tests or scans for patients with minor symptoms, which are unlikely to be cancer but could be in rare cases.

This new system has led to better organization of diagnosis within existing resources and improved survival rates, with Denmark catching up to the elite in Europe.

The passage discusses the establishment of a new regulatory body, Powys, to oversee estate agents in the UK. This body will have the power to issue warning and banning orders against agents who act dishonestly or violate estate agent laws. The decision to disband the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) led to this change, and Powys won the competitive bidding process to take over the OFT's responsibilities. Powys will receive Â£170,000 annually for this service. Complaints about estate agents will still be handled by local trading standards departments, but cases involving potential breaches of the Estate Agents Act will be referred to Powys. The new role is expected to demonstrate Powys' capability to take on more contracts and external work in the future.

The NHS Employers have approved a plan to reshape the workforce, with the Nuffield Trust suggesting that nurses and other health staff could take on more responsibilities with additional training. This is due to gaps in junior doctor rotas and increasing patient load for GPs. The plan aims to improve patient care and provide more rewarding roles for staff, but it has been met with caution from unions who warn against using it as a quick fix and emphasize the need for adequate funding for training.

The passage describes a road closure on the A36 (Lower Bristol Road) in Bath, UK, following a crash at 03:00 GMT. The closure caused disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. The road was reopened at 14:00 GMT. Investigations are ongoing to determine the cause of the collision. First, a bus company, resumed partial services and aimed to have a full service running for the evening commute. The company thanked the public and staff for their support and understanding during the situation and recovery.

The passage discusses a controversy surrounding the Swansea tidal lagoon project in Wales. The Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimated that the lagoon would cause 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout to die each year due to migration to and from local rivers. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP), the project's developer, disputes these figures, claiming they lack a clear scientific basis and are based on "what if" scenarios. TLP's own computer modeling estimates a worst-case scenario of 2% of all fish species dying. The project is seen as a test bed for larger, more cost-effective versions around the coast. The UK government is reviewing the scheme's viability, and Wales' Environment Secretary Lesley Griffiths expressed the need for clarity on the UK government's position. NRW strongly disagrees with TLP's criticism and asserts that their methodology has been shared with TLP and independent experts.

The passage announces the establishment of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland, similar to Scotland Food and Drink. This body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) and will provide strategic leadership and direction for the marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. The agri-food industry in Northern Ireland is significant, employing nearly 100,000 people in farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. The announcement was made by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister Arlene Foster and was welcomed by Stormont's Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill. However, Ms. O'Neill noted that the plans could have implications for other organizations, including her own department.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a tree planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon, inviting the public to participate. This is part of a four-year project to plant millions of native UK trees across the UK, commemorating the millions who died in WW1. In Brackfield Wood, 40,000 trees will be planted to honor the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The event aims to create a living tribute to the Irish people who played a part in the war.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her debut novel, "Someone Else's Skin," a thriller that explores domestic violence and honor crime. The novel features Detective Inspector Marnie Rome. The book was praised for its finely written and tightly plotted narrative, as well as its ability to create atmosphere in few lines. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago. Paretsky's work was noted for its impact on the genre and its influence on female crime writers.

Mitchell Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner, suffered a broken finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, which was a significant blow to their qualification hopes. He made his Test debut in 2015 and will rejoin the Rapids following the ICC Trophy in England in June 2017. Santner expressed his enjoyment of his time at Worcester and his intention to make up for lost time with both bat and ball. In August 2016, Worcestershire signed Australia pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed by a speeding car on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev in 2008 while trying to hail a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, had returned to a restaurant for a missing glove. The coroner, Dr Elizabeth Earland, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating that the case demonstrated the difficulty in investigating a death abroad.
