The passage discusses a reorganization of cancer diagnosis in Denmark, which was initially struggling with poor cancer survival rates compared to other European countries. The new approach focuses on three routes:

1. Fast-track diagnosis and treatment for patients with "alarm" symptoms of specific cancers.
2. Investigation of patients with unexplained symptoms within 30 days of a GP referral.
3. Simple tests or scans for patients with minor symptoms, which are unlikely to be cancer but could be in rare cases.

This new system has led to better organization of diagnosis within existing resources and improved survival rates, with Denmark catching up to the elite in Europe.

The passage discusses the establishment of a new regulatory body, Powys, to oversee estate agents in the UK. This body will have the power to issue warning and banning orders against agents who act dishonestly or violate estate agent laws. The decision to disband the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) led to this change, and Powys won the competitive bidding process to take over the OFT's responsibilities. Powys will receive Â£170,000 annually for this service. Complaints about estate agents will still be handled by local trading standards departments, but cases involving potential breaches of the Estate Agents Act will be referred to Powys. The new role is expected to demonstrate Powys' capability to take on more contracts and external work in the future.

The NHS Employers have approved a plan to reshape the workforce, with the Nuffield Trust suggesting that nurses and other health staff could take on more responsibilities with additional training. This is due to gaps in junior doctor rotas and increasing patient load for GPs. The plan aims to improve patient care and provide more rewarding roles for staff, but it has been met with caution from unions who warn against using it as a quick fix and emphasize the need for adequate funding for training.

The passage describes a road closure on the A36 (Lower Bristol Road) in Bath, UK, following a crash at 03:00 GMT. The closure caused disruption and delays to commuters and bus services during rush hour. The road was reopened at 14:00 GMT. Investigations are ongoing to determine the cause of the collision. First, a bus company, resumed partial services and aimed to have a full service running for the evening commute. The company thanked the public and staff for their support and understanding during the situation and recovery.

The passage discusses a controversy surrounding the Swansea tidal lagoon project in Wales. The Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimated that the lagoon would cause 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout to die each year due to migration to and from local rivers. Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP), the project's developer, disputes these figures, claiming they lack a clear scientific basis and are based on "what if" scenarios. TLP's own computer modeling estimates a worst-case scenario of 2% of all fish species dying. The project is seen as a test bed for larger, more cost-effective versions around the coast. The UK government is reviewing the scheme's viability, and Wales' Environment Secretary Lesley Griffiths expressed the need for clarity on the UK government's position. NRW strongly disagrees with TLP's criticism and asserts that their methodology has been shared with TLP and independent experts.

The passage announces the establishment of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body in Northern Ireland, similar to Scotland Food and Drink. This body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB) and will provide strategic leadership and direction for the marketing activities of both government and private sector organizations. The agri-food industry in Northern Ireland is significant, employing nearly 100,000 people in farming, fishing, retail, and distribution. The announcement was made by Stormont's Enterprise, Trade and Investment (DETI) Minister Arlene Foster and was welcomed by Stormont's Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill. However, Ms. O'Neill noted that the plans could have implications for other organizations, including her own department.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a tree planting event at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley on Saturday afternoon, inviting the public to participate. This is part of a four-year project to plant millions of native UK trees across the UK, commemorating the millions who died in WW1. In Brackfield Wood, 40,000 trees will be planted to honor the estimated 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The event aims to create a living tribute to the Irish people who played a part in the war.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her debut novel, "Someone Else's Skin," a thriller that explores domestic violence and honor crime. The novel features Detective Inspector Marnie Rome. The book was praised for its finely written and tightly plotted narrative, as well as its ability to create atmosphere in few lines. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career writing about VI Warshawski, a female private investigator from Chicago. Paretsky's work was noted for its impact on the genre and its influence on female crime writers.

Mitchell Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner, suffered a broken finger in his second game for Worcestershire in 2016, which was a significant blow to their qualification hopes. He made his Test debut in 2015 and will rejoin the Rapids following the ICC Trophy in England in June 2017. Santner expressed his enjoyment of his time at Worcester and his intention to make up for lost time with both bat and ball. In August 2016, Worcestershire signed Australia pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed by a speeding car on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev in 2008 while trying to hail a taxi. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, had returned to a restaurant for a missing glove. The coroner, Dr Elizabeth Earland, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating that the case demonstrated the difficulty in investigating a death abroad. Pring's family believes he was killed in a staged hit and run accident, and Ziuzina, who was 19 years younger than her husband, was suspected of involvement due to her actions after his death, such as selling his Range Rover, moving funds from his bank account, and having an affair with a Ukrainian man. Ziuzina claimed to be a teacher when they first met, but she was actually a lap dancer and stripper. The Ukrainian police closed an inquiry into his death but relaunched it in 2011 as

Charlie Fearns, a boy from Merseyside, needs to travel to Seattle, USA for experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital. His last transplant failed, and he has been ill since the age of three. After a third relapse in April, there was no further treatment option available in the UK. The family was overwhelmed when an anonymous donor paid for Charlie's treatment, and they are expecting the treatment to start as soon as possible.

The passage discusses a security vulnerability in Apple's iCloud service, where third-party software was used to steal intimate photos of celebrities. Apple has now implemented a two-step verification process to prevent unauthorized access. This process requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to their trusted mobile phone or Apple's Find My iPhone app, in addition to their username and password. If users do not enter the code, they are blocked from making purchases or accessing their account. Apple previously offered two-step verification, but it was not activated for iCloud backups. This allowed hackers to use Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker to download complete backups of users' data. Elcomsoft's owner confirmed that his software was used in the recent hacks, but Apple's new changes prevent this technique. However, there are still concerns about the security of the recovery key, which is required to regain access to an account. Some experts suggest that Apple should make two-factor authentication the default option, rather than an opt-in choice.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of a potential deal for Wright to buy 20% of Billericay Town FC are still under wraps. The Sun reported that Wright, a 30-year-old former I'm A Celebrity contestant, would become a club director if the deal goes through. Billericay Town FC is currently in eighth place in the Isthmian League Premier Division, just three points away from a play-off spot. Wright has played non-league football for several teams, including Lewes, Crawley Town, and Rushden & Diamonds. The club has recently been taken over by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has expressed comfort in investing Â£10,000 a week. Billericay Town FC also signed former England international Paul Konchesky, 35, in early March.

Mr. Ashley, the owner of Sports Direct, has been asked to provide evidence about the treatment of his workers following a BBC investigation into the company's warehouse working practices. He has until 21 March to respond to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee. The committee has offered alternative dates for a meeting at Sports Direct's base in Shirebrook, but Mr. Ashley has not accepted any of them. The committee has warned that it may take further action, including seeking support from the House of Commons, if Mr. Ashley fails to attend. Sports Direct has not responded to the BBC's request for a comment. The company has previously pledged to review worker rights, with oversight by Mr. Ashley.

The report, initially intended to be written by the murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, was completed by his colleagues led by Ilya Yashin. The report, titled "Putin. War," accuses President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own ends, causing significant human and economic costs. The report presents evidence of Russian soldiers and equipment being used in eastern Ukraine, contradicting Russia's claims of only volunteers. The report also details Russian spending on the conflict, estimated at 53 billion roubles. The opposition plans to publish and distribute the report, but faces challenges due to fear among publishers and potential lack of interest from the public.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, was discovered deceased at the Woodhead Tunnels in Derbyshire on Monday at 11:00 BST. The cause of death was determined to be head injuries following a post-mortem examination. Two individuals, a 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman, were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody in connection with the incident.

The passage discusses the reaction of Welsh First Minister Carwyn Jones to the UK government's Article 50 letter, which triggers the process of leaving the European Union. Jones criticizes the lack of consultation with the devolved administrations, including Wales, in drafting the letter. He also expresses concern about the potential loss of EU funding for Wales after 2020. The UK government, however, has stated its intention to consult fully on which powers should be devolved to Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, with the expectation of increasing decision-making power for each devolved administration. The identity of the specific powers and whether funding will accompany them remains unclear.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in Newry on Friday night, during which PSNI officers were attacked while carrying out their duties. The incident occurred in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his disapproval of the mindless attacks on police officers and the Newry community. The police also appealed to parents to be aware of their children's activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of American Apparel, was removed from his position due to employee complaints and allegations of misuse of company funds. The company's board stated that they do not anticipate his return. Mr. Charney's lawyer denied the accusations and claimed the company was attempting to extort him. Court filings reveal evidence of inappropriate emails and racial slurs sent by Mr. Charney to female employees. He is suing the company and its chair for defamation. The company's papers state that Mr. Charney violated their sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy. A restraining order was issued earlier this month, preventing Mr. Charney from making negative statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The British men's basketball team will play against Greece at the Copper Box in London, which will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website. This game is a chance for revenge as three members of the Greek team that previously won against GB will be missing. The game will take place on the same day as the BBC Sport website's live coverage from 5:30 PM to 7:30 PM BST. This is GB's only home game before they compete in FIBA EuroBasket 2017, which starts in September. After the game against Greece, the team will travel to Poland for their last warm-up games before EuroBasket.

The passage describes the introduction of the iPhone in 2007, which revolutionized the way people use their phones. The author, a journalist, was given the opportunity to handle the iPhone before its official release and used it in a news piece. The iPhone's impact on photography and other mobile activities is highlighted, as it made these tasks more accessible and convenient. The author initially had reservations about the iPhone's significance but now recognizes its historical importance in the mobile connected era.

The passage describes a series of cat deaths in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, due to ingestion of a toxic substance, likely antifreeze. The most recent case involved a seven-month-old cat named Meereen, who died on Monday after showing symptoms of poisoning. Three other cats in the area have also died in the last seven days, and another cat died two weeks ago. The cause of the poisonings is unclear, with the RSPCA spokesman suggesting they could be accidental or deliberate. The RSPCA is appealing for everyone in the area to ensure pesticides and chemicals are stored safely, particularly as it is the time of year when people use antifreeze in their cars.

The passage discusses the current situation in Greece, where the Syriza government is expected to agree to more austerity measures despite previously criticizing them. Despite this, Greece's tourism industry is thriving, with increased airport arrivals. The Greeks are not protesting as they await the announcement of the third bailout deal, which is expected to provide â¬86 billion in new credit. The deal is likely to include VAT increases, pension cuts, and controversial privatizations. The passage also mentions that Greece is experiencing monetary austerity due to the partial closure of banks, which is affecting the economy and potentially leading to a cancellation of Christmas sales. The passage suggests that for the new bailout to be successful, creditors must ease the burden of Greece's debts and avoid triumphalism.

Ross Kemp, who previously played Grant Mitchell in EastEnders from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, is returning to the soap for a brief appearance. He will reunite with his on-screen brother Steve McFadden (Phil Mitchell) to say goodbye to their mother, Peggy, played by Barbara Windsor, who is set to die from cancer in upcoming emotional scenes. This return will mark a classic moment in EastEnders' 30-year history.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon was convicted of murdering Alice Ruggles, who was 24 years old. Dhillon had been stalking Ruggles before the fatal attack. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, received the news of her death from two Northumbria Police officers. They immediately suspected Dhillon as the perpetrator. The trial revealed that Dhillon had become obsessed with Ruggles and had been stalking her. Ruggles' mother, Sue Hills, expressed guilt for reassuring her daughter over the phone two days before the attack, as she now believes her daughter might still be alive if she had taken the situation more seriously. The parents have established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking and to remember their daughter for her vibrant personality and smile. Dhillon was sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

The French firm EDF has approved funding for the Â£18bn Hinkley Point project in Somerset, with contracts set to be signed on Friday. However, the UK government has stated it will "consider carefully" before backing the project. The project has faced criticism for potential environmental damage, escalating costs, and foreign involvement, with one third of the cost provided by Chinese investors. The government has launched a further review of the project, causing uncertainty and halting a recent wave of major investment. The project is expected to provide 7% of the UK's total electricity requirement and has been described as a unique asset for French and British industries. However, concerns about EDF's financial capacity and the project's financial risks have led to resignations from the EDF board and shareholders approving plans to issue new shares to raise funds. Environmentalists and campaign groups have also expressed concerns about the project and the need for more investment in renewable energy.

The passage discusses the new divorce application form in England and Wales, which includes a field for the name of the person with whom the spouse committed adultery. Family lawyers express concern that this addition may increase conflict and complexity, as it could involve a third party in the divorce proceedings. The form does not require the third party's name, but lawyers fear that people may feel compelled to provide it due to the presence of the field. If the third party is named, they become part of the court case, potentially causing delays and additional costs. Adultery was the reason for 12,148 divorces in 2015, while "unreasonable behavior" accounted for 46,815.

The passage discusses the conflict between environmental policy and commercial forestry in Wales. Ministers are emphasizing environmental aspects, such as native broadleaf species and access for walkers, while commercial forestry organizations want to invest in woodland creation. Confor, a forestry industry group, warns that at least 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need to be re-planted. The Welsh government aims for a balance between environmental, economic, and social aspects in forestry development. However, the current system is seen as too bureaucratic and the emphasis on environmental aspects is considered "sexier" than commercial forestry. The industry is worth more than Â£450m a year to the Welsh economy, but only 90 hectares were planted last year, far short of the 20,000 hectares needed to meet long-term targets.

A boy was severely injured in an incident in Coatbridge, Scotland, near Langloan Primary School. The incident occurred around 16:40, and the boy was transported to the Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is reported to be serious.

The passage describes the presentation of Ushakov medals to veterans of the Arctic Convoys, who played a crucial role in resupplying the Soviet Union during World War II. These convoys, which traveled from Britain to northern Russia, faced constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, as well as severe cold, storms, and ice floes. The Arctic route claimed 104 merchant and 16 military vessels, with thousands of Allied seamen losing their lives. The Russian Embassy intended to award the medals as a symbol of gratitude, but the Foreign Office initially blocked the move due to rules against receiving foreign medals. However, an exception was made, and President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals during his visit to London in 2013.

The passage discusses an HM Inspectorate of Probation report that found issues with the implementation of unpaid work sentences, or "community payback," for offenders. The report highlighted delays in starting work, offenders not attending, and a lack of enforcement. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the issues and plans to improve the system by ensuring offenders attend on time and face consequences for not doing so. The report also mentioned the use of orange bibs for offenders, a scheme initiated by the previous government to make community sentences appear tougher.

The comedian, known for his economic and political activism, has been accused of hypocrisy due to his luxurious lifestyle. He resides in a spacious London home, which has been featured in his vlogs. Despite this, he continues to advocate for the poor and campaign against gentrification. He has been confronted about his living situation, but has not provided a clear explanation. He has previously addressed the hypocrisy accusations, stating that he is aware of the charge and that he believes in personal change and systemic change. He acknowledges his past mistakes but maintains that the issue of economic disparity and ecological disaster is a real problem that needs to be addressed.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, is known for his work in mapping the human genome and creating a synthetic life form. He started as a surfer and was drafted into the Vietnam War, where he became determined to become a doctor and work efficiently. He excelled in research during his medical training and realized the importance of decoding genes. He developed an automated decoding machine and switched his focus to messenger molecules (RNA) to speed up gene sequencing. His work was criticized by some, leading him to leave the NIH and set up a private research institute. He announced the formation of Celera Genomics to crack the human genetic code in three years, which was met with both praise and criticism. He later formed the J Craig Venter Institute to create the first synthetic life form. He has also conducted a genetic treasure hunt in the oceans to understand the evolution and function of genes and proteins.

The survey of about 1,000 parents in England found that four out of five children who ate school lunches tried new foods they hadn't at home. Half of the parents said their children asked for school lunch foods to be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were least popular. The survey was conducted by England's School Food Trust and Mumsnet, with 628 parents having children who ate school lunches. The findings suggest that school meals can help parents encourage children to try new foods and increase dietary variety.

Morata, a 23-year-old striker, joined Juventus in 2014 from Real Madrid, where he had spent four seasons. The transfer included an option for Real to re-sign him for up to 30 million euros. Morata has scored three goals for Spain in Euro 2016 and previously scored 27 goals for Juventus in two years, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He has also played in two consecutive Champions League finals, scoring in one. Morata started his career at Real Madrid, making his first team debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the club.

Wilson, a 30-year-old footballer, joined Championship side Forest from Celtic for Â£2.5m in 2013. He had previously played for Forest for four seasons and also had stints at Preston North End and Notts County. After being released by Forest in May, he has been without a team.

Tesco, the British supermarket giant, is selling its loss-making US food chain, Fresh & Easy, to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company. Around 4,000 employees will transfer to the new business, while the remaining 50 stores will be closed. Tesco will loan the new business around Â£80m and the deal will cost Tesco Â£150m, part of which may be repaid if Yucaipa succeeds in making the business profitable. Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits for 20 years in April of this year.

The passage discusses an individual who faced racial abuse but overcame it. Initially considering representing France, they are now focused on achieving a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. For those interested in learning about martial arts, a special guide is provided.

The passage discusses the decline of glaciers in the French Alps over the past four decades. In the late 1960s/early 1970s, the ice fields covered around 375 sq km, but by the late 2000s, this area had decreased to about 275 sq km, representing a 26% loss. The retreat is not uniform, with the southern sectors experiencing greater losses. The Belledonne Massif has seen almost complete disappearance of glaciers, while the Ecrins Massif has experienced more than three times the retreat of the Mont Blanc Massif. The northern Alps, which include the largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, have seen less retreat due to higher elevation and different climatic conditions. Efforts to monitor glacier health are ongoing across the Alpine region.

The Scottish women's national football team has won all five qualifiers and is close to securing a place in the major competition. The team's star player, Kim Little, is eager to avoid another play-off loss after previous heartbreaks. The team will host Iceland, ranked one place above them, and a win would likely secure their place. The team has players from various leagues, including the Bundesliga, Sweden, and the US, which benefits their performance.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger, was arrested in the west of England following a complaint from a woman in south London about harassment over a two-year period. The harassment allegedly involved tweets from his Twitter account, which he insists were not threatening. He accused the media of spreading innuendo to encourage speculation. Campbell has been bailed pending further inquiries and has stated that the tweets in question are still publicly visible and not threatening.

Peta, an animal rights group, has proposed replacing Skegness's iconic Jolly Fisherman mascot with a fish symbol, aiming to promote animal-friendly branding. The original Jolly Fisherman poster, created in 1908, is a symbol of the Lincolnshire resort. However, Peta argues that the mascot evokes images of animal cruelty, while the mayor of Skegness supports the current mascot, stating it is loved by locals and tourists alike.

Scotland dominated the match against Georgia, scoring six tries and winning 45-11. The Scots led early with a try from Vasil Lobzhanidze, but quickly responded with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime. Hamish Watson and Hogg added more tries in the second half. Georgia scored two tries, both from scrums, but Scotland's possession and territory dominance resulted in a comfortable victory.

Widnes secured a victory over Castleford with a score of 42-32. The match was marked by several tries, including those from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, Chris Bridge, Paddy Flynn, Lloyd White (twice), Joe Mellor, Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's hat-trick score. Despite Castleford's late surge with three tries in four minutes, Widnes held on to their lead and moved above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford remained in sixth place.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti man, was released from the US facility in Cuba after a review panel determined he was not a "continuing significant threat". He had been detained since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies. His release comes after the Periodic Review Board's decision in July and is the first since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl. Al-Odah had argued he traveled to Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid. He will now face at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait.

Anzac Day, commemorating the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One, was celebrated in London with a service at Hyde Park Corner and a parade to the Cenotaph. Thousands attended, including expatriates and visitors from New Zealand and Australia. The service included the national anthems of the three countries and a wreath-laying ceremony. The event has been held annually since 1916, following King George V's attendance at a Westminster Abbey service. The Gallipoli campaign, a bloody eight-month operation during World War One, was remembered as part of the commemoration.

Clarkson, a 30-year-old Scottish international with over 390 senior club appearances, has joined St Mirren for a second spell. He scored nine goals for Dundee last season and has been training hard to maintain his match fitness. Clarkson, who has been playing for the U20s and training as a substitute, is ready to make his debut against Alloa on Saturday. He aims to help St Mirren, currently eighth in the Championship, win games and push up the table.

The turkey firm, Bernard Matthews, was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. There were concerns about the new owners not honoring the existing workers' pension scheme. However, after productive talks, Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed that all current agreements, including the pension scheme, will be honored. The Boparan Private Office also confirmed this. The new owner aims to restore Bernard Matthews to its former profitability by investing more in the business, making cost savings, and utilizing the current spare capacity to process chicken, not just turkeys.

The council leader announced that the Cowes ferry crossing would be free until 2 July due to issues with the new vessel. The ferry has faced problems since its launch, including breakdowns, groundings, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues. Cars have also been damaged during boarding and disembarking. The council has ordered a review of the project and is considering compensation for local businesses affected by the disruptions. The transport councillor described the issues as teething problems and noted that ramp extensions have been authorized to address vehicle scraping issues.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights the industry's dislike for the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) and the opportunity for the UK to regain control over its waters. However, the report also warns that Britain may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of an overall deal. The report emphasizes that the fishing industry, which contributes only a small percentage to the UK's GDP and employs a limited number of people, should not be marginalized in the Brexit negotiations. The report also suggests that many elements of the CFP should be retained post-Brexit and that the UK will continue to be under international obligations to cooperate with neighboring states. The report also raises concerns about the potential for four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland if Britain leaves the EU. Despite these concerns, many in the fishing industry argue that Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats.

Timothy Geaney, a teacher, admitted to downloading and possessing indecent images of young boys between 2004 and 2014. He was sentenced to a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and ordered to participate in a sex offenders program. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, he was removed from the teaching profession's register due to his conduct being incompatible with the profession and his failure to uphold expected standards. The panel found him unfit to teach and prohibited him from re-registering for two years.

Firefighters worked at a site in Duncan Street following a fire on 2 March, which disrupted train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The firm was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, according to the fire service. The EA revoked the company's environmental permit, effective from 7 August, due to concerns about the impact of a fire on nearby residents, transport, and the environment. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The passage discusses the situation in Syria regarding the destruction of its chemical weapons stockpile. Syria has missed the deadline to hand over its entire stockpile, with only 4% (30 tonnes) of the 1,300 tonnes declared chemical weapons having left the country. The Syrian Deputy Foreign Minister, Faisal al-Mekdad, stated that Syria is committed to its agreements with the OPCW and the UN Security Council and will implement its obligations on time. However, the process has been slowed down by security concerns. The passage also mentions the ongoing conflict in Aleppo, with reports of barrel bomb attacks by the Syrian government and the seizure of a central prison by rebel groups. The Syrian government denies these reports.

England won the cricket match against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, setting up their second-biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his impressive performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also took four catches and a wicket. Pakistan's spirit was broken, and they struggled to score runs, batting for only 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second. The third Test is scheduled for Edgbaston on 3 August.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales. She is gathering experiences from older people, their families, and care providers to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will focus on factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. However, the chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, has expressed disappointment that no care home expert is included in the main advisory panel.

Former Aberdeen midfielder Sheerin, aged 39, has been appointed as the new player-manager at Aberdeen, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin previously managed Arbroath since 2010 and led them to their first national trophy, the Scottish Third Division title, in 2011. He has also played for several Scottish clubs and Ãstersunds in Sweden, earning a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s. Arbroath, who were relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing bottom of League One in the 2013-14 season, agreed to let Sheerin go after a "comprehensive process" led by Aberdeen manager Derek McInnes.

Swansea's assistant manager, Curtis, and Paul Williams will manage the team against Bournemouth following Bob Bradley's sacking. Swansea aims to appoint a new manager soon, with Paul Clement being the top choice. Curtis believes the new manager should be capable of getting them out of trouble, as staying in the Premier League is crucial due to the Championship's strengthening and the difficulty of returning to the top flight. Swansea, once a well-run club known for its exciting football, has struggled since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, with Curtis attributing this to frequent managerial changes and loss of key players. Despite these challenges, Curtis is confident that the current squad is good enough to avoid relegation.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, played a significant role in mapping the human genome and later created a synthetic life form called Synthia. He started his career as a surfer and was drafted into the Vietnam conflict, which inspired him to become a doctor and work efficiently. He excelled in research during his medical training and realized the importance of decoding genes. He developed an automated decoding machine and switched his focus to messenger molecules (RNA) to speed up gene sequencing. His work was initially criticized, leading him to establish a private research institute and later a commercial company, Celera Genomics, to map the human genome. He also formed the J Craig Venter Institute to create synthetic life forms. In addition to his scientific pursuits, he has explored the oceans in his yacht, Sorcerer II, to collect life forms and study their genomes.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are low quality and too short, with fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 starting each year rated at level three, equivalent to A-level. Only 61,000 new apprenticeship starts were for young people, compared to over 570,000 in Germany. The report suggests that England's vocational system has 18,000 different qualifications, while Germany has 330. Since 2010, more than half of apprenticeships have been below level three and three-quarters have been aimed at those over the age of 25. The report calls for apprenticeships to be radically expanded, with up to 300,000 new starts each year, the majority of which should be at level three at least for three years.

Sarah Storey, a British Paralympian, won the women's C4-5 road race in Nottwil, Switzerland, ahead of Anna Harkowska of Poland. She is aiming for her 17th title in the upcoming road race on Saturday. Storey, 37, is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals, including 11 gold, 8 silver, and 3 bronze in both cycling and swimming across six Paralympics. She won four golds at the 2012 London Games and has 21 world titles in total. Storey started her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics before transitioning to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Football Conference due to their failure to pay football creditors, including former manager Martin Foyle and players, amounting to Â£148,000. The club's financial struggles have been ongoing since their relegation from the Football League in 2012, exacerbated by falling attendance and unpaid wages. Despite efforts to raise funds from fans and other clubs, the club still owes over Â£70,000 to HM Revenue and Customs. The Hereford United Supporters' Trust offered to buy the club for Â£1 but was not chosen as the preferred option. Tommy Agombar, a London businessman, took over as the new owner but was unable to meet the payment deadline. Chester FC has taken Hereford's place in the Conference Premier.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has represented England in 61 senior matches since his debut in 2009. He was part of the squad for two World Cups and two European Championships, but only played for three minutes in Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 appearances since 2004. He scored his only international goal in a 5-0 victory over Moldova during the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), passed away at his home in Cambridge after a long illness. He was known for his significant contributions to the early-music movement and his influential work with leading orchestras worldwide. Hogwood studied keyboard at Cambridge University and later held positions with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields and the Early Music Consort of London. He served as the artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and was a professor at Harvard University and the University of Cambridge. His most famous recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah with Emma Kirkby and Carolyn Watkinson. He was praised for his generosity, intellect, and dedication to historically informed music.

The boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is protected, was removed from mainstream schooling due to his inability to cope. His parents have been waiting for a place at a special school since June, but all special schools in their area are full. The boy's mother expressed her concern about the system isolating him further and worried that other families may face the same issue due to over-subscription. The Education Authority is currently reviewing special school provision to ensure places are available close to children's residences.

The Newport Gwent Dragons rugby team is undergoing a takeover bid by the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU), who plan to use Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. The Newport County Football Club has a lease to use the ground until 2023, with primacy of fixtures if they remain in the Football League. The WRU's takeover will be voted on by the shareholders on May 9. The WRU intends to install an artificial surface, which is against Football League rules. Newport County is currently two points clear of the League Two relegation zone with two games remaining and can secure survival this weekend. Relegation to the National League would be a significant blow for the team and the city of Newport.

The passage describes the experiences of a former child soldier in Sierra Leone's civil war and his subsequent involvement in combating the Ebola virus. He was kidnapped by rebels at age 15, trained in combat, and subjected to brutal conditions. After escaping, he lived in the capital and was involved in petty crime before meeting a preacher named Richard Cole. Cole encouraged him to continue his education and become a leader in rebuilding the nation. When the Ebola crisis hit in 2014, the former child soldier and his team started an Ebola treatment clinic, educating communities, providing food and supplies, and setting up an Ebola treatment unit. They saved many lives and helped combat the virus. The former child soldier now sees his life as changed and is investing in young people to build a better future.

The Wedgwood Museum's collection of 80,000 artworks, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs was at risk of being auctioned to pay off the firm's pension debt. However, a successful public fundraising campaign led by The Art Fund raised enough money to prevent the sale. The collection will remain at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, and will be loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The Art Fund will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of a potential deal for Wright to buy 20% of Billericay Town FC are still under wraps. Wright, a former I'm A Celebrity contestant and non-league footballer, could become a club director. Billericay Town FC, currently in 8th place in the Isthmian League Premier Division, is owned by multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who has expressed comfort in investing Â£10,000 a week. The club recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

The match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute through a goal by Jamille Matt, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester United equalized in the 17th minute via Kurtis Guthrie. Blackpool's goalkeeper, Sam Slocombe, made a crucial save to prevent Colchester from retaking the lead before half-time. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time. Blackpool had a chance to win the game in the 75th minute but missed the target.

The Fawley Power Station, located on the western side of Southampton Water, was commissioned in 1971 and had a capacity to power one million homes. It was an oil-fired power station fueled by the nearby Esso refinery and featured a 198-meter high chimney. The station was sold to developers in 2016 and is set to become the centerpiece of a Â£1bn development, including a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The chimney, the tallest of its kind south of London's Shard, will remain as it is planned to be a signature piece of infrastructure for the development.

23-year-old British cyclist, Latham, won a bronze medal in the men's scratch event at the Hong Kong championships. He chased down Adrian Teklinski of Poland, who won gold, and Lucass Liss of Germany, who got silver. In the men's team pursuit, Britain was beaten to the bronze medal by Italy. British rider Joe Truman was outclassed in his semi-final in the men's keirin event. The women's team pursuit team, consisting of Emily Nelson, Manon Lloyd, and Ellie Dickinson, finished fifth in the heats and failed to make the bronze-medal ride. Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated from the women's sprint in the first round.

Ross Kemp, who previously played Grant Mitchell in EastEnders from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, will return to the show for a brief appearance. He will reunite with his on-screen brother Steve McFadden (Phil Mitchell) to say goodbye to their mother, Peggy Mitchell, played by Barbara Windsor, who is set to die from cancer in upcoming episodes. Grant Mitchell is considered an EastEnders legend, known for his involvement in family dramas such as having an affair with his brother's wife and his brother marrying his ex-wife.

Sadio Mane scored twice in quick succession as Liverpool defeated Tottenham 2-1 at Anfield, with Tottenham manager Pochettino expressing concern about his team's lack of desire and inability to cope with pressure, particularly in away games against top-six rivals. Tottenham has won only twice on the road since September and has the joint best defensive record this season, but they struggled against Liverpool with a back four instead of their usual back three. Former Tottenham and Liverpool midfielder Danny Murphy criticized their performance, suggesting they should stick to their usual defensive setup against big sides.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The APC leader, Muhammadu Buhari, will be inaugurated on 29 May after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP lost control of key northern states like Katsina and Kaduna, as well as Adamawa, a state affected by Boko Haram's insurgency. However, the PDP managed to hold on to Rivers State, Nigeria's oil hub. The PDP won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The election in Imo state was declared inconclusive due to a high number of spoilt ballot papers. Elections were not held in seven states. The APC made historic gains, relegating the PDP to a regional party, while the PDP governors in the five oil-producing states are unlikely to help President-elect Buhari rein

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, taking place in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis from 19-22 July, will offer an augmented reality experience through an app. This feature will allow visitors to access online information from signs and posters, watch videos, and interviews with bands like The Waterboys, Imelda May, and Dougie MacLean. The app will also enable people worldwide to interact with the festival and experience its atmosphere remotely. The app's content will be updated during the event and will provide information on buying tickets and getting a taste of the festival.

The passage discusses the termination of funding agreements for four schools in Birmingham due to concerns about their management and adherence to regulations. Park View Educational Trust may be removed from running Park View and Nansen Primary schools, while Oldknow Academy Trust is warned about losing funding unless certain issues are addressed. The schools were rated inadequate by Ofsted, and concerns include segregation of boys and girls, less favorable treatment of non-Muslims, and a narrow, faith-based ideology. The schools have been accused of not promoting spiritual, moral, social, and cultural development of pupils and allowing external speakers with extremist views to address students. Parents have criticized Ofsted's reports and accused inspectors of bias.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, died in July 2012 due to a build-up of fluid in his brain, which increased pressure in his skull and led to his death. This was allegedly preventable as Vinnie had a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich five months prior, where optometrist Honey Rose failed to detect swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation. The prosecution claims Rose's conduct was so far below the expected standard that it was "criminal," and she is currently on trial for gross negligence manslaughter.

Clive Weatherhogg, a 42-year-old man, was found guilty of coercing a woman to engage in sexual activity and intercourse with another man between September 2013 and September 2014. He also sent a sexually explicit clip to the victim's sister on Christmas Day 2014. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register and his case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater sentencing powers. He was assessed as posing a moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

Ireland scored 165-5 in their first T20 match against Afghanistan, with Stuart Thompson (56) and Gary Wilson (41 no) contributing significantly. Afghanistan won the match by 6 wickets, reaching their target of 171-4 with two overs to spare. The teams will meet again in the second T20 on Friday. Ireland's captain, William Porterfield, expressed disappointment in not adding more runs and executing bowling well. The loss of paceman Boyd Rankin due to a back problem is another setback for Ireland.

Barcelona, the Spanish football club, has made a complementary tax payment of 13.55 million euros to the Spanish tax office regarding the transfer of Neymar from Santos. The club denies any wrongdoing and maintains that the original tax payment was in line with their fiscal obligations. Neymar, a 22-year-old striker, was signed for 48.6 million euros in the summer, with his parents receiving 34 million euros of the fee. The total cost of the player, including wages, agents' fees, and other contracts, is estimated to be around 106.8 million euros. The club's former president, Sandro Rosell, resigned amid accusations of misappropriation of funds, but he also denies any wrongdoing. The case is still under investigation.

The bodies of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were discovered on a beach in Koh Tao on September 15. Two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, have been held by Thai police and allegedly confessed to the murders. However, they have since denied their confessions. The UK police have completed their investigation and will return to the UK to compile a report and update the families of the victims. The suspects are charged with conspiracy to murder, conspiracy to rape, and robbery, and could face the death penalty if found guilty. The UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns about the police investigation, including the verification of DNA samples and allegations of mistreatment of the suspects.

The Scottish women's national football team has won all five qualifiers for the upcoming major competition and is on the verge of securing their place. They host Iceland, ranked one place above them, in a crucial match. The team, with 12 players playing abroad, is aiming for their first major finals. The benefits of having players in top leagues like Germany and the US are highlighted as they strive for success.

The passage discusses a security vulnerability in Apple's iCloud service, where third-party software was used to steal intimate photos of celebrities. Apple has now implemented a two-step verification process to prevent unauthorized access. This process requires users to enter a four-digit code sent to their trusted mobile phone or Apple's Find My iPhone app, in addition to their username and password. If users do not enter the code, they are blocked from making purchases or accessing their account. Apple previously offered two-step verification, but it was not activated for iCloud backups. This allowed hackers to use Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker to download complete backups of users' data. Elcomsoft's owner confirmed that his software was used in the recent hacks, but Apple's new changes prevent this technique. However, there are still concerns about the security of the recovery key, which is required to regain access to an account if the trusted device is lost or stolen. Some experts suggest that two-factor authentication should be the default option, rather than an opt-in choice.

UKIP, the party that won the May election, spent the most on campaigning at Â£2,956,737, followed by the Conservatives with Â£2,980,815. The Lib Dems spent Â£1,580,575 and lost most of their MEPs. Labour, which came second, spent Â£1,027,339. The Green Party spent Â£534,249 and came fourth. The total spending by the six highest-spending parties was Â£9,347,087, with all parties except Labour spending more than they did in the 2009 election.

Anderson, a 27-year-old center-back with experience in Italy and previous stints at Aldershot and Exeter, has left Barrow by mutual consent and will join their National League rivals. He may play against his former club on 18 February. Keating, a 21-year-old striker, has been recommended to the Gulls boss by Micky Adams and has had spells with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. His move is subject to international clearance. The Gulls, currently four points above the relegation zone, are looking for a leader-type player in Anderson and a hungry young player in Keating.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day. He suffered from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare condition that can occur in horses with no underlying health issues. Despite previous episodes of post-race ataxia, Many Clouds had shown no symptoms on the day of his death. He was known for his past victories, including the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014.

The passage describes the farewell speeches of several MSPs (Members of the Scottish Parliament) ahead of the election on 5 May. Former SNP leader Alex Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, expressed his belief that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse" and emphasized the importance of the parliament assuming greater responsibility for the governance of Scotland. He also welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill but criticized it for not fulfilling the pledges made during the referendum campaign. Salmond's speech was marked by humor, including jokes about the UK budget and the Cheltenham racecourse. He concluded by expressing his gratitude for the opportunity to serve the parliament and the people of Scotland.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was visibly emotional during Salmond's speech and also during the farewell speech of Scottish Labour backbencher Duncan McNeil, who served in the parliament since its

The live-action adaptation of the Disney film "Beauty and the Beast" will be released in US cinemas on March 17, 2017. Emma Watson will play Belle, while Harry Potter star Dan Stevens will portray the Beast. Luke Evans will play the villainous Gaston, and Josh Gad will co-star as LeFou. The film will begin shooting at Shepperton Studios in May, with Bill Condon directing.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to announce its decision on whether to charge individuals related to the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, which resulted in the deaths of 96 football fans. The decision will be communicated to victims' relatives at a meeting in Warrington. The disaster occurred during an FA Cup semi-final between Liverpool and Nottingham Forest. The CPS has been reviewing evidence related to 23 suspects, with 15 cases linked to the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes and 8 cases related to the IPCC probe into police conduct during the aftermath. The families have been awaiting the decisions, which are expected to evoke mixed emotions.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, with residents reporting sightings. The prison is known for its issues with contraband, particularly mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the problem and is exploring ways to improve prison tools to tackle this issue. Despite claims of drones being used to smuggle goods, the Ministry of Justice denies evidence of such occurrences at the Chelmsford site. Laws have been introduced to penalize those who smuggle packages into prisons, with potential jail time of up to two years.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, was struck by Brian Wright's VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red traffic light. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care. Wright denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving.

Hellen Obiri won the 5,000m gold at the World Athletics Championships, with Laura Muir finishing fourth. Muir, a Scottish athlete, will not be able to participate in the Commonwealth Games due to her veterinary medicine studies. She is aiming for the World Indoor Championships in March and has set a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old man from County Kildare, Republic of Ireland, was last seen walking home from a Christmas party in December 2000. A search has begun in a three-acre woodland area in Chapelizod, Dublin, near the R112 and River Liffey, which is expected to take several weeks and involve excavations. The search was initiated following a review of Deely's disappearance by a team of six detectives, who enhanced CCTV footage from the night he went missing. The footage shows Deely talking to a man dressed in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where he worked, and later being followed by the same man on Haddington Road. The man in the CCTV footage has not been identified, and gardaÃ­ have renewed their appeal for him to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th, defeated Stan Wawrinka in a thrilling match at Wimbledon. Del Potro, who had three wrist operations and missed over two years due to injuries, is in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray. He will next play either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Nick Kyrgios also advanced to the third round, defeating Dustin Brown in a rain-affected match. He will face Feliciano Lopez next. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also won their matches.

Tunisia was at risk of being disqualified from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to a dispute with CAF over a controversial penalty in their quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea. However, after a meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou, they were able to resolve their differences and will now participate in the tournament. Morocco, who were initially banned from participating in the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw, had their ban overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport and will also compete in the tournament. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will be in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome.

McLaren, a team with a rich history of success in Formula 1, has been experiencing a decline in recent years. They have won 182 grands prix and 12 drivers' world championships, but their current results are not as impressive. Despite having two world champions in their team, Fernando Alonso and Lewis Hamilton, they are struggling with their car's performance, particularly with the Honda power-unit. This is a stark contrast to their past successes, such as winning 15 out of 16 races in 1988 with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, and their partnership with Honda that led to multiple constructors' titles. However, their last constructors' title was in 2007, and they have since faced scandals and a decline in performance. The team's current predicament is not surprising, as their history has been marked by cycles of triumph and decline. Despite this, team principal Ron Dennis remains optimistic and believes that success is around the

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 due to a sudden death. Police found alcohol being served until 04:49 BST. The bar was closed for three months. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, was charged with two counts of allowing consumption of liquor outside licensing hours and fined Â£3,000. James Thomas, also present, was charged with one count and fined Â£1,000. The court noted that the licensing laws were not strictly followed and the premises were running into the morning.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. He hit eight three-pointers, surpassing his previous record of 272 made in a single season. Lamarcus Aldridge had 27 points and six rebounds for the Blazers, while Damian Lillard added 20 points and eight assists. In other news, the Chicago Bulls defeated the Miami Heat, with Pau Gasol and Derrick Rose contributing 16 and 12 points respectively. The Heat were outscored 57-27 after halftime.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised when YouTube star Bas van Velzen, known for his free-kick skills, arrived at Melwood. They believed he was a competition winner for a dead-ball masterclass, but van Velzen showcased his abilities, impressing the players with his shots. He even wore Balotelli's famous t-shirt, which he wore during Manchester City's 6-1 win over United in 2011.

The passage discusses a study that found women with the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, can reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by more than 60% if they have their ovaries removed after a breast cancer diagnosis. The study analyzed 676 breast cancer patients with the BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation and found that oophorectomy was associated with a significant drop in breast cancer death for BRCA1 carriers but not for BRCA2 carriers. The protective effect of oophorectomy against breast cancer was apparent immediately after diagnosis and lasted for 15 years. The study also found a 65% reduction in death from all causes associated with oophorectomy. The authors called for follow-up studies on women who undergo oophorectomy as part of their initial treatment, especially those who had the surgery within a year of finding out they have breast cancer. The journal editor suggested that the results provide a validation of oophorectomy in conveying both a disease-free and overall survival

A married couple, Derek and Tina Lowe, were killed by an Amtrak train in Durham, North Carolina, on Easter Sunday. The incident occurred around 10 am when they were on the tracks. The train, Amtrak No. 80 (The Carolinian), was traveling from Charlotte to New York City. None of the 166 passengers were injured, but a man who fell ill during the delay received treatment. The train was delayed for about three hours before continuing its journey. The couple may have been living in a homeless camp, as reported by a man who knew them.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years after fleeing Colombia due to a confrontation with his boss. He provided information about his former bosses and associates, aiding in the prosecution of cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Despite his valuable contributions, Toro was not paid for his work and was promised US citizenship, which has not been granted. He is now facing deportation due to declining health and the DEA's refusal to help with his citizenship. Toro fears for his life if he is sent back to Colombia and is currently in limbo while trying to secure a green card or passport.

The US body that regulates internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for potentially illegal actions involving the new '.sucks' domain name. The company has been selling domain names with celebrities' and brands' names, such as 'youtube.sucks', 'bing.sucks', and 'visa.sucks', for around $2,499 a year. Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift have reportedly paid to have their names removed from these domains. ICANN sent a letter to the US Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs to determine if Vox Populi's actions were illegal. The company's CEO, John Berard, claims the domain name is meant to create destinations for companies to interact with their critics, but the Intellectual Property Constituency has called it a'shakedown scheme' and 'predatory'. ICANN has threatened to declare Vox Populi in breach of its contract and seek to change the registry's behavior if regulators find its actions illegal.

The passage describes a case from 1988 where a baby boy's body was found in a Sainsbury's bag in a village pond in Norfolk. The mother was arrested 27 years later after DNA samples led police to her. The baby was stillborn, and the mother had concealed the pregnancy and birth from her family and friends. The baby was reburied in the local churchyard after being exhumed for a case review. The mother remains on bail while the Crown Prosecution Service decides whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, was ordered to pay compensation to a passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of the moving car. Hicks was on his way home from a night out in Bath, Somerset, with his girlfriend in a taxi driven by Young. Young mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to "do a runner" and decided to drive him back to the rank to teach him a lesson. When Hicks objected, Young continued on for almost a mile, leading Hicks to jump from the vehicle while it was traveling at more than 20mph. Hicks suffered devastating brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and now requires round-the-clock care from his mother. The family took Young to the High Court, where a judge ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages. The exact amount of compensation is yet to be decided but is set to be around 50% of what the family had requested and thought to be "hundreds

Tornado sirens blared in Kansas on Wednesday night as multiple storms reported twisters. A tornado was spotted about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, missing Wichita but posing risks to other communities. Other tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas, including near Aetna. Kansas was not the only state affected; a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage, flooding, and roof damage. More storms are expected in the midwest, mississippi river valley, tennessee river valley, and near the southern great lakes on Thursday.

Luke Rockhold is preparing to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight clash in New Jersey. Rockhold aims to secure his fourth consecutive victory and secure a title shot. He plans to dominate Machida by coming forward and dominating him, cutting him off, and slowly progressing to put him in a bad spot. Rockhold believes he has a significant advantage over Machida, both on the ground and on the feet. He has been training rigorously, including running marathons daily. Machida, on the other hand, is confident in his ability to upset Rockhold and earn a title shot. He believes he can win the fight by applying his style and technique. Both fighters are coming off victories and are well-prepared for the clash.

A light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar, approached the Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, without deploying its landing gear. The video maker noticed this and the plane touched down on the runway, causing its propellers to ricochet off the ground and its wings to bounce up and down. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, realized his mistake and re-engaged the engines, taking off back into the air. The plane flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The most common causes of a gear-up landing are human error and mechanical fault. The FAA is investigating the incident.

Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment in Yaya Toure's performance this season but has vowed to support him until the end of the campaign. Toure, who has two years left on his Â£220,000-a-week deal, has been criticized for his performances amid Manchester City's struggling Premier League defense. Pellegrini, who is facing questions over his own future, has stated that Toure will have his support until the end of the season. City will also face West Ham without captain Vincent Kompany, who could miss the rest of the campaign with a muscle injury. Joe Hart, the City goalkeeper, has insisted that the players should take responsibility for their performances, which have let down the manager and themselves. Allardyce has warned West Ham left-back Aaron Cresswell not to make the same mistake as other English players by moving to Manchester City, citing the lack of playing time for players like Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair.

The passage discusses the case of Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "godfather of Uxbridge" who was living in the UK for over 20 years. He was convicted in absentia in Italy for his role as a "man of honor" in the Cosa Nostra and was sentenced to seven years in prison. However, his sentence expired in October 2014, and his European Arrest Warrant was withdrawn in February 2015. The Italian authorities no longer seek his extradition, and he will be allowed to remain in the UK. The passage also mentions the costs and inefficiencies of the extradition process and the reactions of legal experts to the case.

Mr. Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, is one of three 7-2 co-favorites in the grade one celebration chase at Sandown on Saturday. The other favorites are Irish raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson's Sprinter Sacre. AP McCoy will ride Mr. Mole in his last grade one race, as he announced his retirement after winning with Mr. Mole at Newbury in February. Other runners in the race include Mick Channon's Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcia, was murdered in 1975 by Jerome Sydney Barrett. Her body was found 33 days after she disappeared, and Ritter's then-husband advised her against seeing the body and crime scene photos. Ritter recently viewed the crime scene photos for the first time in decades, describing the gruesome details of her daughter's body. Barrett was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one, aims to win the Masters at Augusta National to complete his career grand slam of major titles. He has only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, finishing joint eighth last year. McIlroy believes it is "unthinkable" that he will not win the Masters at some point in his career. He has revealed that his final-round collapse in 2011 was the most important day of his career, as it taught him valuable lessons. McIlroy is hoping to use the golf course as his sanctuary from the pressure and hype surrounding Augusta.

1. Four rainbows appeared in the New York area after heavy rain, captured by Amanda Curtis.
2. Hiring exotic dancers for wakes is a growing trend in rural China, but it's being cracked down on due to the country's vice crackdown.
3. Robert Downey Jr. (Rdj) became agitated during an interview about his private life.
4. The latest trend is lip plumping, inspired by Kylie Jenner, with the hashtag #kyliejennerchallenge.
5. Alice Barker, 102 years old, went back in time with help from filmmakers.
6. A prom-posal referencing bombs was rejected by a school, but the prom-poser accused administrators of racism.
7. Ewan McGregor will play Lumiere in the live-action "Beauty and the Beast."
8. Johnny Depp's nearly unrecognizable appearance in the "Black Mass" trailer gained attention.
9. A woman announced her pregnancy by referencing "

272 children in England were hospitalized due to Fetal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS) in the past year, according to data from the official health and social care information center. However, the actual number of children affected by their mother's drinking could be much higher. Research by the World Health Organization suggests that at least one in 100 babies born in the UK could suffer learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure in the womb, equating to about 7,500 every year. FAS can cause various medical issues, including learning difficulties, behavioral problems, deformed limbs, liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. Pregnant women are advised not to drink alcohol, with a maximum consumption of up to two units no more than twice a week. However, some experts believe the guidance should be changed to advise complete abstinence from alcohol during pregnancy.

An axe-wielding robber, Shaun Andrew McKerry, attempted to rob a store in Shildon, County Durham, but was foiled by the shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, who tackled him, and his wife, Sam, who hit him with a baseball bat. McKerry, known for his criminal history and nicknames like "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy," was sentenced to six years in prison for attempted robbery.

The four Royal Navy sailors, Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley, have been charged with gang rape of a young woman at an alcohol-fueled party at a Canadian barracks. They have been granted bail with unusual conditions, including living on a Canadian naval base, surrendering their passports, and continuing to work for the Royal Navy. They are forbidden to contact the victim or six witnesses and cannot leave the province of Nova Scotia. They are accused of sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which are punishable by up to 14 years in prison. The investigation is still ongoing, and forensic tests could result in additional charges.

Valerie Jackson, a mother from Las Vegas, was accused of child abuse after a stranger reported her to the police for allegedly scalding her four-year-old son, RJ Jackson. RJ suffers from Netherton's syndrome, a rare skin disease that makes his skin appear red and scaly. The condition is caused by a faulty gene and can lead to hair, infection, and allergy problems. Despite being diagnosed at birth, RJ's condition has not improved with time, and his skin remains red and scaly. His mother has to regularly apply creams to ease his painful symptoms. The family has faced cruel taunts and been denied entry to play centers due to RJ's condition. Valerie Jackson is determined to raise awareness about Netherton's syndrome and hopes that as RJ grows, his condition will be better understood.

The controversial "Are you beach body ready?" adverts by Protein World, featuring a bikini-clad model named Renee Somerfield, have been removed from the London Underground after a three-week advertising period. The ads sparked a backlash from feminists, body image campaigners, and social media users who criticized the perceived insinuation that only women who look like Renee are ready for the beach. The Advertising Standards Authority received over 200 complaints, and the ads were defaced by bloggers. Protein World has taken note of the reaction and will consider it for future advertisements. The removal of the posters comes as a protest against the campaign gathers steam in Hyde Park, with hundreds expected to attend. The company has actively engaged in the controversy on social media, defending their campaign and receiving threats and a bomb threat. The Advertising Standards Authority is assessing the complaints, and sales of protein powder are expected to reach Â£358m by 2017.

Rail firms, including First Great Western and Virgin, have planned significant fare hikes of up to 87% for certain routes, despite party leaders pledging to freeze prices. The Prime Minister, David Cameron, has requested First Great Western to review its decision to increase fares on the route between London and the Cotswolds, which passes through his constituency. The planned changes have angered his constituents, prompting him to personally intervene. Train companies have three windows every year to increase 'unregulated' fares, which make up around half of their total revenue. The increases are set to come into effect on May 17.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was left blinded in one eye after being hit by a brick thrown through his front door by vandals. The attack occurred when he confronted them about throwing stones at his property in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The couple, who had recently married, were writing thank you cards for their wedding gifts when the incident happened. Police are investigating the attack, which appears to have no motive and could be a case of yobs "messing around".

Tom Poynton, a 25-year-old wicketkeeper for Derbyshire, has signed a one-year contract extension after recovering from leg injuries sustained in a road accident that also resulted in his father's death. Poynton, a former England under-19 international, underwent an ankle operation and made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi. The club's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's resilience and expressed hope that the new contract will boost his confidence to perform well in the upcoming season.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw, from Stretford, was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer, in his kidney, lung, bones, and neck. Despite the diagnosis, Harley remained brave and asked to decorate his protective mask for radiotherapy treatment like a Ninja Turtle. He underwent 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, an operation to remove his kidney tumor, a stem cell transplant, and weeks of radiotherapy. After a year of treatment, Harley was given the all-clear by doctors and is now cancer-free. He will undergo regular check-ups to ensure he remains cancer-free.

Jack Grealish, a 19-year-old Aston Villa player, is at the center of a tug of war between the Republic of Ireland and England for his international allegiance. Tim Sherwood, Villa's manager, wants Grealish to focus on his club career and earn a spot in the first team. Sherwood believes Grealish has the potential to play for either country, but he should first make a decision based on his heart. Grealish's father also advises him to concentrate on his club football first.

The passage discusses the varying landing fees for private jets at different airports worldwide. The most expensive fees are found in Japan, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo charging the highest at Â£ 4,559 ( $ 6,850 ). Other expensive airports include Narita International Airport in Tokyo (Â£ 3,728 or $ 5,600) and Kansai International Airport in Osaka (Â£ 3,594 or $ 5,400). The UK's Bristol Airport and the US's LaGuardia Airport in New York also make the list, charging Â£ 2,929 ( $ 4,400) and $ 3,950, respectively. The passage also mentions that the private jet industry is worth $ 16.7 trillion in the US and $ 15.8 trillion in Europe, with 2.5 million private flights in the US and 705,000 in Europe. The most popular routes include Los Angeles to Las Vegas and Milan to R
