The passage reports that as of now, there have been over 392,000 confirmed cases of a certain event worldwide. Out of these, more than 17,100 have resulted in fatalities, while over 102,000 individuals have successfully recovered.

Paul Merson and Andros Townsend had a public disagreement over Townsend's inclusion in the England squad. Merson initially criticized Townsend's call-up, stating that he shouldn't be in the squad. However, Townsend responded by scoring a goal for England against Italy, which Merson acknowledged as a great goal. Despite this, Merson continued to express his opinion that Townsend shouldn't be in the squad. After Tottenham's draw with Burnley, Merson made another comment about Townsend's late appearance in the game, which led to Townsend responding on Twitter.

Chelsea have made an offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, who has played for the J-League side since 2013. If he joins Chelsea, he will initially be on loan to Vitesse Arnhem next season. The offer is not related to Chelsea's Â£200million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. Muto, who graduated from Keio University with an economics degree, has earned 11 caps for Japan and scored once. He has scored 16 goals in 37 appearances for FC Tokyo and has been named in the J-League's best XI. Muto has not yet decided whether to join Chelsea, despite being pleased with their offer.

The study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight or obese as toddlers. The research, published in the medical journal Pediatrics, suggests that antibiotics may contribute to the obesity epidemic. The study involved over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds and found that boys who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight. The study did not prove that antibiotics cause weight gain, but it suggests that they may do so by killing off gut bacteria that would otherwise feed on food, leaving more food for the body, or by increasing appetite. The study also found that repeated prescriptions before the age of two raised the odds of being a fat toddler. The researchers warned that the extended use of antibiotics may have undesirable consequences, including contributing to the development of excess weight problems.

A Queen's Guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony at Buckingham Palace, causing his bearskin to fall and his rifle to drop. The incident was captured on a tourist's camera and the guard, who was wearing full regalia, quickly got back up. The guard is believed to have slipped due to metal protectors on his boots. The Changing of the Guard is a popular event where tourists gather to watch.

The original "Roots" miniseries, which aired in 1977 and had over 100 million viewers, is being remade for 2016 by A&E networks. The new version will focus more on Alex Haley's novel and will be more contemporary, with consultation from African and African-American history scholars. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new miniseries. The remake will reach a new generation of viewers who have seen historical events like Barack Obama's presidency and "12 Years a Slave" winning the Oscar, but also recent racial unrest.

Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, alleges that he was forced into an orgy by palace aides at Clarence House, the Queen Mother's London residence, on his first day of work in 1978. He claims he was pinned to a chair and groped by a male member of staff, which left him in tears and led to him leaving the job the same day. His complaints were reportedly ignored for months before being passed to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide was interviewed but denied involvement. The Palace has stated they will cooperate with any police investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song of the 1990s TV sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'. The video, which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube, shows the couple rapping as they drive in a car. They revealed that they found out they were expecting after trying for two months and were surprised by the positive pregnancy test result. The video was made to share the news with loved ones living far away.

The gray jacket and skirt ensemble worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at an auction. The outfit was used in several key scenes, including Scarlett's encounters with Rhett Butler and her attack in the shanty town. The dress, originally slate blue-gray, has faded to light gray over time. The collection was amassed by James Tumblin, a former hair and makeup department head at Universal Studios, who bought the dress for $20 in the 1960s. Other notable items from the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), Rhett Butler's trousers and jacket ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by both Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000).

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his mother dangled him over the edge. The boy was rescued by his parents and suffered minor injuries. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family.

The speed camera located on Wellington Road in Handsworth, Birmingham, which previously enforced the 30mph speed limit, has not been working for over two years. The camera was recently re-pointed to face a house, and the owners were not available for comment. The camera was part of the old technology that was decommissioned in 2013, and there are no plans to include it in a new pilot using digital technology.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete in the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3, as part of the Jamaican team. He expressed his excitement and readiness to run, emphasizing Jamaica's strong relay tradition. The Jamaican Athletics Administrative Association (JAAA) is pleased to have Bolt on the team, expecting'sprint magic' from him. The full Jamaican team list will be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves, teammates at Barcelona, showed their support for the club's basketball team by attending a Euro League match between Barcelona and Real Madrid. Barcelona won the match 85-80, but Real Madrid remains top of their Euro League division. Neymar recently led Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile in a feisty contest. Barcelona returns to La Liga on Sunday to face Celta Vigo, aiming for a treble of trophies.

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East, with over 8,000 rescued in a single weekend. However, there are reports of a possible capsized boat carrying 550 migrants, with 400 potentially missing. The Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident. Most migrants are from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. At least 480 migrants have died this year due to bad weather and overcrowded vessels.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool last summer. Sanchez has made a significant impact at Arsenal, scoring 19 goals so far this season. Wenger believes Sanchez's quick adaptation to the team and environment showcases his exceptional qualities. He also acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez could have been used as leverage in negotiations over Luis Suarez's transfer to Barcelona. Wenger downplayed speculation about a potential transfer for Liverpool winger Raheem Sterling, praising Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for his team's performance despite the sale of Suarez and injury to Daniel Sturridge.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break the cycling hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. The current record is 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins aims to set a mark that will last for some time and is expected to race in front of a capacity crowd. Tickets for the event will go on sale from April 19.

Serena Williams, the world No 1, struggled to beat Sara Errani in the Fed Cup, eventually winning 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3. Despite the victory, Williams expressed concern about her readiness for the claycourt season, stating she's playing like she's on hard court instead of adjusting to the clay. The US team lost the match 3-2, leading to their relegation to World Group II. Williams' doubles defeat with Alison Riske was a rare blemish on her otherwise flawless Fed Cup record.

River Plate, a former club of Radamel Falcao, is interested in signing the Manchester United striker. Falcao, who left River Plate in 2009, has struggled at United this season, scoring only four Premier League goals. However, he has been in good form for Colombia, scoring three goals in two games and equaling the country's all-time goalscoring record. Falcao scored 34 goals in 90 appearances for River Plate during his time there.

Ella Henderson, a platinum award-winning artist and X Factor finalist, has been named the face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. This is her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson showcasing various hairstyles, including a wavy style and a half-ponytail, against a blurred city background. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency and includes a TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's single, Mirror Man. Henderson uses Batiste dry shampoo regularly and is excited about the collaboration.

Aaron Siler, 26, was fatally shot by officer Pablo Torres in Kenosha, Wisconsin on March 14 after allegedly arming himself with a weapon during a confrontation. The billboard featuring Torres and his dog, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, has been erected in the city, causing shock and outrage among Siler's family and friends who view it as disrespectful. The police association claims the billboard was intended to thank the community for its support during the recent incidents, including the shooting of Siler and another man, Terry Knight, who was wounded by Torres in a separate incident. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing, while the shooting of Knight was deemed justified by the District Attorney's office.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Iran-Pakistan border. The militants, believed to be from the anti-Iranian group Jaish al Adal, crossed into Iran from Pakistan's Balochistan province. Three militants were killed by Iranian forces, and the surviving assailants have been asked to be caught by Pakistani authorities. Jaish al Adal has claimed responsibility for the attack and has previously targeted Shiites and Iranian influence in Pakistan. Iran has criticized Pakistan for failing to rein in the terrorists, and Pakistan has condemned the attack and promised to apprehend the militants if they entered Pakistan after the incident.

The passage discusses a political discussion in Japan about the possibility of extraterrestrial life and UFOs. The Defense Minister, Gen Nakatani, confirmed that Japan's Air Self Defense Force has never encountered an extraterrestrial UFO. The discussion was sparked by a query from former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki, who has a history of promoting products and attempting diplomacy through sports. Inoki himself claims to have seen a UFO but admits he doesn't know if aliens exist. The topic of extraterrestrial life has been discussed by Japanese politicians before, including the legal implications of defending against an outer space invasion.

A passenger, Jin Pai, 35, was injured after a toilet he was squatting on at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China collapsed, causing deep cuts on his leg and buttocks. He was embarrassed to shout for help and was later hospitalized. The incident is believed to be an accident, and authorities remind people to use toilets as intended.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl and filming her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom. He faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. The girl discovered the camera in March and reported that Rebbie had been watching her for years. He allegedly molested her when she was 9-13 years old and recorded her showering and undressing. Rebbie admitted to filming other victims but specifically targeted the 15-year-old girl. He is being held on $500,000 bail and will have a preliminary hearing on May 1.

The passage describes a photography series by Japanese photographer YÃ»ki Aoyama, featuring fathers leaping into the air next to their daughters. The images are part of a book titled "Daughter and Salaryman," with fathers dressed in suits and daughters in casual clothing. The photographs capture the fathers' fun side, expressing their excitement and hope, despite their age and the sometimes pained expressions. The families pose in front of various Japanese landmarks, and the series has gained online interest due to its unique and curious nature.

Kevin Pietersen, a former England cricketer, has rejoined Surrey and is aiming to return to the international set-up. His last international appearance was during the last Ashes tour in Australia in 2013-14. The dismissal of Paul Downton, England's managing director, has opened up opportunities for Pietersen's potential return. Pietersen was seen in deep thought during a team photo shoot, but also in a jovial mood, indicating his eagerness to return to the England team.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian football club facing relegation, has dismissed their Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week due to a 2-0 loss against FC Botosani. Ze Maria, who has represented Brazil 25 times, was initially reinstated after a poor run but was fired again due to the recent defeat. The club is now 16 points away from safety and will be appointing Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic as his replacement.

Radamel Falcao, a former Atletico Madrid striker, joined Manchester United on a season-long loan last summer. However, he has struggled to perform at his best due to a serious knee injury, scoring only four goals all season. United has the option to make the transfer permanent for Â£46 million, but it is unlikely they will do so given Falcao's poor performance. Falcao's former Monaco team-mate, Nabil Dirar, believes Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, as he was not happy in France and may have needed a more vibrant atmosphere.

A man, described as very tall and wearing a distinctive cartoon mask, robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday. He demanded cash from the dairy owner's daughter, threw the cash register, and made off with the till drawer and approximately $1500. The robber remained at large, and police are appealing for public assistance to identify him.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice in March and April for having inappropriate relationships with two different 15-year-old students. The first arrest was on March 19 for admitting to kissing one student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April 2021. The second arrest was on Monday after another student accused her of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January 2022. The sexual encounters allegedly took place in her car near another school in Dallas. Granado was released on bail after each arrest and is currently on administrative leave from her teaching position.

A crocodile was spotted in a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its mouth. The dog belonged to the local bike shop's owner. The incident was witnessed by a New Zealander named Tim Weston, who described the crocodile as calmly holding onto the dog for hours. The marina is located near a crocodile sanctuary, and the area is known for its American Crocodiles, which can reach lengths of 6 meters. The video of the incident has been viewed over half a million times online.

Steve Bruce, manager of Hull City, is confident that his team can avoid relegation from the Barclays Premier League despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton. Hull has only secured six wins out of their targeted ten, and now faces challenging fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players, including Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Hull is currently two points clear of the drop zone.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after he asked pupils to change their exam answers for the national curriculum tests, invalidating his school's SATs results. He also altered some pupils' exam answers himself. The Department for Education annulled all SATs exam results for the entire school after an investigation. Guffick was found to have committed unacceptable professional conduct and was banned from teaching for at least two years.

Anders Lindegaard, Manchester United goalkeeper, is enjoying his personal life with his wife Misse Beqiri, a Swedish model with Albanian roots. They have a son together and married in a beach wedding in Mauritius. Despite limited playing time at United, Lindegaard has been active on Instagram, sharing moments with his wife and promoting her modeling work.

The passage describes the failed auction of 13 glowing blue letters that once adorned Yankee Stadium in the Bronx. The letters, which were estimated to sell for $300,000 to $600,000, did not receive any bids at the Sotheby's auction. The current owner, Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, purchased the letters for an undisclosed amount after the stadium's final game in 2008. Jackson had hoped a new generation would own and enjoy the iconic signage, but the auction ended without a successful bid. The letters had been displayed at the stadium since 1976, and Jackson bought them "on a lark." Additionally, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s was auctioned off and sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has addressed the recent behavior of Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe, who were pictured smoking a shisha pipe. Rodgers reminded them of their professional responsibilities and urged them to learn from the incident. He spoke to them in his office but decided not to discipline them, aiming to draw a line under the matter. Rodgers also discussed the importance of learning from losses and setbacks, referencing the journey of successful players and teams. He did not reveal whether he would recall Steven Gerrard, who is available after a three-match suspension, for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, recently returned from the international break and shared a photo of himself relaxing with his dog on Twitter. He had a successful international match against Georgia, scoring two goals, and is now preparing for the upcoming Premier League game against Liverpool. Ozil, who joined Arsenal in 2013 for Â£42.5 million, missed the last game due to illness but is expected to start against Liverpool. He has been performing well since returning from injury, contributing with four assists and three goals in the past few months. Ozil also mentioned that he enjoys the demanding schedule of English football, as it allows for more games, which he prefers as a player.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has confirmed that the team is not planning to replace manager Luis Enrique, who has been with the club since last summer and is set to win the La Liga title. Despite speculation about his future, Bartomeu expressed satisfaction with Enrique's performance and his ability to lead the team towards winning three trophies this season.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, has agreed to a new long-term contract with the club. The deal, worth around Â£100,000 per week, will run until 2020. Henderson, who joined Liverpool in 2011, has been one of the most improved players under manager Brendan Rodgers. He has contributed 13 assists and 7 goals this season and is considered for the role of club captain when Steven Gerrard leaves. Talks with Raheem Sterling are not expected to resume until the end of the season.

Filipe Luis, a full back at Chelsea, has expressed his desire to stay at the club until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. He played for Brazil during the international break but is now focused on the Premier League title run-in. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is urging his team to remain focused and win every game, as they have nine challenging matches ahead.

Nathan Hughes, a Wasps No. 8, had his ban for accidentally knocking out George North overturned on appeal. Hughes was initially suspended for three matches after a disciplinary panel ruled he was'reckless' for failing to prevent his knee from colliding with North's head. However, the ban was thrown out in a stunning twist following fierce criticism. Hughes missed Wasps' Champions Cup quarter-final loss against Toulon last Sunday and is now free to return to action immediately, but he is not in the match-day squad for Wasps' Aviva Premiership trip to London Welsh tomorrow.

The passage describes a series of wildfires in Siberia that have led to intense red sunsets in the Pacific Northwest, including Seattle. The fires, started by farmers burning grass, spread rapidly due to strong winds, destroying several villages. The smoke from these fires has been carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean, causing the red sunsets. As the smoke dissipates, the sunsets will lose their reddish hue and air quality will improve.

Becky Schoenig, a Missouri mom, had her new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. The car was found by a man who recognized it and returned it to her with red rims, red detailing, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig thanked the thieves and is now getting the car professionally cleaned. She is also creating a smoothie at her restaurant to honor the man who located her car.

Manchester City players, including Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, and Yaya Toure, are at risk of losing Â£500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The team is currently in fourth place, four points ahead of Liverpool, but has struggled with seven losses this season. Manager Manuel Pellegrini acknowledged the team's poor performance and the challenge of signing top-class players like Paul Pogba due to their current position.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City's Under 18s 1-0 in a'mini-derby' match. The game was played at Altrincham's Moss Lane, with 13 out of 22 players being English and 10 of them being Mancunian. Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal for United with a free-kick. The match was part of the Barclays Under 18s Premier League end-of-season play-off series. United won two of the cross-town clashes this year, while City lost both matches. The game showcased talents from both sides that may deserve first-team opportunities in the future.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart, who has earned 50 caps, praised Italian veteran Gianluigi Buffon, who has 147 caps, as a 'legend of the game'. Hart, 10 years younger than Buffon, expressed his admiration for the Italian's longevity and skill in the game.

Chipotle, a popular Mexican restaurant, is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app. This collaboration will allow customers in 67 cities to order online or through the mobile app and have their burritos delivered to their doorsteps. However, a 9% service charge will be added, and delivery fees will start at $5, depending on distance and demand. Chipotle has previously declined offers from third-party delivery services but has now approved this partnership. Other franchises like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring delivery services.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have written an opinion piece in The Boston Globe, urging the Justice Department to drop the death penalty for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the convicted bomber. They argue that the pursuit of the death penalty could bring years of appeals and prolong the pain of reliving the tragedy. They believe that Tsarnaev should spend the rest of his life in prison without any possibility of release and waiving all of his rights to appeal.

The passage describes a custom-built Boeing 747-8 jumbo jet, costing Â£400 million, converted into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire. The plane features multiple bedrooms, lounges, a dining room with a kitchen, and an onboard restaurant. It can accommodate dozens of guests and has a top deck with eight full beds for sleeping during flights. The interior is designed to resemble a luxury hotel, with plush decorations and porthole-style windows.

SpaceX successfully launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying a Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station, but failed to land the rocket stage on a drone ship for the first time. The top part of the rocket will break away and burn up in Earth's atmosphere, while the Dragon will deliver supplies and return with experiments and trash. This is the sixth SpaceX mission to the ISS.

Priscilla Presley, Elvis Presley's former wife, will serve as a witness at the first wedding to be held at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The winning couple, chosen through a contest by NBC's Today show, will tie the knot on April 23. They will receive a free wedding reception, hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Elvis's Memphis home.

Liverpool's Jordan Henderson believes they can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after equalling the record for most appearances by any player in the top five European leagues this season. Liverpool won 2-0 against Newcastle United, with Raheem Sterling scoring the first goal and Joe Allen scoring his first Anfield goal. Despite a disappointing few weeks, Liverpool are determined to keep winning and make up the four-point gap behind City.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home with a victory over Napoli in Serie A, thanks to a goal from Miralem Pjanic in the 25th minute. Goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several crucial saves to secure the win. This victory moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio. Napoli's winless streak was extended to five matches, and they remained fifth in the league. The match was marked by tight security due to previous incidents involving the two clubs.

Doncaster Rovers played a goalless draw against Fleetwood Town in League One, leaving the media team with minimal match highlights to showcase on the club's YouTube channel. The video was a brief 27 seconds long, featuring only 14 seconds of match action, including the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

The passage describes a man named Roland Giroux who has a unique bond with his blood parrot cichlid fish. Despite being a marine pet, the fish enjoys human interaction, particularly through touch. Giroux interacts with the fish by stroking and massaging it, which the fish seems to enjoy. The fish was initially bullied by other fish in its tank, leading to its removal. Giroux then began hand-feeding the fish and eventually developed a daily routine of playing with it for at least 15 minutes. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid of the midas and redhead cichlid, first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes, a fiery character in the England cricket team, is set to return after a year of ups and downs. He has a reputation for aggression, which he needs to channel in the right way. Stokes' natural exuberance and desire to take someone on are valuable, but he must avoid trying to live up to his reputation and become pigeon-holed. England wants to have Stokes in the team as much as possible to help him reach his full potential. The team is considering playing a second spinner, which could affect Stokes' or Chris Jordan's place in the team. However, England wants both to play as much as possible this summer.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium, scheduled for June 12, has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Both teams have 11 points in Group B, with Belgium leading due to a better goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has boosted expectations for their chances of qualifying for the tournament. The match will be held at the Cardiff City Stadium, which the Wales squad prefers over the Millennium Stadium.

England's Under-17 team, coached by John Peacock, has been named for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. They are the defending champions and have been placed in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland. Patoulidis is considered one of the best talents from Anderlecht's youth set-up and has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. He previously rejected a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy to focus on his studies. A transgender escort named Vanessa Santillan was found strangled and beaten to death in a Â£400,000 flat in Fulham, London on March 28. Dawn, a woman who has experienced seven miscarriages, discovered that her friend Jamie had stolen Â£207 meant for a gravestone for her late son, Daniel James. Despite initial denials, a lie detector test confirmed Jamie's guilt. The stolen money was intended to cover a portion of the Â£500 gravestone cost. Dawn expressed her distress and betrayal, as she had saved the money to honor her son's memory.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, a minority group, on Wednesday. Most of those released were women and children, with the rest being ill or elderly. The release was coordinated by Arab tribal leaders. The Yazidis are of Kurdish descent and their religion is considered a pre-Islamic sect. They have long suffered persecution, with many Muslims referring to them as devil worshipers. ISIS' cruelty to them has been extraordinary, including slaughtering hundreds and raping and enslaving female captives. The Yazidis were released to the Peshmerga, who sent them to the Kurdish regional capital, Irbil. The motive behind the release is not clear.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham striker, has had an exceptional season, scoring 20 Premier League goals and making his England debut. He is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A new animation featuring his best goals and celebrations has been released, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?'. The animation uses still photographs to create an animated effect.

Jamie Carragher, a former Liverpool defender, believes Brendan Rodgers is still the right man to lead the team forward despite a third consecutive season without a trophy and a likely finish outside the top four. Carragher, who received a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside, thinks Rodgers' future should not be determined by one game and that the team will improve next season. James Hayward, a four-year-old boy, had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport due to it being deemed a security risk. He is not a drinker, smoker, or drug user, loves traveling, outdoors, sports, fishing, and camping. He is successful, makes good money, and owns properties. He is not shy about spending money on his partner and promises many benefits. Former partners need not apply.

The passage discusses the proposal by Football Association chairman Greg Dyke to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in Premier League club squads from eight to 12. This proposal is supported by five former England managers: Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren. They warn that blocking this proposal could lead to England falling further behind leading football nations and make it harder to win the World Cup. The managers also highlight the shrinking pool of English talent playing at the top level and the lack of opportunity for young players.

Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, gives birth to the show's latest addition in the upcoming episode. The North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has made the longest migration of any mammal, covering nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpasses the previous record set by a humpback whale. Varvara's route included three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting she may be an eastern gray whale despite being initially thought to be a western gray whale. This discovery could impact the estimated number of western gray whales, which is believed to be around 150.

1,000ft of seabed emerged overnight along the coastline of Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, Hokkaido Island, Japan, due to a landslide caused by melting ice and snow. The new landmass, which is 30-50ft above sea level, measures approximately 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide. Local residents were surprised as they felt no tremors or heard any sounds indicating the movement. Authorities do not expect the landmass to expand further and it is not related to the Nepal earthquake.

Bayern Munich manager Pep Guardiola ripped his trousers during their 6-1 Champions League victory over Porto, exposing his underwear. The incident occurred as Guardiola celebrated his team's impressive performance, which secured their place in the semi-finals. Guardiola joked about needing to buy new trousers for the next match.

Ten individuals, including four children, were involved in a multi-vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale. Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico. The deaths appear to be a murder-suicide, with the authorities investigating the incident. The ship departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29 and is currently in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

Christopher Hogwood, a renowned conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), passed away at his home in Cambridge after a long illness. In the year ending March 2016, there were 57 recorded homicide cases in Scotland, a decrease of 5 from the previous year and the lowest number since 1976. Cuadrilla, a company involved in shale gas drilling (fracking), has temporarily suspended operations due to a 1.5 magnitude earthquake in Lancashire, UK. This is the second such incident in two months. The earthquake occurred near the Preese Hall site, where fracking was taking place. The British Geological Survey (BGS) has confirmed that the earthquake's location and mechanism are similar to a previous tremor on April 1st. Fracking involves using hydraulic pressure or tiny explosions to shatter hard shale rocks and release gas. The process has been controversial in the US due to environmental concerns, but the UK's energy select committee has called for its support with tight regulation and good industry practice. The BGS is monitoring fracking as a precaution, as any process that injects pressurized water into rocks at depth can cause earthquakes.

Angus Carpenter, a bagpiper from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for using a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes to imply he was collecting funds for the charity in April 2015. The UN conference in Geneva decided to allocate a radio frequency for global flight tracking, aiming to improve the current radar-based system. This new system will use satellite tracking and automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) to enable real-time tracking of aircraft worldwide. Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, has been found living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland at age 18. Bobby Hernandez, 53, is currently in jail in Ohio, charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. He is also suspected of being involved in Julian's disappearance in 2002. The FBI confirmed Julian's identity after receiving a tip on 30 October, and his mother has been notified of his recovery.

Firefighters worked at a site in Duncan Street for several days following a fire on 2 March, which disrupted train services and caused travel delays. The Environment Agency suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste after the fire. The company was generally compliant with fire safety laws, but the cause of the fire is still unknown. The Environment Agency has revoked the company's environmental permit, effective 7 August, and the company must remove all waste from the site.

The passage discusses two bills proposed by the pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia, which are linked to the situation in Ukraine. The first bill aims to simplify the process of incorporating a neighboring state's territory into Russia, particularly in cases where a state is disintegrating. This bill was drafted in response to the strong pro-Russian sentiments in Ukraine's Crimea region, which has a significant Russian population and is the current focus of the crisis. The second bill expedites the procedures for issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, especially those who speak Russian, to support them in the face of what is perceived as a "brown threat." This bill allows Ukrainians to apply for Russian passports at Russian diplomatic missions before August 1 and become citizens after two months, instead of the usual one-year wait. The plan was announced in Sevastopol, where several Russian MPs, including celebrities, have visited.

McLaren, a team with a rich history of success in Formula 1, including 182 grand prix wins and 12 drivers' world championships, is currently facing a slump. Despite having two world champions in their lineup, Fernando Alonso and Lewis Hamilton, the team is struggling with their car's performance, particularly with the Honda power-unit. This is a stark contrast to their past partnerships with Honda, which led to their most successful era in 1988 when they won 15 out of 16 races. The team has experienced cycles of triumph and decline throughout their history, with their last constructors' title in 2008. Their current predicament is not surprising, given their history of ups and downs. The team's owner, Ron Dennis, has been involved since the 1970s and has held various roles, including co-team boss and team principal. Despite recent setbacks, Dennis remains optimistic about the team's future and believes they will return

Tommy Baker, a 44-year-old man from Everton, was shot and killed in Liverpool on January 27. He was found injured at Stanley Meat Market in the Old Swan area after being shot in the head and chest. Three Liverpool men, aged 29 and 32, were arrested in connection with the incident and remain in custody. The shooting is believed to have occurred after Baker left Phoenix Gym at the market, with the perpetrators having been waiting outside for about an hour. A silver VW Polo, which left the scene at speed, is being sought by police. Several people captured on CCTV near the meat market have not yet come forward, and their information could be crucial to the investigation.

The passage discusses various ways to enjoy Christmas online, including virtual church services, a fantasy game, and Manga versions of Bible stories. Everyday Church Online, a UK-based virtual church, has a global congregation and offers sermons themed around Star Wars. Guardians of Ancora is a free-to-play game for children aged 8-11, aimed at teaching Bible stories. The Churches Advertising Network's Christmas ad was rejected for being too religious. Next Manga has launched Manga versions of Bible stories, including the nativity, in 33 languages, with 25,000 Arabic copies sent to Syrian and Libyan refugees. Many groups use social media platforms to connect with their communities, especially during Christmas.

The passage discusses an eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale regarding a request to take over 250 hectares of common land for a development. The backers, including Blaenau Gwent council, have offered around 320 hectares of replacement land. The inquiry has heard differing opinions from experts about the potential damage to habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales has expressed difficulty in concluding that the replacement land is of equal value, but they are not opposing the development overall. An ecology report presented by the developers suggests a "net gain" in biodiversity due to plans to enhance nearby habitats, which the Gwent wildlife trust disputes. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will make a recommendation after the inquiry, with final approval resting with Welsh government ministers.

The passage discusses a report by Novaya Gazeta on April 1, revealing that over 100 people were detained in Chechnya on suspicion of being homosexual, with at least three killed. The report was confirmed by the Russian LGBT Network. The Chechen Muslim clerics met on April 3, condemning the report and calling for "retribution" against the journalists, which Novaya Gazeta interprets as a call for reprisals. The Chechen leader, Ramzan Kadyrov, denies the allegations, and his spokesman claims there are no gay people in Chechnya. The report also mentions that some influential Muslim clerics and TV presenters were among the detainees. The LGBT Network is helping people flee the persecution and threatens to file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute anyone.

Investing Solutions, a lettings agency, has been receiving benefit payments over the past two years by housing single homeless men, primarily those aged 35 and over. The company, based in a storage unit in south London, is one of the largest recipients of housing benefit in the UK, making it highly profitable. They charge housing benefit for each tenant in a property, rather than the property's rent fee, leading to higher total benefit payouts. The company has been criticized for its practices, with one tenant describing the properties as unsuitable and another accusing them of prioritizing profit over people. Nearly half of the money Investing Solutions has received has come from Wandsworth Council in south London.

London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13 for GB in a game against the Netherlands. GB led for most of the first three quarters but lost their advantage in the last 10 minutes, ultimately losing the game. Coach Joe Prunty used his strongest line-up and was pleased with Gordon's performance. GB will begin their Eurobasket qualifying campaign with a game in Hungary.

The former five-weight world champion, Conor McGregor, submitted a necessary waiver to the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) on Wednesday, hours before the deadline. The NAC, which sanctioned the bout, expects to debate the matter of using 10oz gloves instead of the usual 8oz gloves for a 154lbs fight on 16 August. The debate will focus on the impact of lighter gloves on punching power and hand protection. McGregor, who will make his boxing debut against Floyd Mayweather, has used 4oz gloves in his UFC career and welcomed Mayweather's Instagram post suggesting 8oz gloves. The NAC will publicly debate the matter before announcing its decision.

The passage discusses the history of Fleet Street, once the heart of British journalism, where many national newspapers had offices. It was known for its journalists, bars, and the Sunday Post's London office, which is closing. The street was famous for its journalists and pubs, with notable figures like Robin Esser and Liz Hodgkinson working there. The street's significance declined with the rise of television and social media, and many newspapers moved to Wapping in the 1980s. The passage ends with the closure of the Sunday Post's London office, marking the end of an era in British journalism.

J.K. Rowling, the Harry Potter author, has expressed her experiences of being a famous woman on Twitter, highlighting the presence of abusive comments and bullies. She has donated significant amounts to political causes, including Â£1m to the No vote in the Scottish independence referendum and the Labour party in 2008. Following criticism for her political views, she has been called a "traitor" and has blocked abusive users, but also engaged with nice SNP supporters. Despite facing backlash, she has joked about her books being burned. The SNP won 56 seats in Scotland's election, becoming the third largest party in the UK.

The study found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action than better-off children who commit the same crime. Living in poverty also increases the likelihood of violence among both boys and girls. The researchers identified poverty as an exacerbating factor that increases the likelihood of young people offending, even when other risk factors are taken into account. The study also found that people who live in extreme poverty are more likely to be victims and perpetrators of crime. Gender was identified as a powerful predictor of violence, with boys being three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts. Girls from poorer backgrounds were twice as likely as girls from more affluent households to be involved in violent crime. The study was conducted by University of Edinburgh researchers and published in the Scottish Justice Matters journal. The findings suggest that contact with the juvenile justice system increases the risks associated with poverty, inadvertently reproducing the conditions in which violence can flourish.

Mr Haugh, a 25-year-old man, was stabbed to death in a laneway in the Marian estate in Kilkee early on Sunday. Robbie Walsh, of Island View, Kilrush, has been charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr Haugh and is remanded in custody. Two other men arrested over the killing were released without charge. It is alleged that Walsh and two other men entered the Marian Estate looking for Mr Haugh and a fight ensued where weapons were used, resulting in Mr Haugh's death. Knives and golf clubs were recovered at the scene, and a knife handle and blade with blood on it were found. The state presented evidence of tension in the area due to the killing, and Walsh was remanded in custody until 14 August.

Phil Flanagan, a Sinn FÃ©in MLA, tweeted in May 2014 that Tom Elliott, a former UDR member and current MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone, had harassed and shot people during his service. Elliott, who has a clear MoD record, was alerted to the tweet by victims' campaigner Ann Travers and DUP assembly member Arlene Foster. Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and apologized, admitting it was untrue. Elliott is seeking compensation and costs, as the insurance firm indemnifying MLAs at Stormont has refused to cover Flanagan. Flanagan is challenging this decision in a separate court action.

Hawick Knitwear, established in 1874, has seen a significant increase in production and sales. The company, now under the management of Benny Hartop, has boosted its production to 9,500 sweaters per week, up from 7,500 last year. This increase is due to a surge in orders from both domestic and international private label clients, as well as demand for their own brand. The company sells in Europe (Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, Spain) and markets outside Europe (USA, Canada, Mexico, Japan).

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, was struck by Brian Wright's VW Golf outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red traffic light. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care. Wright denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving, stating he cannot remember if the lights were red or green. The trial is ongoing.

The passage discusses a naval exercise conducted by Nato to improve anti-submarine warfare capabilities, focusing on the growing threat from Russian submarines. The exercise involves 10 Nato warships, including the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, searching for a German U-boat (U33) acting as an enemy submarine. The challenge lies in locating an invisible enemy under vast stretches of ocean, likened to finding a needle in a haystack. The exercise highlights the gap in Britain's defenses due to the lack of maritime patrol aircraft, as Britain has had to rely on Nato allies for such capabilities in recent years. The exercise also showcases the use of underwater drones and long-range maritime patrol aircraft for surveillance.

The passage describes a humanitarian crisis in South Sudan, where violence has led to a massive exodus of people into neighboring Uganda. Since July, over 340,000 people have fled, making it the largest refugee influx into Uganda this year. The violence is primarily ethnic, with the Dinka and Nuer tribes targeting each other and other groups like the Equatorians. The refugees share harrowing accounts of killings, rape, and displacement. Uganda has been accommodating, providing land and resources for the refugees, but is now struggling to cope with the influx. The UN is calling for international pressure to stop the violence.

McKenzie, a 38-year-old former footballer, will compete against Jahmaine Smyle on 12 November at York Hall for the English super-middleweight championship. He turned professional in 2013, having previously played football for Norwich and Peterborough. McKenzie has an 8-1-1 record in his nine fights. He is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, former three-time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The passage discusses the planned construction of a new Bridgwater Community Hospital in England, funded by the coalition's Â£330m investment for new NHS facilities. The new hospital will have 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated and cramped, with maintenance and repair issues. The new hospital is expected to be completed by autumn 2014, pending planning permission, and will be built on land at Bowers Lane.

The victim, a member of a family living near Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, was fatally shot outside a property around 13:35 GMT. The incident occurred during a family celebration, with relatives gathering nearby. The victim was taken to Northern General hospital but died from his injuries. The area was sealed off by armed police. Recent weeks have seen several shootings in Sheffield, primarily in the north of the city, but this is the first incident in the Upperthorpe area.

The passage discusses the role of cyber warfare in the Ukraine conflict, featuring three main groups: the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are known for their DDoS attacks, hacking into Russian interior ministry servers, and monitoring rebel-held areas via CCTV systems. They also claim to have hijacked network printers to print pro-Ukrainian messages. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, aims to thwart Ukraine's military plans and has hacked Ukrainian government websites, electronic billboards, and vote-counting systems. They also claim to have leaked Ukrainian defense ministry data and blocked President Poroshenko's website. Anonymous International, a Russian activist group, focuses on Russia's domestic affairs but has also published material on Ukraine, including a letter from a Russian fighter and leaked emails from a former rebel command

The passage describes the farewell speeches of several MSPs (Members of the Scottish Parliament) ahead of the election on 5 May. Former SNP leader Alex Salmond, who served as first minister from 2007 to 2014, expressed his belief that Scotland is "not divided, but diverse" and emphasized the importance of the parliament assuming greater responsibility for the governance of Scotland. He also welcomed the transfer of powers to Holyrood under the Scotland Bill but criticized it for not fulfilling the pledges made during the referendum campaign. Salmond's speech was marked by humor, including jokes about the UK budget and the Cheltenham racecourse. He concluded by expressing his gratitude for the opportunity to serve the parliament and the people of Scotland.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was visibly emotional during Salmond's speech and also during the final speech of Scottish Labour backbencher Duncan McNeil, who is stepping down after serving in the par

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care. She is seeking input from older people, their families, and care providers to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will focus on factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. However, the chair of Care Forum Wales has expressed disappointment that no care home expert is included in the main advisory panel.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported a Â£800,000 increase in pre-tax profit to Â£3.5m for the year ending June 2016, despite a Â£1m drop in turnover to just over Â£100m. The company, which manufactures and supplies animal feed and operates Country Store shops, saw international sales grow in Europe and new markets. The outlook for agriculture is uncertain due to Brexit, but the company is confident in its position.

A man in his 70s was found deceased at a house in Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. A man in his 80s was also hospitalized. The police are treating the death as murder and are seeking to question Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, who is described as a white man, about 6ft tall, with greying hair, of average build, and last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue and white checked shirt. The police have warned the public not to approach McLoughlin and have urged anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers.

David Lipton, the second in command at the IMF, warned about the weakening global economy in a speech. He noted that the IMF's latest assessment shows a deteriorating baseline, and we are at a critical point. This comes after China's trade figures showed a significant drop in exports, which may impact businesses and industries that rely on China's growth. The IMF is expected to downgrade its global growth forecast from 3.4% in April.

The council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the Cowes ferry crossing would be free until 2 July to address the issues surrounding the new vessel. The ferry has faced numerous problems since its late May launch, including breakdowns, groundings, suspension due to training issues, and damage to cars. The council has ordered a review of the project and is considering compensation for affected local businesses. The issues are attributed to teething problems and seamanship, which have been addressed with ramp extensions and improved training.

A fatal crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott, around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man was pronounced dead at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed for several hours for investigation.

Matching Models, a London-based temp agency, has been criticized for its job advertisements seeking a personal assistant with a "classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup" and a "sexy female driver" for a businessman. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) has deemed these ads "appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women". The agency's founder defends the practice, stating that looks are important to their clients. The ads have been criticized for potentially discriminating against older women and for being unlawful under the 2010 Equality Act. The agency's clients include MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca-Cola, and Harrods.

The shooting incident occurred at a hostel attached to the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore city. The alleged gunman, Mahesh, a school office assistant, shot two students, 18-year-old Gautami and Sirisha, on Tuesday evening. Gautami was killed, while Sirisha suffered severe injuries but is expected to recover. Mahesh was arrested on Wednesday after a manhunt. India has strict gun control laws, but firearms are often used to settle disputes. This is one of the rare incidents of gun crime at schools in India, with the last major incident occurring in 2007 when a 14-year-old student was shot dead at a school campus near Delhi.

The advocacy group GLAAD analyzed shows seen or to be shown between June 2016 and May 2017 and found 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. The number of transgender characters increased from seven to 16. However, GLAAD expressed concern over the high number of lesbian and bisexual female characters who died or were killed off, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The report also highlighted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, thanks to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. GLAAD's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, noted progress but emphasized that numbers are only part of the story.

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, has decided not to seek re-election. This decision comes ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was expected to be opposed. The MP has been criticized for a loan of millions of pounds of public money to Northampton Town FC for stadium rebuilding and land development, with about Â£10.25m now missing and subject to a police investigation. The football stand remains half built. A majority of his party's local executive council intended to vote to deselect him.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, shot and killed Jordan Edwards, a 15-year-old, in April 2017 in Balch Springs, Texas. The incident occurred when Oliver fired into a car driving away from a party where underage drinking was reported. The car was full of teenagers, including Edwards and his two brothers. Oliver was initially reported to have fired after the car reversed aggressively towards him, but footage later disproved this claim, showing the car driving forward away from him. Oliver was fired from the police force a few days after the incident and was charged with four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official. He currently faces five to 99 years in prison on the murder charge and is free on bail. If convicted, he would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas county since 1973.

The passage discusses the decision of Melania Trump, the incoming First Lady of the United States, to delay moving to the White House with her son Barron until the end of the school year. This is unusual as only two other First Ladies, Martha Washington and Anna Harrison, did not live in the White House during their husbands' presidencies. Melania Trump has emphasized that Barron's education is her top priority. The passage also mentions that children of previous presidents have often had to change schools mid-term, but they have always lived in the White House from the day of the inauguration. The role of the First Lady is primarily ceremonial, serving as the White House's hostess and supporting various causes. Melania Trump has indicated that she will not take on a full-time role like her predecessors. The passage also discusses the public role of the First Lady, which can be filled by the president's wife or, in some cases, other family members.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) has been asked to investigate the initial police response to a call made by the man. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation and awaiting its findings. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) has instructed Pirc to conduct the investigation, and a report on the findings will be submitted to COPFS in due course.

The passage warns of a yellow warning for strong winds, with gusts up to 75mph (120kmph) expected, particularly in western areas near mountains. The unusual easterly wind direction may exacerbate the impact. Disruption to travel on roads and at sea is anticipated. The affected counties are Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. A tree fell in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing a main route into the town, and the road is expected to remain closed for most of Monday for cleanup.

In the first match of a double-header, the Giants scored the opening goal through player-coach Derrick Walser, but the Panthers equalized with a goal from Jeff Dimmen. Mike Forney's powerplay breakaway goal gave the Giants a 2-1 lead, which was then equalized by Andy Bohmback. Mike Radja scored from an acute angle, and James Desmarais made it 4-2 before Nottingham's David Ling got one back. Nottingham leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

World champion Lewis Hamilton had a challenging race, starting from the back, suffering a broken front wing on the first lap, and making five pit stops. He faces a 36-point deficit in the remaining 18 races of the season. Sebastian Vettel won the race despite colliding with team-mate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap. Raikkonen recovered to finish fifth, passing Hamilton in the closing stages. Hamilton will try to overhaul Rosberg's points lead, but no driver who has won the first three races of a season has failed to win the World Championship. The race was marked by incidents on the first lap, including collisions between Hamilton and Raikkonen, and Kvyat and Vettel. Mercedes decided not to stop Rosberg under the safety car, allowing him to drive off into the distance after the race restarted. Hamilton had to make three stops within the first six laps and faces an uphill battle to stop Rosberg winning his first World Championship this year.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a former German footballer, has publicly revealed his homosexuality, becoming the first prominent footballer to do so in Germany. His announcement has been met with widespread support from his former teammates, football administrators, and public figures. Hitzlsperger's decision is considered a significant step in the fight against homophobia in German football, which has struggled with the issue. His announcement follows a controversial statement by current Germany captain Philipp Lahm, who advised against coming out as gay in football. Hitzlsperger's courageous move is expected to encourage greater openness about sexuality in German football.

Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has played 32 Championship games for Brighton this season, contributing to their promotion to the Premier League. His contract is expiring, and he aims to sign a new deal. He has previously played in the Premier League with several clubs and believes he deserves another chance at the top level. Brighton is set to win the league title, with a four-point lead over second-placed Newcastle.

The match between Blackpool and Colchester United ended in a 1-1 draw. Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute through a goal by Jamille Matt, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized in the 17th minute via Kurtis Guthrie. Blackpool's goalkeeper, Sam Slocombe, made a remarkable save to prevent Colchester from retaking the lead just before halftime. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after substitute Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time.

The passage discusses a 29-year-old footballer named Reid, who played for the Sky Blues last season and was relegated from League One. He has also played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. Reid is set to make his debut for Colchester United (U's) in their upcoming EFL Cup match against Aston Villa. Colchester lost their first match of the season 3-1 against Accrington.

The passage discusses the proposed UK Police Memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum, which aims to honor and commemorate police officers and staff who have lost their lives over the past 250 years. The memorial, set to bear the names of more than 1,400 officers and staff, was prompted by the murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament in March. The UK Police Memorial Trust appealed for Â£1.5m towards its construction, with the government committing Â£1m. The memorial is expected to be completed by 2019 and will include a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out, given to the families of fallen officers as a personal memorial.

Manchester United won 1-0 at Sunderland, extending their lead at the top of the Premier League to 15 points with eight games left. They have won 25 out of 30 matches this season and have 50 points from their last 18 games. Manager Sir Alex Ferguson is focusing on the upcoming derby against Manchester City and the FA Cup quarter-final replay at Chelsea. He plans to make changes due to injuries and fatigue, but praised the team's performance in the first half against Sunderland.

Google's chairman, Eric Schmidt, stated that the company complies with the legal tax requirements in the UK, having paid Â£10m in corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011. He emphasized that taxes are not optional and that Google will pay more if taxes increase and less if they decrease. Schmidt also suggested that the UK government should change its tax system if it wants companies to pay more taxes. Meanwhile, Margaret Hodge, the head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, proposed establishing a new committee to oversee the tax arrangements of major firms, including Google, which routes most of its UK sales through Ireland to minimize tax payments. European Union leaders recently agreed to tackle tax avoidance through an "automatic information exchange between tax authorities." Schmidt has previously advocated for corporate taxes to be levied in the country where economic activity and risks occur, rather than where products are consumed, and has called for a debate on international tax reform.

The NHS has been struggling to reduce its agency bill, which was Â£3.6bn last year. NHS Improvement, the regulator, aims to decrease this by Â£1bn by the end of the current financial year. A cap on agency staff costs was introduced in October, saving Â£600m so far. The cap limits hospitals, mental health trusts, and ambulance services to paying no more than 55% above normal shift rates for agency staff, excluding senior managers. The goal is to lower the overall cost of agency staff and reduce hospitals' reliance on them. Agency staff are more expensive due to additional fees and employer costs. While progress is promising, the NHS is still short of its target, with trusts 10% below their desired agency spending. The agency bill is decreasing, but it's unclear if spending on other pay elements has increased. NHS Improvement will publish league tables of trusts' agency spending and collect data on the highest-earning agency staff per trust. Examples of hospitals being quoted double the agency rates have been found,

The Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of economic prosperity, has become a reminder of the Republic of Ireland's economic downturn. Despite recent improvements in business for local traders like Matt O'Brien, who has diversified his family-owned men's clothing shop, the area still faces challenges. The opposition party, Fianna FÃ¡il, criticizes the government's handling of the midlands, arguing that resources should be allocated to broadband improvement instead of water meters. The government, however, points to the planned Center Parcs tourism development as a sign of progress. The project, if approved, could bring about 1,000 jobs to the area. However, traders like O'Brien believe more can be done to boost local business, such as eliminating parking charges.

The Indian Premier League (IPL) tournament concludes on 29 May in the same stadium. There are eight teams participating, each facing each other twice. The top four teams will qualify for the play-offs. The tournament's progress can be followed through BBC Sport. Notable players include David Warner, Virat Kohli, AB de Villiers, and Chris Gayle, who are among the leading run-scorers. Warner, de Villiers, and Gayle have also scored the highest individual scores in an innings. Mitchell McClenaghan, Ashish Kumar, and Imran Tahir are the top wicket-takers. Four current or former England players are participating: Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. The tournament schedule includes various matches from 25 April to 29 May.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013, contributing to environmental issues as many are not recyclable and end up in landfills and waterways. Starting October, a 5p charge for plastic bags in England aims to promote reuse and reduce waste, following successful reductions in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland where similar charges are in place.

On Friday, a school roof was damaged by strong winds in Wales, causing power cuts for hundreds of homes. Major bridges had speed and lane restrictions due to the wind. Irish Ferries cancelled some sailings between Holyhead and Dublin. Arriva Trains Wales warned of delays and speed restrictions. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle due to high winds. Winds eased in the evening, but a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend led to the postponement of Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip.

Michael B. Jordan is set to star in a new film directed by Ryan Coogler, with whom he previously worked on Creed. He expressed his excitement about the project and his eagerness to work with his co-stars Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. The film is expected to be released in February 2018.

The theatre, established in 1875, is set to be revived for various performances, including theatrical shows, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios, located at the eastern end of the Palace, will also undergo repair and refurbishment. If funding goals are met, the theatre aims to reopen in 2018. This project is part of a larger east wing restoration initiative to transform Alexandra Palace into a new cultural hub. The glazed east court will be converted into a public space and exhibition area. The Heritage Lottery Fund is contributing Â£18.8m, Haringey Council is contributing Â£6.8m, and the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust aims to raise the remaining Â£1m by summer 2017. The theatre, which has been vacant for decades, retains much of its original decor and stage machinery.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has announced his retirement from international football. He earned 61 caps for England, making his senior debut in 2009. Milner was part of the squad for two World Cups and two European Championships, but played only three minutes at Euro 2016. He also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player, with 46 appearances since 2004. Milner scored his only international goal in England's 5-0 victory over Moldova in 2014.

Marcy Smith and her family escaped a house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, but their house was destroyed and their pets did not survive. The fire was started by rubbish burned in the wood stove. David, Smith's son, woke up the family and alerted them to the fire, saving them from the rapidly spreading flames. The community has rallied to support the family, donating clothes, shoes, and a bike for David.

The passage discusses the potential takeover of West Ham United by an energy drinks company, which is considering a Â£200m offer. The current majority stakeholders, David Sullivan and David Gold, bought the club in 2010 for Â£105m and now own more than 85% of it. The club has also been linked with takeovers from Qatari and Chinese groups since moving to London Stadium. Sullivan and Gold have mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to clear debts, but they plan to pass on their ownership to their children.

The MTV Movie Awards ceremony, held in Los Angeles, was a platform for promoting summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars was the big winner, taking home best movie and best female performance (Shailene Woodley). Woodley also won best kiss for a scene with Ansel Elgort. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for his role in American Sniper. Channing Tatum took home best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep won best villain for her role in Into the Woods. Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne were also among the winners. Kevin Hart, who was the target of size-related jokes, brought his kids on stage to accept the comedic genius award. Robert Downey Jr received the Generation Award, with his fellow Avengers stars presenting it to him. Clips from upcoming films like Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Ultron were shown during the ceremony.

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 cap, has scored five goals this season for Dundee United, whom he joined on loan from Aberdeen in July. Smith made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and has scored four times in 89 appearances for the club. St Mirren, who are at the bottom of the Championship, have acquired Smith permanently and will host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council plans to address 145 potholes daily using Jetpatcher machines over the next four months. Additionally, they will allocate extra staff to repair damaged drainage systems and clear debris from gutters due to heavy rain.

The incident occurred on EnQuest's Thistle platform, off Shetland, in December 2016. Six Wood Group contractors, including Steve Innes from Sunderland, were exposed to low levels of NORM (naturally occurring radioactive material) while removing a piece of pipework during a shutdown. The exposure was less than 1% of the reportable level, but EnQuest informed the HSE. EnQuest has since taken additional precautionary steps to prevent such exposure. The contractors have expressed concerns about potential long-term health effects and fears of cancer. The HSE was not made aware of the incident separately and did not investigate.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) purchased a bronze sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari from a New York art dealer, Art of the Past, in 2007 for $650,000. The dealer's manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, including the sculpture. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, India. After discussions with the Indian government's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), the museum decided to return the sculpture. The ASI submitted an official request for its return in May. The museum will seek compensation for the apparent fraud.

The passage describes a magnitude-4.8 earthquake that occurred in Italy, near the city of Lucca. The quake had a depth of 15.5km and was felt in nearby cities like Milan and Florence, as well as in the Garfagnana area where the epicenter was located. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. Italy is prone to earthquakes, with a notable one in L'Aquila in 2009 that resulted in nearly 300 deaths. The latest quake was described as "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow" by Alessandro Amato of the INGV. The area is still recovering from the aftermath of the L'Aquila earthquake, and six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of manslaughter for providing falsely reassuring information about the danger of tremors before the 2009 quake.

The passage describes a situation where Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, has successfully grown a fruit that is still attached to the plant and is not yet ripe for consumption. Despite his initial doubts about the suitability of South Yorkshire's climate for growing fruits, he has now seen positive results, which he expressed by jumping for joy.

The game Grand Theft Auto V, developed by Rockstar, has been delayed until 24 March. The release date was initially set for 27 January. The delay is to ensure the game receives additional testing and polishing for optimal quality. The company also announced that online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release. The PC version will offer enhanced graphics, including 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for up to triple monitor configurations. Minimum system requirements for running the game have been published. The game previously became the fastest-selling entertainment product, generating $1bn in revenue within three days of its initial release in 2013.

The 76-year-old artist, whose name is not mentioned, won the Â£25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)". The painting depicts a leper squint, a hole in medieval churches for undesirables to view services. The artist, who has been shortlisted three other times, chose this piece for the competition due to its small size and familiarity. The painting is described as "very subtle" and "minimal", but evokes a broad field of sympathy due to its subject matter. The prize, established in 1957, has previously been won by notable artists such as David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The daily newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, which support the ruling AK Party of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, were targeted in simultaneous night-time attacks on Thursday. The Yeni Safak building was attacked by four masked assailants, resulting in a fire that was quickly extinguished by firefighters. The Yeni Akit offices, located 20km away, also had windows shattered by gunfire. No casualties were reported, and police are currently investigating the incident, as no group has claimed responsibility. This attack follows a similar incident in September when pro-government protesters attacked the offices of the daily Hurriyet.

The 24-year-old player, previously with Burton, was under contract with Mansfield Stags but has agreed to join Grimsby Mariners on a free transfer starting from 1 January. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances.

ArsÃ¨ne Wenger, the Arsenal manager, has commented on the potential appointment of England manager Gareth Southgate on a permanent basis. Wenger praised Southgate's experience and competency, stating that the only way for Southgate to secure the job is by making the right decisions. Wenger also mentioned that he focuses on his job and is happy for Southgate to have the opportunity to show his quality. Additionally, Wenger discussed Arsenal's plans for their players, confirming that they will offer a new contract to defender Hector Bellerin and that midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss more games due to injury.

A local man employed at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint investigation, with the company cooperating fully.

The Transport Minister, Humza Yousaf, has announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats serving the Northern Isles.
