Some viewers have criticized Gallegos for feeding her dogs ice cream and fast food, but she defends her actions, stating that Cooper is healthy and in good shape.

Gary Locke, the former assistant manager of Kilmarnock and ex-Hearts team-mate of Allan Johnston, has been appointed as the permanent manager of Kilmarnock. He joined the club last summer and took over as interim manager after Johnston's resignation in February. Locke has had a successful run, losing only once in his seven games in charge. He will sign a three-year deal and will hold a press conference on Friday morning.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused a school in Seminole County of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, due to essential oils he wears to help manage his illness. The oils, manufactured by Doterra, are applied to Logan's head and neck to keep him calm and focused. Kemp claims the school threatened to remove Logan from class because the oils smelled and were a distraction to other students. Despite receiving a letter from the local school board stating the oils had created a problem for staff and students, Kemp insists she will continue to use the oils, as they have a positive impact on her son. However, the Lake County School District has since stated they will not suspend Logan, as it is a health issue.

The Sandpiper complex, a beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, was destroyed by a fire on Wednesday afternoon. The fire spread through 90 condos, causing the building to collapse. The cause of the fire is unknown, but it was so intense that it melted the paint off nearby buildings. Despite the efforts of 12 fire crews, they were unable to enter any of the summer homes. The building manager, Rob Taber, lost everything in the fire. The fire is being investigated, with claims suggesting it may have started near a car parked by the complex.

The Queen, who is 88 years old, enjoyed a ride on her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park today. She has a long-standing love for horses and has been riding since the age of four. The Queen is known for her preference for silk scarves over riding helmets, despite being encouraged to wear safety hats. She has bred several breeds of horses and ponies, including Fell ponies, which are one of the oldest equine breeds on the planet. The Queen's Fell pony is a gentle and hardy animal, originally used as a pack pony by the Vikings and later for transporting goods. Today, Fell ponies are popular for riders of all ages, including the Queen's grandchildren.

A dispute over noise levels between two neighbors in North Brisbane escalated into a fatal altercation. Leon Yeaman, 55, was allegedly punched by Phillip Pama, 28, during a confrontation in front of their homes. Pama, a married father of three, was sleeping when Yeaman was making noise. Pama has been charged with manslaughter and was granted conditional bail. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene. Neighbors described Yeaman as kind and generous, while his friend mentioned he was a schizophrenic pensioner who enjoyed playing loud music.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, was caught on camera attempting to hire a hitman to torture and kill her 15-year-old ex-lover, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. She offered 100,000 rubles (Â£1,400) for the job and specified that she wanted Vanya to suffer unbearable pain, with his arms and legs broken and his kidneys damaged. Simonova was arrested after handing over some expense money to the undercover police officer posing as a hitman. She now faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder.

Jose Mourinho, the Chelsea football manager, reveals that he talks to God every day but not about football. He has a strong faith and prays for personal matters, not for Chelsea's success. Mourinho, who is married to Matilde Faria, has two children and is an ambassador against hunger for the World Food Programme. He tries to separate his professional and personal life, despite his intense personality on the sideline. Chelsea is currently top of the league and will play against QPR this weekend.

Bob Barker, the former host of "The Price is Right" for 35 years, returned to the show for the first time in eight years on April 1, 2023. He hosted the first price-guessing game, "Lucky Seven," before handing over the hosting duties to Drew Carey. Despite his absence from the show for most of the past eight years, Barker seemed to have not missed a beat.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. on Friday morning for allegedly attempting to break into a house at midnight. He was charged with felony attempted burglary and destruction of property. Baldwin was posted with the Foreign Missions Branch of the service, which deals with the U.S.'s diplomatic activities. His security clearance was revoked, and he was put on leave following the arrest. He was to be arraigned on Friday afternoon, and no attorney was listed in court records. This arrest comes after a high-ranking supervisor was also put on leave for misconduct allegations, and follows a March 4 incident where two high-ranking officials were accused of driving into a secure area at the White House after drinking.

Atif Saeed, a 38-year-old freelance photographer from Lahore, Pakistan, bravely approached a hungry lion in a safari park, getting within 10 feet of it while armed only with a camera. He managed to capture a few frames before the lion's aggressive reaction forced him to retreat into his car. Despite the close call, Saeed found the experience amusing at the time but now acknowledges it as a risky encounter.

The New York City Police Department has released images of a tattoo found on an unidentified woman who was found dead in Brooklyn on March 22. The woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, was discovered unconscious near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. The tattoo, which is believed to be the name "Monique" etched across a tattooed ribbon within a heart topped with a rose, is the only distinctive feature found on the woman. The cause of death is still unknown and awaiting a medical examiner's report. Anyone with information about the woman is asked to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a two-bedroom home on the bed of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK. The home, which took a year and a half to build, is solar-powered and nearly self-sufficient, with gas-powered stove and hot water, and water from a nearby spring. The project cost around $25,000 and the couple plans to build another one.

Children who share iPads in class perform better in early literacy tests than those who do not, according to research by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University. Blackwell's study involved 352 students in a midwestern suburban school district and found that shared iPad users scored around 30 points higher than those who used the device on their own or had no iPad access. The research suggests that collaborative learning around the technology, rather than just collaboration, is the key factor contributing to improved literacy levels.

The passage describes a two-legged piglet, born without back legs, that has learned to walk on its front trotters. The heartwarming video of the piglet's progress has become an internet sensation. The piglet, nicknamed "super pig," lives on a farm in Sichuan province, China, and is cared for by farmer Ms. Duan. The piglet's siblings have all been born with four legs, but it has captured the hearts of thousands with its extraordinary balance and determination. This is not the first animal with two legs instead of four to gain popularity in China, as a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo also became a star attraction for walking on its front paws.

A pit crew member, Todd Phillips, was injured during the inaugural Indycar Grand Prix of Louisiana on Sunday. He was struck by the car of Francesco Dracone, who was coming in for tires and fuel on lap 25. Dracone's car spun, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips was taken to the infield care center for treatment and was released after receiving stitches for a cut on his leg. Dracone did not finish the race and ended up 23rd. Many cars struggled with traction during the race due to rain that had fallen for hours before the green flag.

The passage describes a horrific incident where a husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The couple had been married for only four days when Severiano, driven by jealousy, attacked his wife, who was known by the stage name Amanda Bueno. He first dragged her into the garden, then proceeded to smash her head into concrete paving 11 times and punched her in the face another 10 times. After leaving her unconscious, he returned with a handgun and shot her in the face five times at point-blank range. Severiano was later arrested after crashing a stolen car during his getaway. He confessed to the murder, stating that he was jealous of men looking at his wife. The couple was part of a dance troop called Jaula das Gostozuedas.

Sarah Wilson, a journalist and author of the best-selling book "I Quit Sugar," opened up about her personal struggle with mental illness, revealing she came close to taking her own life due to anxiety. She mentioned that a combination of issues, including mounting stress, anxiety, her thyroid disease, and distant family, drove her to believe her life was no longer worth living. Wilson also discussed the link between depression and anxiety, stating that they are intrinsically linked and that acknowledging this link can help better equip people to tackle the increasing rate of Australian women affected by stress and anxiety. She emphasized the importance of seeking help if needed, as one in three Australian women will experience anxiety in their lifetime, and depression and anxiety often lead to each other.

Elena Curtin, a pregnant woman from Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault for using a crowbar to attack her boyfriend's former girlfriend, who was found shooting heroin in her bathroom. The charge was dropped due to Curtin's justification, as Oregon law allows for physical force against an intruder who refuses to leave a resident's home. The ex-girlfriend had a history of harassing and threatening Curtin, and the boyfriend, who is the father of Curtin's child, had struggled with heroin in the past.

Gemma, a pit bull dog, was filmed in California being fed treats, but she expressed disgust when her owner tried to trick her with a broccoli spear. She spat it out on the floor. Despite this, she enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC has apologized for a link on its official website that directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link was for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, which were scrapped in 2011, and the website's URL address was transferred to a porn business due to the registration on hsbc.com.hk retiring. HSBC removed the hyperlink and assured the public that its website remains secure, as it offers various services such as checking account balances, transferring funds, and applying for loans and insurance.

A 13-year-old boy, Marcus, called 911 when a fire broke out in his Maryland home, trapping him and his 9-year-old sister, Aaliyah, in a second-floor bedroom. Marcus guided firefighters through the home, providing instructions and keeping his sister calm during the 11-minute call. Firefighters rescued them by breaking a window and handing Marcus out, with Lt. Kenny Ward giving his gas mask to Aaliyah. All four family members were taken to hospitals with non-life-threatening injuries.

Blue fluorescent algae, known as noctiluca scintillans, have been spotted along Australia's east coast, particularly in Jervis Bay. This single-celled phytoplankton, which is a type of algae, emits a luminous glow as a defense mechanism against another type of algae called diatoms. The sight of millions of these plankton lighting up the beach was described as a "beautiful supernatural scene." A similar display was seen in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014, and experts assure there's no cause for concern as the phenomenon is usually due to natural causes.

Breast cancer patients may be spared chemotherapy due to new genetic tests that determine the aggressiveness of the tumor and predict the risk of recurrence. These tests, such as Endopredict, can provide results within days after surgery, indicating a low risk of recurrence (as low as 5%) for some patients. This information can help patients make informed decisions about chemotherapy, as it may not be necessary for those with a low risk. However, these tests are currently available privately at a cost of around Â£2,500, and efforts are being made to make them available on the NHS.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, including at least one from HMS Illustrious, which was nicknamed "HMS Lusty" by the crew before it was decommissioned last year. Eighteen other ships also had emergency evacuations. The data comes nine months after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990, and in 2014, around 9% of personnel were female. Strict military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones, and women are flown back on flights usually reserved for injured troops. Most of the babies would have been conceived before the mother left the UK, but a small number of women may have become pregnant on tour.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material was found on the rooftop of Japan's equivalent to the White House, raising concerns about potential terrorism involving drones. The discovery came on the same day a Japanese court approved a government plan to restart two reactors at the Sendai nuclear power plant. The drone was equipped with a small camera, smoke flares, and a plastic bottle containing small traces of cesium, a common byproduct of nuclear reactors. The amount of cesium was not immediately harmful to humans. The discovery has raised concerns about terrorism attempts using drones at the Olympics and G7 summit. Japan has no flight restrictions for most of Tokyo, including the prime minister's residence and local and federal government buildings.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang province in China, takes his 84-year-old mother with Alzheimer's to work on the back of his motorbike every day. He ties a sash around both of their waists to ensure she doesn't fall off. His mother used to get lost when left alone, and after his father's passing, he decided to take her to work as there was no one else to care for her. He rides slowly to work, checks on her during the day, and feels a duty to care for her as she devoted her life to caring for him and his siblings.

The passage discusses a study that found an increase in heavy drinking and binge drinking among Americans, particularly women, between 2005 and 2012. Heavy drinking is defined as exceeding an average of one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men, while binge drinking is defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion at least once during the past month. The study found that women's drinking habits have been changing, with binge drinking rates among women rising more than seven times the rate among men in some areas. The study also found that despite the increases in heavy drinking, the percentage of people who drink any alcohol has remained relatively unchanged over time. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level. The increase in binge drinking does not surprise clinical director Terri Fukagawa, who has seen more people seeking treatment for alcoholism in the past four years. Public health experts offer various explanations for the increase in excessive drinking, including changed social norms

The passage discusses the overuse of caesarean sections in England, with over a quarter of women giving birth via this method. This rate has more than doubled since the early 1990s. The World Health Organization (WHO) warns that this figure should ideally be between 10% and 15%, due to the risks and costs involved. Caesareans can lead to infections, disability, or even death, and can divert resources from other patients. The WHO statement contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow women to have the operation even when there's no medical justification.

A woman named Michelle Filkins, 44, from West Wareham, was arrested for breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling items belonging to the owners in a yard sale. She was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property. The homeowner, Mark Conklin, discovered her on April 17 and confronted her, but she fled when he called the police. She was later arrested after attempting to re-enter the home. Items missing from the home include deck chairs, a grill, side tables, lamps, a painting, and various kitchen items. The police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them and are assisting victims in seeking restitution.

A woman named Bella Crooke lost her iPhone at a friend's birthday party on Saturday night. The phone was handed in to Albury Police Station on the NSW-Victoria border on Sunday morning. Police officers realized the phone was unlocked and used it to post selfies and photos of the phone in various locations around the police station on Bella's Facebook page. They also posted puns and humorous comments about the phone. Bella didn't realize what was happening until she arrived at the police station around 1 PM. By then, the original post had already garnered a humorous response from her friends and officers. Bella didn't have to give her name when she reclaimed her phone, as officers recognized her from her Facebook page. She has since put a password on her phone.

A five-day-old hippopotamus calf was killed during a fight between two adult male hippos in the Isimangaliso Wetland Park, Eastern South Africa. The calf's mother watched in horror as her baby was lifted into the air and dragged along the water's surface. The cause of the calf's death is unclear, but it may have been due to the adult hippos' aggression or playful behavior.

The passage describes a three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, priced at Â£575,000, which is a bargain compared to the area's average. However, the property has only three years left on its lease, making it a risky investment. The lease extension could cost up to Â£4.5 million, potentially increasing the property's value to over Â£6 million. The apartment is in need of renovation and is being sold by Russell Simpson. The property was built in 1893 and has a rich history, with notable residents including Sir Evan MacGregor and Sir Henry Fielding Dickens. The phone has been ringing non-stop since the property was listed, indicating high interest.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage that affected 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, causing registers to malfunction and leading to free drinks being given away. The outage began in the early evening on the east coast and late afternoon on the west coast. The company is working to resolve the issue, which was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh. The outage also affected Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores.

Terrorists are undergoing training in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire. These locations are also used to radicalize Muslims. The training activities are often disguised as ordinary community activities, but they have an ulterior motive. Incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales can be traced back to 1998. The area is also used by the British military for training due to its rugged terrain. Some would-be terrorists have been arrested in Wales, and one of the men convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby studied Arabic at a center in Wales. Community intelligence is important to authorities in identifying and preventing such activities.

The Omura's whale, a species previously thought to be extinct, was discovered on a remote beach in Western Australia after a tropical cyclone. This is the first sighting of the species in WA and only the second in Australia. The whale was identified through DNA profiling and will be buried and studied further for scientific research and possibly public display in museums. The Omura's whale is typically found in Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan, and has a sleek body shape and unique skeletal features.

The passage discusses the concern raised by Cheryl Rios, CEO of Go Ape Marketing, about Hillary Clinton's potential presidency due to her hormones. Rios believes that women should not be presidents because of their hormones, which she thinks could lead to irrational decisions, such as starting unnecessary wars. The passage also mentions that male leaders have historically been influenced by their hormones, leading to poor decisions. It highlights that women leaders take fewer unnecessary risks than their male counterparts and provides examples of male politicians who have been negatively impacted by their hormones. The passage also mentions that Hillary Clinton is considered "biologically primed" to lead due to her postmenopausal status. The passage concludes by emphasizing the importance of addressing gender bias in the workplace and the benefits of equality, stating that it benefits everyone, including companies, families, and marriages.

Robert Hardy, a veteran actor known for his roles in All Creatures Great and Small, playing Winston Churchill, and appearing in Harry Potter films, is selling his extensive collection of antiques in a Â£100,000 auction. The collection includes over 200 items, such as a diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a longbow, paintings, furniture, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, and crystal chandeliers. The auction will take place at Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire on Saturday. Hardy, who is a keen military historian and expert on the medieval longbow, is selling the collection due to downsizing and is sad to part with it.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man, is on the run after being named a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, 57. He failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was found dead at their shared home in Winter Garden. An initial investigation determined foul play. Shemansky has a history of bipolar mental illness, was involuntarily committed to a psychiatric ward for attempted suicide, and is on parole for battery on law enforcement. His mother was helping him through a divorce, and neighbors believe divorce proceedings may have pushed him over the edge. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not confirmed how Sandra Shemansky was killed. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without any provisions or medication. Anyone with information on his whereabouts is urged to contact authorities.

The city of Eugene in the United States has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. This decision was made by the IAAF Council, who chose to bypass the usual bidding process due to a unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene previously failed in its bid to host the 2019 event, which was instead awarded to Doha, Qatar. The IAAF Council made this decision based on a recent presentation that persuaded them of Eugene's capabilities to stage a world championships. The 2007 IAAF World Championships in Osaka, Japan was also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old care assistant from Gillingham, Kent, was jailed for 16 years for manslaughter after luring professional gambler Mehmet Hassan, 56, to his death in a honey trap. Granger used her good looks to befriend Hassan, who showered her with gifts, cash, and trips to fancy restaurants. She took advantage of his "soft target" status, as he was a divorced father who enjoyed the company of women and kept his winnings around his flat. Granger left Hassan's flat after making excuses and letting in her boyfriend and an accomplice, who tied him up and kicked him to death. Hassan's body was found with multiple broken bones, lying face down in his bedroom drowning in his own blood. Granger was found guilty of manslaughter but not guilty of murder. Her co-defendants, Kyrron Jackson and Nicholas Chandler, were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life with a

Cesc Fabregas, the Chelsea midfielder, has been struggling in the second half of the season, as highlighted in his performance against Holland on Tuesday. Despite a strong start to the season, his form has significantly dropped, and he has been given low ratings by Spanish newspapers. His durability has been questioned, and his role in Chelsea's title charge has declined due to fatigue. Fabregas has a history of post-Christmas slumps, as noted by his former club Barcelona, and his assists have decreased since mid-January. However, he still has the potential to help Chelsea secure the Premier League title with his passing ability and could prove doubters wrong with a late-season resurgence.

West Ham United is in talks to sign Jamaican teenager Deshane Beckford, who has impressed during a trial with the club. The 17-year-old forward from Montego Bay United has spent two weeks training with West Ham's academy and has caught the attention of coaches. Beckford, who has been linked with several European clubs, is considered one of the most promising prospects from the Caribbean. Meanwhile, West Ham has announced that season tickets for the Olympic Stadium will start at Â£289, making it the most affordable pricing strategy in the Premier League as they aim to fill the 54,000-capacity stadium for the 2016-17 season.

The passage describes a vicious assault on a huntsman, Mike Lane, by hunt saboteurs armed with iron bars on ropes. Despite providing evidence, including a video and names of suspects, to Wiltshire Police, the investigation was dropped due to insufficient evidence. Lane was beaten, suffered memory loss, and has been left disappointed and let down by the police. The attack occurred when the hunt was chasing an artificial scent, not a fox. The main suspect's photograph was issued, but he remains unidentified. The police's decision has dismayed hunt supporters across the country.

Adam Gadahn, an American born in California, converted to Islam in 1995 and moved to Pakistan in 2001. He became a prominent member of Al-Qaeda, serving as its chief English-language propagandist. He was known for his statements against the U.S. and was indicted for treason and material support to Al-Qaeda in 2006. He was killed in a U.S. counterterrorism operation in January 2015.

The passage describes a viral video of a five-year-old Chinese boy named Mai Zizhuo, who has been playing basketball since he was two and a half years old. He demonstrates exceptional skills, scoring hoops and dribbling two basketballs at once, which has earned him many fans in China. The video has stunned netizens, with some questioning if it's special effects and others feeling ashamed of their own basketball skills.

Tom O'Carroll, a former member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which advocated for the legalization of child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. PIE campaigned for the age of sexual consent to be lowered to ten and for incest to be legalized. O'Carroll was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals." He attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation, which was chaired by comedian John Cleese. Hacked Off, established in response to the phone-hacking scandal, is campaigning against what it perceives as the biased and unfair Independent Press Standards Organization and advocates for a statutory body to regulate the press, as recommended by the Leveson Inquiry.

The Bondi Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as a unique catwalk for Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The event, organized by Ten Pieces, a unisex clothing label headed by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, showcased a monochrome collection of ten pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways. The collection was presented in the empty pool and along the break wall, with a beautiful ocean backdrop. Guests enjoyed nibbles and drinks from Icebergs and Santa Vittoria, while beachgoers and passersby stopped to watch the show.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan spent his Friday at a safari park in Northern California with his family. He posed with and fed a rare white tiger, as well as giraffes and sea lions. Khan recently announced his next fight will be against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian teenager, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, according to prosecutors. His name was initially included in an Israeli memorial commemorating fallen soldiers and victims of terrorism at Mount Herzl, the national cemetery. However, his family and Almagor, an organization representing victims of terror in Israel, objected to his inclusion. Abu Khdeir's father refused to have his son's name listed between soldiers of the occupation, while Almagor described his death as a rogue attack and not a terror victim. Following his father's complaints, the National Insurance Institute of Israel will remove Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial.

The YouTube user Lionel Hutz filmed his young son trying to use their family cat as a pillow in the garden. The cat initially sat still, but quickly moved away when the boy lay down on it. The boy then followed the cat to its new location and repeated the process. Eventually, the cat had enough and went inside. Later, the boy and cat were seen making up, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

Robert Kushner, a former drug dealer turned basketball coach, lost his job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying in a police corruption trial in Philadelphia. He was arrested in 2007 and 2011, and pleaded guilty to driving under the influence in 2008. Despite his past, Kushner claims he never intended to deceive the school and believes he is innocent of the 2011 charges. He currently coaches in a Narberth summer league, where he is described as an excellent coach.

Six people were injured in an explosion at a controversial chemical plant in Fujian, China, which produces paraxylene (PX), a potentially carcinogenic chemical used in polyester production. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility due to an oil leak, but no toxic chemical spill was reported. The fire was extinguished by over 600 firefighters, and residents near the plant shared photos of the incident on social media. The plant had a previous explosion in 2013, and its construction in Xiamen faced protests due to pollution concerns, leading to its relocation to a more remote location.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager, is known for wearing his socks low and not using full-sized shinpads due to superstition. Despite referees advising him to pull his socks up, he plans to continue this practice. He recently made his first Premier League start against QPR, which was a tough game in a relegation scrap. Grealish is pleased to have gotten his first start but is not satisfied with the outcome of the match. He appreciates the faith shown in him by his coach and hopes to get more starts before the end of the season.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has been diagnosed with global and irreversible brain damage. She is no longer in a medically induced coma but remains unresponsive. Her grandmother, Cissy Houston, stated that she can live in this condition for a lifetime. Brown does not respond to visitors or familiar voices, and her eyes do not follow a person around the room. She has a tracheostomy in her throat. Despite initial reports of improvement, her condition remains the same as it has been for nearly three months. The quality of her life will not be known for years to come.

Russia is on the verge of securing a spot in the Fed Cup final after taking a 2-0 lead against Germany. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point and won the match 4-6, 7-6(4), 6-3 against Sabine Lisicki. Svetlana Kuznetsova also won her match in straight sets against Julia Goerges. Both players struggled with their serves, with Pavlyuchenkova committing 13 double faults and Lisicki making 63 unforced errors. Russia needs one more win from Sunday's three matches to secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales, particularly those in the Hunter region, are being warned to prepare for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that more storms will hamper clean-up efforts, as they still have over 4,000 jobs from the 24,196 requests to complete. Meteorologists suggest that an east coast low, similar to the one that hit last week, could bring heavy rain from Thursday through to Saturday. The Hunter region, which was severely affected by the last storm, is of particular concern. The weather system is expected to move quickly, with two days of rain likely but not the same three days of wind and rain experienced last week. The Bureau of Meteorology suggests that rain will increase this week, peaking between Thursday and Saturday, and further rainfall is likely for catchments that have already experienced flooding.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loco" video, denied claims that she attempted suicide. She posted photos of bruises on her arms, stating she collapsed due to low blood pressure after a domestic accident. Italian media reported that her boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, suggested she tried to commit suicide, but Moric clarified that she was fine and had no intention to end her life. She was once married to paparazzi snapper Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photos.

The passage discusses the anticipation of the arrival of the second child for Kate and William, with the British public hoping for a traditional name. According to a YouGov poll for the Sunday Times, if the child is a girl, the favorite name is Diana, after William's late mother. If it's a boy, James is the preferred name. Many people are hoping for a girl, with only 3% hoping for a younger brother for Prince George. The poll also shows that the majority of Brits support William's decision to take six weeks paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber killed 17 people and injured 64 others, including an Afghan lawmaker, in a protest in Khost, Afghanistan. The attack occurred near a group of protesters on their way to join a larger rally against the provincial governor. The Taliban has denied responsibility for the attack, and no other organization has claimed it yet.

Dani Alves, the Brazilian right-back, is likely to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. He has spent seven successful years at Barcelona, winning multiple titles, but has been unable to agree on a new deal. His agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that negotiations have ended, stating that it doesn't make sense for Barcelona to wait until April to renew his contract.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old Argentine striker currently playing for Boca Juniors on loan from Southampton, has expressed his desire for Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca. Osvaldo believes that the duo would be a great fit for the club and would be loved by the fans. Pirlo, a renowned midfielder, and Totti, a Roma legend, are highly respected in the football world.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old amateur jockey, experienced a spectacular fall from his horse, Merrion Square, during a race at Wincanton. Despite the fall, which involved double somersaults and was watched hundreds of thousands of times online, Ferguson suffered only a cut on his nose. He returned to riding out and is undeterred from getting back in the saddle. Ferguson described the fall as a blur and expressed gratitude for his luck, as he received abuse from his peers but also gained hundreds of Twitter followers. He jokingly considered a gymnastics career after racing.

James Haskell, the London Wasps captain, showed his excitement for the new Avengers: Age of Ultron movie by posting an Instagram photo of himself dressed as Iron Man, played by Robert Downey Jr. Haskell, who has played rugby in France, Japan, and New Zealand, returned to Wasps in 2012 and has since made over 100 appearances for the club. He has also earned 57 caps for England.

The wide leg trouser is a prominent trend in Spring/Summer 2015, with various styles such as denim, cropped, printed, and striped. It offers an alternative to skinny jeans, which have been popular for several years. The trend has made a comeback since the 1970s, with celebrities like Louise Redknapp endorsing it. The wide leg can be intimidating, especially for shorter individuals, but pairing it with high heels and simple tops can create a flattering look. Denim is the easiest way to achieve the trend, with brands like Gucci and Topshop offering wide-leg jeans. Celine showcased colorful billowing bottoms, while Stella McCartney and Finery London provide dressier options. The wide-leg trouser can update your wardrobe and is suitable for various occasions, including evening looks.

The University of Michigan has decided to proceed with screening the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students. More than 200 students signed a petition asking the school not to show the movie as part of a series of social events. Bradley Cooper was nominated for an Oscar for his portrayal of Chris Kyle, a Navy Seal and the most lethal sniper in U.S. military history. Kyle was fatally shot at a Texas shooting range in 2013. Some students believed the movie's depiction of the Iraq War reflected negatively on the Middle East and people from that region. The University's Detroit metropolitan area is home to the nation's largest Arab-American population. However, there was a backlash to the decision to cancel the movie, and a counter-petition asked school officials to reconsider. On Wednesday, the University's vice president for student life announced that the show will go on, stating that the initial decision to cancel the movie was not consistent with the high value the University of Mich

Two French tourists allegedly set a Quokka, an animal native to Western Australia, on fire on Rottnest Island on April 3. The Quokka survived but was singed. The tourists, aged 18 and 24, were charged with animal cruelty and will appear in court on April 17.

Alice Barker, a 102-year-old dancer, was part of chorus lines in New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar during the 1930s and 1940s, performing alongside notable figures such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra. Despite being featured in motion pictures, she had never seen any of them. Her photographs and memorabilia were lost over the years, and she had never seen herself dancing until now. Mark Cantor of Jazz-on-Film.com and volunteers created a video of "soundies" â early music videos â and showed them to Barker at her nursing home, delighting her with the experience.

The passage discusses a decline in the tradition of washing one's own car in Britain, with a third of men admitting they've never done it. Most drivers prefer car washes, and only 5% have asked their children to help. Factors contributing to this trend include shops opening on Sundays, more TV sports, and the rise of hand car washes. Cars are most likely to be washed by their owners during holidays, with Birmingham, Chelmsford, and Sheffield having the highest rates. Audi, Toyota, and BMW owners are most likely to wash their cars, while Range Rover, Peugeot, and Mercedes owners least often.

Martin Skrtel, a Liverpool defender, praised Steven Gerrard's impact on him since joining the club in 2008. He acknowledged that Liverpool will face a challenge in replacing Gerrard, who is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa and potentially lead the team to the final on his birthday. Skrtel considers Gerrard one of the best players in the world and synonymous with Liverpool. He believes the club has potential replacements for Gerrard, but they need the right support to fill his void. Both players could return to the line-up for the match against Villa after serving bans.

Jack Nicklaus, at 75, made a hole-in-one on the fourth hole during the Masters' Par-3 Contest, his first on the Augusta National course. He was playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. Nicklaus became the youngest to win the Masters in 1963 and has won it six times. He is one of five golfers to achieve the Career Grand Slam.

Tornado sirens blared in Kansas on Wednesday night as multiple storms reported twisters. A tornado was spotted about 6 miles northwest of Goddard, which missed Wichita but posed potential risks to other communities. Nighttime tornadoes are considered the most dangerous. Other tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas, near Aetna. Kansas was not the only state affected; a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage and flooding. More storms are expected in the midwest, mississippi river valley, tennessee river valley, and near the southern great lakes on Thursday.

An Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter charges for fatally shooting Eric Harris, whom he intended to subdue with a taser. Bates claims the shooting was accidental and has apologized to Harris' family. The incident occurred during a weapons sting operation on April 2. Bates, 73, was granted permission to go on a family vacation to the Bahamas, which was criticized by Harris' family. Bates' lawyer stated that the preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2, and they look forward to dealing with the facts in the courtroom. Allegations of preferential treatment and forged records for Bates have been made, but the Tulsa County Sheriff's Office denies these claims. Two deputies involved in Harris' arrest have been reassigned due to threats against them and their families.

Conor McGregor, an Irish fighter, is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11. He has recently gotten a tiger tattoo on his stomach and shared it on Instagram, stating "if you see the tiger, it's too late." McGregor is known for his confidence and has expressed that he has more motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it. The two have a tense relationship, with McGregor previously grabbing Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin.

Tony Abbott, the Australian Prime Minister, was criticized for skolling a beer at an Australian rules function, which was seen as glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with alcohol consumption. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor, argued that this behavior sets a problematic culture where drinking is about how quickly and how much one can consume, rather than socializing with friends. Despite health minister Sussan Ley defending Abbott's actions, critics maintain that he should set an example that one doesn't have to drink heavily to be a 'true blue Aussie bloke.'

The passage discusses a significant increase in HIV cases in Scott County, Indiana, following the approval of a short-term needle exchange program by Governor Mike Pence. As of now, there are 120 confirmed HIV cases and 10 preliminary positive cases linked to the county. The program, which has been in effect for over two weeks, has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and collected about 1,400 used syringes. The outbreak is primarily among intravenous drug users, with the use of the high-powered painkiller Opana being a significant factor. The future of the Scott County program and similar legislation in other counties is uncertain, as Governor Pence opposes needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy. The House has approved a bill allowing 23 Indiana counties with high hepatitis C rates to establish their own needle-exchange programs, but it is unclear whether the Senate will support it.

The passage describes an Arsenal fan who made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a test on her knowledge of the football club. The test covered various aspects of Arsenal, including its history, players, and recent performances. Saskia scored 87% and received positive feedback from her boyfriend, who decided not to end their relationship. The test was well-received by the public, with many praising Saskia's knowledge and the boyfriend's creativity. However, some criticized the boyfriend for taking the test too far.

Carlos Toro, a former mid-level member of the Medellin cartel, worked as an undercover operative for the DEA for 27 years after fleeing Colombia due to a confrontation with his boss. He provided valuable information about his former bosses and associates, aiding in the prosecution of cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. Despite his significant contributions, Toro is now facing deportation as he was not granted US citizenship as promised, and his temporary visa has expired. He is currently in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits, and is prepared to go into hiding if necessary.

The passage describes a tragic incident where a 14-year-old girl was allegedly gang-raped by five men from her village in India. After the incident, she set herself on fire using kerosene, resulting in severe burns. The accused men have been arrested. The incident has sparked heightened sensitivity to the issue of sexual assault in India, following a documentary about a similar case that led to protests and calls for more protection for women. The girl's family reportedly told her to keep quiet about the attack.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal will not have Robin van Persie available for the derby against Manchester City due to fitness issues, despite van Persie claiming he was fit to play. Van Gaal has ruled out both van Persie and Luke Shaw from the match. The game is a significant opportunity for United to secure a top-three finish and avoid Champions League qualifying. Van Gaal aims to control his aggression and learn from past mistakes, acknowledging City as a tough opponent. He is looking forward to experiencing the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford for the first time since joining the club.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against high ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their match at the Emirates Stadium. The protest was organized by Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906 fan groups. Fans held banners reading "Â£5bn and what do we get? Â£64 a ticket" and "Football without fans is nothing". The protest aimed to raise awareness of the struggles fans face due to rising ticket prices, with some of the highest prices in the Premier League. Fans called the prices "extortionate" and expressed concern about losing a generation of fans if the issue is not addressed.

A newborn baby named Star Reader was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, within days of being born in Barnsley, West Yorkshire. After an unsuccessful attempt to unclog her bile ducts, a liver transplant was the only option. Star's parents, Jade Reader and Matthew Bygrave, were told neither of them was a suitable match for a partial liver transplant. Star's maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, offered part of her liver and successfully saved her niece's life. Star underwent the operation in November and has since made a good recovery, although she will require regular blood tests, liver function tests, and anti-rejection medication for the rest of her life.

Chelsea players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in Audi's Football Challenge. The challenge involved various games such as firing balls into car boots, playing over a makeshift tennis court with a car as the net, and shooting at cars from long range. Hazard and Ake won most of the rounds, but Remy and Willian surprisingly won the final challenge. However, Willian accidentally smashed the wing mirror of one of the cars during his shot.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, was sentenced on Wednesday for causing a highway crash that killed a Vermont couple and their unborn baby. Dellinger, 54, pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault for the fetus's death. He faces 12 to 24 years in prison when sentencing resumes on Thursday. Dellinger's attorneys claimed he was suffering from ambien withdrawal, the effects of a psychiatric drug overdose, prozac, and advanced symptoms of multiple sclerosis at the time of the crash. He initially charged with two counts of reckless manslaughter, which were later upgraded to negligent homicide.

Lacey Spears, the ex-wife of Chris Hill, was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning their five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, with salt. She was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison, which was less than the maximum 25 years to life. Spears showed no emotion during her sentencing. Chris Hill, the boy's father, expressed his hope that Spears would die in prison and criticized her lack of emotion during the sentencing. Spears' lawyer requested the minimum 15 years to life, describing her as a hardworking single mother who loved her son unconditionally. Prosecutors argued for the maximum sentence, stating that Spears had a bizarre need for attention and loaded her son's feeding tube with a lethal amount of salt while continuing to blog about his condition. Spears maintained her innocence and planned to appeal the verdict.

The passage discusses two new strains of influenza, H3N2 and B/Phuket, which caused an increase in deaths in Europe and the United States during the northern winter. To combat this, an improved vaccination is arriving in Australia, which includes protection against both strains. The vaccine was delayed by a month due to the modification. High-risk groups, such as the very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians, can access free, government-funded flu shots from April 20. Experts believe the modified vaccine is worth waiting for, as it should provide a better match against the circulating strains globally.

The Lincoln Tomb in Springfield, Illinois, is facing criticism and potential budget cuts, which could threaten its management. The tomb, designed by Larkin Mead and dedicated by President Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, has undergone repairs and renovations totaling over $2.5 million. However, it was recently criticized in National Geographic magazine for having "all the historical character of an office lobby." The tomb's interior was renovated last year, and its interior lighting was upgraded. Despite these improvements, the tomb's hours and staffing have been reduced due to funding cuts, and its future management is uncertain due to proposed budget cuts and a plan to eliminate the state historic preservation agency.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 1990s fashion trends, including chokers, berry-colored lips, round sunglasses, and Calvin Klein logo t-shirts. However, the return of JNCO jeans, which were popular at 1990s raves, has been met with horror by those who wore them the first time around. The article then lists several other 1990s and early 2000s trends that should be left in the past, such as bucket hats, camouflage print, taking trends to the extreme, UGG boots, daisy dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, and harem trousers. Serena Williams reached the semi-finals of the Miami Open after defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets. This victory marked her 700th career win, and she will face Simona Halep in the next round. Halep advanced to the semi-finals by defeating Sloane Stephens. The Miami Open has seen several celebratory cakes presented to players for reaching significant milestones, with Andy Murray receiving one for his 500th career win the previous day.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani entrepreneur and activist, was shot dead in Karachi after locking up her second-floor cafe. She was known for her advocacy of technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship. Mahmud had recently led a discussion on Balochistan, a province in Pakistan where separatists have been fighting an insurgency, despite authorities shutting down the event. She had received death threats in the past for handling this topic. Mahmud was a figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance in Pakistan, and her death has caused widespread grief and gratitude for her work.

The passage discusses the plight of Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu refugee who has been living in a slum in Jammu, Kashmir for the past 70 years. He was born in Punjab province, part of modern-day Pakistan, and fled to India during the partition of the sub-continent in 1947. He and thousands like him have been denied citizenship rights, including the right to own property or vote in state elections, and have been classified as refugees. Despite this, they have been living in India for generations and have contributed to the country's prosperity. However, they have been marginalized and live in abject poverty. Recently, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), a Hindu nationalist party, won a share of power in Kashmir and has pledged to normalize the status of the West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs). Yoshinori Muto, a forward for FC Tokyo, is considering a move to Chelsea this summer. Chelsea has made an offer, believed to be around Â£4 million, for Muto. However, Muto is keen on joining a club where he can play regularly and develop his skills. He is currently thinking about his decision carefully. Muto has been praised for his potential and intelligence by his former coach, Ranko Popovic, who believes he could be a big hit at Stamford Bridge. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is aware of Muto but has not commented on him publicly.

Australia has dropped its policy of not selecting the best players if they are playing overseas, which leaves England looking outdated. Stuart Lancaster should be free to pick his best players, regardless of where they play. Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell, who play for Toulon, are top-class performers and could potentially play against England in the World Cup. Steffon Armitage, another Toulon player, has improved since moving to France and should be considered for the England squad. Nick Abendanon has also become a better player since moving to France. Jonny Wilkinson's move to France improved his game, and he should have been considered for the England squad. England's policy of not selecting overseas players is misguided and could lead to "what ifs" after the World Cup.

The FireChat app, developed by Open Garden, allows users to chat with friends without the need for the web or mobile signal by creating a wireless mesh network. The app has been downloaded over five million times and uses Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) and Android's similar feature for sending messages and photos. Greenstone, a small egg-shaped device, has been developed to strengthen these off-the-grid networks by acting as a beacon or booster for messages. It can extend the range of messages up to 200ft (61 metres) and is currently under development, working with FireChat at a range of around 20ft (6 metres). Greenstone has a one-year battery life and can hold up to 1,000 recent messages.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, is challenging the negative connotations of the word 'fat' by embracing it as a honest and body-positive description of her own physique. She stands at 5'3'' and is married, referring to herself as'short' and 'wife' alongside 'fat'. Bustle believes that 'fat' does not have to be synonymous with 'ugly' and that beauty comes in various sizes. She has noticed an increase in size discrimination in the workplace and negative perceptions of larger people, especially among young girls who wish to be thinner. However, she finds hope in studies showing that exposure to body diversity can lead to increased tolerance and acceptance of different body types. Bustle performs burlesque to expose her audiences to a 'fat' body in a positive and glamorous way, aiming to change their perceptions. Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger, has been frequently seen on the bench this season, with his teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil. They posed for a Lanvin photoshoot, Arsenal's official tailor since 2013. Walcott, who has been named on the substitutes' bench for 17 of Arsenal's 33 Premier League games, came on for the last six minutes of Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea. He is hoping to make his first Arsenal start since March 14 when Arsenal faces Hull on Monday.

The collection of props and puppets from legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker, spanning his 30-year career, will be auctioned off on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on PropStore.com. The collection, valued at $746,100, includes items from films like Men in Black, Batman Forever, How the Grinch Stole Christmas, and Planet of the Apes. Some of the highlights include the Alien Edgar Bug from Men in Black (estimated value: $40,000), the Two Face mask from Batman Forever ($1,500), and the Grinch costume from How the Grinch Stole Christmas ($8,000). Other notable items include the Harry suit from Harry and the Henderson ($6,000), the Bat Gremlin from Gremlins 2 ($8,000), and the Michael Jackson Robotic Transformation Face from Moonwalker ($3,000).

Carwyn Scott-Howell, a seven-year-old British boy, tragically fell to his death while skiing in the French Alps with his family. He became separated from his mother during their last run of the day and ventured into dense woodland, where he fell over a 164ft drop. His mother, Ceri, desperately searched for him, and his footprints in the snow led police to his body. Carwyn was described as a daring, outgoing, and determined youngster with a handsome smile. He was an experienced skier and snowboader, starting at the age of three. His family, including his mother, Ceri, and siblings, Antonia and Gerwyn, are devastated by his loss.

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old girl from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia after becoming obsessed with her weight and wanting to be "size zero." She started a diet, but it escalated into eating only one piece of fruit a day and hiding food. Her weight loss led to a heart attack, and she was hospitalized. After recovery, she joined eating disorder teams and child and adolescent mental health services. Now, she has gained confidence and made it to the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, promoting positive body image.

Raheem Sterling was urged by Liverpool fans to stay at the club during the unveiling of the new home kit, which is the first offering from US sports brand New Balance. The kit features all white branding and a new style of collar. Sterling, along with other players, posed with the kit and interacted with fans at Anfield. Despite recent speculation about his future, Sterling and other players expressed their commitment to the club and their excitement for the upcoming season.

The largest high-definition map of dark matter has been produced, covering 0.4% of the night sky. The map, created by researchers at the University of Manchester, shows clumps of mysterious particles and was released at the April meeting of the American Physical Society. The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Survey (DES) led by Fermilab, which uses the Dark Energy Camera on the Victor M. Blanco Telescope in Chile. The survey aims to map 12.5% of the entire sky over five years, creating a 3D map of dark matter and dark energy. The map shows large filaments of matter along which visible galaxies and galaxy clusters lie and cosmic voids where very few galaxies reside. The survey uses gravitational lensing to study the distortion caused by the gravitational pull of dark matter.

Manchester United have made an official approach for Memphis Depay, a 21-year-old winger currently playing for PSV Eindhoven. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, is familiar to United manager Louis van Gaal from their time together with the Dutch national team. Depay's contract with PSV is worth more than the Â£15 million offer from Tottenham last summer. He is enjoying a prolific season and has been tipped to become as good as Arjen Robben and even better than a young Cristiano Ronaldo. Depay was handed his first Oranje call-up in 2013 and was selected for Holland's World Cup squad last year, scoring the winning goal in their 3-2 victory over Australia.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 lead in the first leg of the Youth Cup final against Manchester City, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a late goal. The match was played at the Academy Stadium, and both teams had their chances. Chelsea's defense, led by Jake Clarke-Salter and Fikayo Tomori, was strong, while Manchester City's midfield, featuring Isaiah Brown and Isaac Buckley-Ricketts, was lively. Manchester City's youngsters, such as Aaron Nemane and Ruben Sammut, showed promise but were unable to find the back of the net. The second leg will be played at Stamford Bridge.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate and Catholic, believes that people are born with a sexual preference, but he does not support same-sex marriage as a constitutional right. He thinks that states should regulate marriage and that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. He also stated that he would attend the same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, even if he did not agree with the decision. Rubio has received significant financial commitments for his presidential campaign.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde, a Spanish-Latvian couple, have embarked on a cycling journey around the world with no specific plans or agenda. They started in London and have since covered nearly 7,000 miles in 16 countries, living on less than three euros each per day. They rely on free accommodation, such as camping and hosting websites, and their primary expense is food, which costs 2.74 euros each per day. They have traversed through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, and Turkey, and plan to continue into Asia and eventually cycle the length of the American continent.

A couple from Texas, who got married in 2012, are suing James Evans, the owner of Premiere Photos, for allegedly printing racial slurs on the bottom of their wedding photos. The couple discovered the slurs months after their wedding when the bride's sister informed them about the incident. Evans has denied the allegations and refused to apologize. The couple is seeking an apology and is suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract.

Mike Brown, England's full-back, has admitted to taking a cautious approach in recovering from a recent concussion. He is unsure when he will return to action for his club side, Harlequins, as he pulled out of their match against Saracens at Wembley last weekend. Brown is determined not to suffer an extended break and will not rush himself back to action. He was knocked out cold in England's match against Italy in February and pulled out of the match against Ireland in March due to concussion symptoms. Brown has praised the increased awareness of concussion symptoms, driven by players undergoing World Rugby online modules, which helped him realize he was not ready to face Ireland. He emphasizes the importance of being honest about symptoms and the potential long-term dangers of concussions.

The passage suggests that the decline in the frequency of sexual activity among Britons, from five times a month in 1990 to three times a month now, may be due to increased smartphone use and the blurring of boundaries between work and personal life. This has led to less time spent with partners, as people are constantly checking emails and dealing with work-related matters, even late in the evening.

Tibetan Mastiffs, once highly valued and expensive dogs in China, are now being sent to slaughterhouses due to a decline in popularity. This is partly due to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has made it difficult for wealthy businessmen to give the dogs as gifts to officials. Additionally, recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities have impacted the breed's popularity. The dogs are now being used for their meat in cheap hotpots and their skin for leather belts. Animal welfare workers have rescued a group of dogs from a slaughterhouse, but it is feared that many more are meeting a similar fate. The breed's boom began in 2005, but its popularity has since declined due to urbanization and the realization that the dogs are not well-suited to city living.

Every woman surveyed in Paris claimed to have experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport. Half of them were victims before the age of 18. The survey found that "every female user of mass transit has been a victim" of gender harassment or sexual assault, often unaware due to conditioning. The poll of 600 women found that half had first suffered harassment under 18. Harassment ranges from insults to sex attacks or rape. Six out of ten women fear being attacked, compared to three out of ten men. The problem limits women's freedom, forcing them to alter daily lives. The poll led to calls for a campaign to stem sexist or threatening behavior. Attackers often act with impunity, and women need better education on what constitutes normal behavior.

The passage discusses a competition called #EverydayFix by Direct Line, where groups designed products to solve common everyday problems. The top emergency identified was not being able to sleep, leading to the creation of the Snooze alarm clock by Instruments. Another product, the Forget Me Lock by Onn Studio, helps users remember if they've locked their front door. The Nipper, the world's smallest mobile phone charger, was also designed by Impulse. The public can vote for their favorite product on Twitter, and the winner will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign.

Police and Crime Commissioner Vera Baird is under investigation for awarding over Â£500,000 of taxpayers' money to a charity she runs alongside the force's chief constable, Sue Sim. The charity, Victims First Northumbria, supports crime victims in their area. Critics accuse them of creating a conflict of interest and a "soap opera" within the force. The Home Secretary allowed PCCs to commission services for victims of crime, and Baird boasted about securing funds for the charity. However, critics describe her selection as inappropriate and a conflict of interest. The Ministry of Justice will investigate whether any conflict of interest rules have been broken.

The passage describes a horrific assault on a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, by a group of individuals known as the "tattoo terrorists". The ringleader, Corry "Corey" Campbell, believed Valecce had hurt his cat, Pebbles, and was staying in Campbell's mother's basement. The basement became a torture chamber where Valecce was strapped to a chair and violated for three days. Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng, and friend Carl Halin cornered Valecce, punched, slapped, and spit on him, and filmed the abuse. They tattooed offensive messages on Valecce's body, including "rip pebbles" and swastikas. Valecce suffered severe injuries and was able to escape on April 1.
